description: In The Crypts of Plumbous, the player has to fight alien ships who are trying to raid underground Nuclear waste storage for some unknown reason and unleash it on the planet. The game is a side scrolling shoot-em up, which is kind of reminiscent of Defender. There are various skill levels, from "Very Easy" to "Really Tough".

sample_screenshots.caption: Alien Ship stealing nuclear waste cask

title: The Crypts of Plumbous

description: In E.T. Phone Home! the player controls Elliott, the hero of the movie E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial. He has to search his neighborhood for pieces that the E.T. wants to build his transmitter. Depending on the difficulty level, the player may or may not need all the pieces to complete the game. It is also possible to communicate telepathically with E.T. to get a reminder of which pieces he is looking for. As Elliott looks for the pieces, he is pursued by a number of men who are trying to stop him from completing his task.

sample_screenshots.caption: E.T. shows the objects he seeks

title: E.T. Phone Home!

description:
This is a compilation of three games by Imagic: Laser Gates, Quickstep and Wing War.

Laser Gates is a side scrolling shoot-em-up in the same genre as Scramble. You must blast through gates before you hit them as well as fight enemy ships and installations.

"Quick Step" is a 1-2 player game where food items scroll down the screen vertically, and you must hop from item to item and change the item to your color. But you play against an opponent (human or computer) who is trying to change it to their color. You must make the color change before the item scrolls off the screen, but if you are standing on the object as it scrolls of, you lose a life.

In "Wing War", you play a dragon who is trying to collect her eggs and return them to her lair. The player flies from screen to screen and encounters various creatures while hunting for eggs.

sample_screenshots.caption: A solid gate that must be blasted through

title: Imagic 1-2-3

description:
OVERVIEW

Programmed exclusively for the Atari 8-bit computers, Gauntletak! was one of the earliest "cave-flyer games." It was also one of the earliest games that functioned in the shareware mode of distribution, though the word had not been coined yet, and was generally distributed on BBSes. The shareware version was named Gauntlet, and, though it was released a year before Atari's release of the popular coin-op arcade game by the same name, the developer opted to rename it for the paid version.

GAMEPLAY Gauntletak! is a side-view 2D shooter in which the player controls a lander-like ship in a zero-gravity cave environment, progressing through fifty screens and facing progressively more difficult enemies and situations before facing the final Kingship.

Movement is similar to other lander-style games, though simplified by the lack of gravity. Pressing the joystick in any direction thrusts in that direction, with momentum maintained until either canceled by thrust in the opposite direction, or pressing the X key to cancel all motion. Meanwhile, holding down the fire button while pointing in any direction fires the ship's weapons in that direction, allowing the player to drift in one direction while firing in any other direction. The controls are simple and intuitive, without the complexity and higher learning curve involved in many other lander-type games.

The core portion of the game involves avoiding and destroying a variety of enemies, including homing proximity mines, ground installations that fire all sorts of guns and missiles, and a variety of alien ships whose firepower increases over the course of the game. The alien ships have varying AI behavior, from simply pursuing the player directly to using the terrain to take cover from player fire. To succeed, the player must use the terrain as cover and avoid being detected by too many on-screen enemies at once or be swarmed and damaged excessively or destroyed.

The player's ship fires direct-fire fusion bolts in a steady autofire, limited to six bolts on-screen at any given time, creating tiny explosions on impact. At the beginning of each game, the player also chooses one of three missile types, with different characteristics and tactical uses, that will be used for the entirety of that game. Missile ammunition is limited to 10, but replenishes periodically.

The environment in Gauntletak! is completely destructible, and sometimes must be blown through to progress to the next screen. Beginning game options also provide an option to play the game without any landscape whatsoever.

Everything in the game takes damage continuously as long as it is in contact with an explosion or some other object. The player's ship starts with 30 points of shield damage capacity, and if that shield is ever reduced to zero, the next hit will destroy it. Every screen completed increases the player's shield by 2, up to a maximum of 99, and the player receives 100 bonus points per shield point remaining at the end of every screen. Every 10,000 points, the player receives an additional 10 shield points. Thus, it is important to build up shield points in the early game so as to bring in enough points to get the 10,000-point shield bonus every one or two screens.

NOTEWORTHY TECHNICAL ASPECTS

One of the most noteworthy aspects of Gauntletak!, beside its sophisticated treatment of movement and intertia, was the sheer number of moving objects it can have on the screen at once -- often ten or so enemies, six of your fusion bolts and scads of enemy shots and missiles -- despite the fact that the Atari 8-bit video driver made this impossible because of its need to redraw the whole screen when even one pixel was changed. The author circumvented this limitation by programming the game in lean assembly-language code, writing his own video driver and packing it into 28k. Few other action-arcade games of the time matched the complexity and dynamism of the action, and the physics modeling implemented in Gauntletak!.

REGISTERED VERSION RELEASE

The developer released an expanded registered version of the game, mailed to players who paid for for registration. The registered version had a number of improvements over the shareware version, including more levels, new missile types, and a larger variety of enemies. Some of the new enemies had new AI behaviors, including behaviors like coordinating attacks. The registered version could accommodate twice as many objects on the screen at once, increasing the difficulty ceiling of the game. It also came with a printed manual.

sample_screenshots.caption: Some screens don't leave room for much maneuvering.
The entrance to the underground phase of the game.
A valley lined with difficult-to-see ground batteries.

title: Gauntletak

alternate_titles.title: Eastern Front (1941): A Historic Military Strategy Game

description:
A strategic turn-based wargame for the Atari 8-Bit computer line. Eastern Front puts you in charge of the German invaders as they start their infamous Russian campaign, or as it was known at the time "Operation Barbarossa". The game is played from an overhead scrolling map that encompasses the entire eastern European theater, and from which you select your units and issue orders based on their action points and strength which are defined by their appropriate control zones. Isolate units, and their strength starts to go down proportionally.

Only 1-player mode is supported against an AI that actually processes its moves between turns, the longer the player takes to make a move., the better the computer results will be.

sample_screenshots.caption: Please enter your orders now (Disk version)
Please enter your orders now (Cartridge version)

title: Eastern Front (1941)

description:
Guide Flip Ogart, a continually bouncing blob-like creature, through several maze-like dungeons in order to rescue all the other Ogarts that have been captured by the evil RotogartEatos.

These dungeons aren't just all bare, stone walls, though - you'll have to contend with plenty of RotogartEatos patrolling the corridors, invisible walls, teleports, harmless blowers, deadly suckers, and switches that reverse everything's direction.

Rebound is a type-in game from the January 1987 issue of ANTIC magazine, one of a long line of very popular BASIC games by J.D. Casten that were published by ANTIC.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level 5 - the edges of this screen are all blowers/suckers - the blowers are safe to bounce off, the suckers kill you.  The switches will turn suckers to blowers and vice versa.
Level 3 - the odd-looking red things are RotogartEatos.
Find out how many Ogarts you saved when your game is over.
Level 1 - every obstacle and item that you will encounter throughout the game appears in this level

title: Rebound

description: Get the magic ring of power back to crypt #1. You explore various crypts on a map, fighting monsters, looking for the ring. A secret will be revealed to those that complete the quest at the highest difficulty level.
title: Crypts of Terror

description: Two players each control a "cowboy". A gold bar appears randomly on the screen, and if either cowboy takes it to the assay office at the top of the screen, the goal vanishes and a ten dollar bill appears nearby. Each player has a bank in which to deposit the money, and after ten bills have been deposited, the player receives a house worth 20,000 points. A second house is worth 30,000 additional points. The two cowboys can shoot each other, the victim going to one of two hospitals in the upper corners of the screen. Following the two cowboys are snakes and tumbleweeds; the snakes follow one cowboy, the tumbleweeds the other. If caught, a cowboy will be paralyzed for a few seconds. However, if he shoots whatever is chasing him, it is converted into whatever chases his opponent: snakes into tumbleweeds; tumbleweeds into snakes.

sample_screenshots.caption: Gameplay; lots of snakes and tumbleweeds to avoid!

title: Claim Jumper

description:
The task in Power Down is to infiltrate a fortress built on an asteroid by the evil Argon, inside a one-hour time limit. You have five ships, but there are many ways to lose one. Lazer beams and triangular rays toggle on and off, so require timing and planning to avoid. Argoniks patrol the area, and are fatal to the touch - however, they can work in your favour, as they activate some types of indestructible blocks on contact, changing the blocks' frames from white to red as a signal to you.

Most doors are closed by default, and are activated by firing into their brown covers. They can be closed in the same way - this is a defensive tactic to block Argoniks, but make sure you are not in the way of the door as it closes. You can collect and activate shields to deflect and block various hazards - although the ultimate challenge is to complete the game without them.

sample_screenshots.caption: This section is very timing-based - the lines are fatal but intermittant

title: Power Down

description: This is a program to teach children their alphabet and their numbers. When the program begins, the screen draws a clown, frowning, then the letters of the alphabet begin to appear on the screen while the alphabet song plays. You are then taken to the main menu. Here, you can have the screen show pictures for each letter of the alphabet and/or each number, zero through nine. There is also an option to select that will show a corresponding picture for whatever letter or number you press on the keyboard.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is the screen you get if you choose "Selected Pictures".
The clown smiles when the song is done.
You have a different character at each choice.
After the screen finishes drawing, it flashes different colorsand a short song plays.

title: My First Alphabet

description:
One of the earliest 'Software Toys', Alien Garden is set on a scrolling planet consisting mainly of 24 clusters of crystals, representing flowers. You control an embryonic life-form and must ensure its survival and reproduction through up to 20 generations.

Through trial and error, you must find which of the crystals are food, which of them grow when you sting them, and which of them are fatal to touch. Depending on this, you can use either your tail, stinger or wings to make contact with them. Every time you boot the game, the behaviour of the crystals changes, emphasising the need for experimentation.

sample_screenshots.caption: Note the score down the left and right of the playing area

title: Alien Garden

description:
50 rooms full of treasures await the brave yet thoughtful explorer in this platform game. Using limited thrusting ability, you must collect as many crystals as possible before moving on to the next level. Rooms have multiple exits, leading the player to different segments of the screens.

You have five lives, and will lose one on contact with any of the nasties which move around the screens, or when you run out of time (represented by depleting oxygen). In either case, you are sent back to the start of the screen, but keep any crystals you have collected. Collecting every crystal on a screen earns you an extra life.

For an extra challenge, the game can be played in Night mode, which limits visibility to the area immediately surrounding your character.

sample_screenshots.caption: Conveyer belt, waiting to spit me off
...But it leaves you unable to get most crystals

title: Crystal Raider

description: You are a helicopter trying to get to buried golden dollar signs. You must bomb the ground to dig a hole to reach the dollar signs but beware of the plane as it is dropping giant clods of dirt to fill in the hole, and maybe bury you. Even if you avoid the dirt clod, you will need to bomb to uncover the treasure again. When you gather a treasure, you must land on your base to claim it. If you are destroyed before you return to base, you drop the treasure. You can only carry one treasure at a time. After you collect all the buried dollar signs, you move on to the next level.

sample_screenshots.caption: I cannot blast through the rocks.
The title is brought in letter by letter by plane.
I need to unbury the treasure.

title: Buried Buck$

description:
This game is the inspiration, both directly and indirectly, of arcade dungeon crawlers like the The RamJam Corporation version of Dandy, Dark Chambers and Gauntlet.

You, and up to three of your friends, are in a dungeon of monsters. You must fight your way through, gathering food and treasure while destroying monsters. Each time a monster touches you, you lose energy. You can gather food, which can be eaten to restore energy. Once you reach the end of the dungeon level, you descend to the next level down. If you are playing mutiplayer and one of you dies, the other player(s) can revive their fallen comrade by shooting a heart found in the level. If no comrades are fallen and the heart is shot, a monster will appear.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is eats (a.k.a. food). Used to heal yourself.

title: Dandy

description: Your civilization is under attack, and it's down to you and your Laser Hawk helicopter to put things right. Destroy the five bases belonging to Proc Irata. They have sent their full fleet of ships to intercept you - shoot to destroy, and avoid those bullets. The centres are increasingly well-defended, with bombs, missiles and meteors among the threats. Many upward-shooting ground targets are destructible, but beware of the trees they are interspersed with. You have limited fuel, but fuel stocks hang through the air - contact with these triggers a refuel.

sample_screenshots.caption: Lots of cyan on the second level
Level complete - the base looks oddly favmiliar

title: Laser Hawk

description: Mississippi has been hit by a deadly storm, leaving many boaters stranded. You control the more powerful SS Commodore, and must boat through these hazardous waters and rescue as many of these as possible. This involves travelling up a succession of screens, each of which has one person to rescue, while avoiding static rocks and debris. The screen layouts each time are random, so it is not always possible or safe to rescue the boater. You start a screen in the horizontal position you exited the previous one, so a central exit maximises your chances on the next screen. Other boats travel horizontally across the screen - contact with these results in losing a life. A tap of the fire button gives you a quick boost of speed, useful for avoiding hazards.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game start - avoid the yellow, collect the green

title: Barge

description:
The follow-up to Laser Hawk takes a wider view of the universe. Your aim is to take over several hostile planets, such as the verdant Xavier and militaristic Cytron.

Gameplay takes a wider range too, eschewing the side-view blasting of its predecessor. There are two distinct gameplay styles. First you must fly up the screen Xevious-style, destroying the force field towards the end of the level (fail to do this and you must replay the whole level). You must face waves of enemies as well as ground installations. There are many hidden targets to shoot; these release white flags which when collected award extra lives, a short-term shield, or a points bonus.

Once you reach an accessible base, you must enter it on foot, in a section with similar gameplay to Gauntlet. Keys, weapons and bonus items are hidden in hatches on the wall, which are activated by touching them (most are empty, however). Blasting through walls (using a different weapon to your main one) is a large part of progression on these.

sample_screenshots.caption: Approaching a wall to shoot out

title: Hawkquest

description:
Planet Plastron is the last remaining source of fossil fuels. As Omni-Corp has been mining it exclusively for 500 years, they have excessive commercial power. To limit this, you head to the planet in the Scavenger One craft, collecting as much fuel as possible.

Gameplay is essentially Moon Patrol with a third movement dimension (steering the craft, moving it up or down the side-viewed screen). The surface is rocky and full of craters - falling into these damages the craft. There are gaps in the road, some preceded by ramps. Your craft can jump - you start with a limited amount but more can be collected alongside the fuel tokens. Some sections have enemy craft, either patrolling the ground or shooting at you from overhead. Each section must be completed within a time limit.
title: Plastron

description: Thunderfox is an attempt at bringing the gameplay of Uridium to the Atari line. Aboard the Thunderfox space fighter, you are on a mission above a transporter, which contains Disilicate energy crystals intended to power the Phalon War Machine. If you do not infiltrate the transporters and their heavily-guarded Energy Rooms, and destroy the crystals, your society is doomed. It's a race against time - a death missile is being prepared, and will launch to destroy Thunderfox when time runs out. As you fly over the transport, you will encounter enemy ships and defence lasers. Once you reach the end of the ship without destroying all encroaching enemies and bases, you are automatically reversed.
title: Thunderfox

description:
When you first play this game, you'll be forgiven for thinking that your Atari's collision detection has failed. The space-suited character you control moves through enemies, walls and other hazards without losing any of his five lives. It also moves past the heart which starts next to you, and even across the screen's borders.

This is correct; the idea of the game is to use your gas cannon to guide the heart (which represents a clearance pod) from one end of the screen to the other, within a time limit. If this runs out, or the heart hits a wall or any of the marauding enemies or hazards, a life is lost. Controls are rotational - moving the joystick left or right changes the character's angle, while pushing forward causes him to move in that direction, with fire activating the blow-gun.
title: Heartache

description:
World Cup Manager recreates the role of a manager in the 1986 football World Cup - by default the 24 teams have the same names as the real-life qualifiers. The competition format is the same - there are two group stages, whittling the teams down to 12 in the second round, then a knock-out semi final and final. Matches are played out via a running commentary.

Your team is pre-selected and there are no substitutions; the player's main impact is tactical. You must choose one of the three formations provided, and have three options for each aspect of match play. Should you defend using a sweeper system? Should you play corners to the near post? Should you make fast attacking breaks? Before the tournament starts, you choose four teams to scout, gaining crucial information on their tactics.

sample_screenshots.caption: Opposition names are a random set of top players of the time

title: World Cup Manager

description:
Stealing money is the aim of the driver you play in Getaway!, in an overhead-view city spread across 35 screens. The player controls a car which moves constantly in the direction it faces, unless you hit fire button for the brake.

Drive over the $ signs, special items (depending on the level they may be hearts, rings or chalices) and white vans to collect money, and return it to your hideout (in the south-east, represented by an H). You have limited gas, but can top this up by stopping at one of the gas stations. As time goes on, you will encounter roadblocks (which cause you to lose fuel more quickly) and stop signs (which take all your cash when you try to pass them).

The police don't take this lying down - their cars (red, blue and yellow) chase you, especially when you are carrying lots of money or have hit a white van. Making contact with a cop car costs one of your three vehicles and takes any money you are carrying - money you have stashed at the hideout is safe. The ultimate goal is to find the three of the special items and then the white van, which leads to an increased difficulty level - with higher police interest no matter how much money you are carrying.

sample_screenshots.caption: The layout has lots of bridges

title: Getaway!

description:
This is a greatest hits compilation for the Atari 8-bit computer that features:

  • Elektraglide
  • Colossus Chess 3.0
  • Blue Max
  • Alley Cat
title: Atari Smash Hits Volume 7

description:
In Journey to the Planets, you play a spacefarer who must find a way to return to his home planet. To do this, you need to collect various treasures from several unexplored worlds. Sometimes you will need to shoot your way to a particular treasure; other times, you will need to solve a set of puzzles to reach your goal. Once you recover all the treasures, you must pilot your starship through uncharted space with a limited amount of fuel and find your home planet.

The 1983 cartridge release features a different soundtrack and tones down some of the more difficult puzzles.

sample_screenshots.caption: This white object should be fairly easy to identify...
The Disk/Tape version adds some additional complications to takeoffs and landings. For example, some planets are windy...
Wait, it recharges your energy reserves by blasting you in the head with white stuff. Man what?

title: Journey to the Planets

description:
The protagonist of this puzzler is a reneged jack escaped from a box, thanks to a mutation of feet growing out of his spring. You'll control him as he kicks his way through the games puzzles.

You'll be able to make your springman wander up and down the left side of the screen pushing a tile with a symbol on it before him. This tile can be kicked to the left where a stack of tiles await. If you've lined up your tile with a matching one on the other side they all shall vanish, if any tiles are above they'll fall into the newly vacant spaces. You'll also have a limited number of lightning tiles which will act like the sort of tile that it comes in contact with after you kick it. After you clear all the blocks you will be moved to a new level with, hopefully, a new background.

Each level has a number of neutral tiles that you can bounce your tiles off to have them hit another area of the tile mass that you're trying to clear.

A two player mode is also available where you can play against someone else on the same computer. Instead of clearing levels you'll play to see who can get a certain score. After that is reached a new area will begin.

sample_screenshots.caption: Using up your lightning means you'll lose a life... feeling woozy?
Gee this would be harder if I had someone to play against...

title: Plot's

description:
In Plot you take the part of a round head, with curly golden locks cropped close to the scalp, in a cell that has a penchant for matching symbols on tiles. Your red head will move vertically on the right side of the cell while holding a tile to you left. This tile will show a symbol on it. The symbol will match with tiles on the other side of the cell. Your goal is to shove the tile across the room and match it with tiles that share its symbol. Once you destroy a tile you'll receive a new tile, more specifically, a tile that matches one near or behind the one(s) you destroyed

You can attack the tiles directly from the right or ricochet them off an angle in the ceiling. Another devious trick up your sleeve is the lightning tile. This tile with its lightning design can mimic any other. If it touches another tile it will act as if the correct image has touched it and booth shall explode.
title: Plot

description:
Skarbnik (Treasurer) is a puzzle game where your goal is to arrange gems (which come in various types) into specific designs. The design you have to make is on the right of the screen, and your current arrangement of gems is on the left. By clicking on a gem here, you turn it - and all the gems around it - into another type of gem. After a few such changes, the gem disappears and all the ones above it fall down.

Initially, the puzzles are quite easy, but later they get harder. The game is divided into a few levels, each of them having a number of puzzles, which are presented to you in random order.
title: Skarbnik

description: Video Easel is an early drawing game that allows the player to create a basic design. The computer AI then expands on this and continually creates ever evolving graphics much like a screen saver might look like. It uses Conway's Game of Life to generate the continuing patterns. It will continue forever, or until you reset to create a new image for the computer to run away with.

sample_screenshots.caption: Create shapes such as a big X.

title: Video Easel

description:
A simple race game simulating off-road buggy racing in the Baja California desert. The game uses pseudo-3D perspective and behind-the-car view. As opposed to most of the racing games of the period, collisions with other buggies cause slowdowns rather than crashes. Other notable features include a speedometer and a race progress indicator.

From the technical perspective, the game uses Display List Interrupts (DLIs) to create multicolor horizon and 3D-road effects.
title: Baja Buggies

description:
Godart the evil wizard has kidnapped the beautiful princess Fiscella. The valiant prince Roderic, knowing that Godart's keep is virtually impossible to infiltrate by an intruder, proposed himself as a hostage in exchange for Fiscella. Godart agreed, counting on a large ransom. Yet he forgot about young Roderic's knowledge of magic. A few spells and magical herbs, and Godart was gone for good. Now Roderic is alone in Godart's castle - and he needs to get out.

Roderic is a platform adventure game, where you have to collect items scattered throughout the castle to use them in solving puzzles elsewhere. You can carry up to 3 items at a time. With them, you can open blocked passages or avoid sudden death. There are some situations in the game which can kill you - falling chandeliers and rooms filled with deadly traps, to name a few.

The castle has three levels (1st floor, basement, roof), between which you can move with an elevator.

sample_screenshots.caption: Falling chandelier? What is it, Phantom of the Opera?
Colorful effects when riding the elevator.

title: Roderic

description:
Fixing bugs in a new computer circuit board late at night is hard, but it gets even worse when suddenly, real bugs appear out of nowhere. It's time to grab a gun and shoot at those little pests.

Bug Hunt is a game designed for the Atari XG-1 light gun, and came bundled with the Atari XEGS and the stand-alone XG-1.

The game consists of seven waves. Each wave features more of the little critters (flies, spiders, butterflies, ticks, frogs, etc.) on the sections of the PCB, waiting to be shot. Some are large and stationary and easy to hit, others are small and move rapidly and net more points. To progress into the next wave, a certain accuracy percentage must be met (from 25% to reach wave 2 to 80% to reach the final wave). The final score is converted into a performance rating - CEOs, directors and managers at the lower end, programmers, hackers and engineers at the higher end.

sample_screenshots.caption: As I have no light gun, I scored zero points.

title: Bug Hunt

description:
The eponymous Upiór (Ghoul) has invaded your castle along with his monstrous buddies. Your task is to search the labyrinthine castle for 20 gems, which will allow you to enter the ghoul's chamber and deliver some well-deserved punishment to him.

On your way, you'll face numerous monsters, some stationary, some moving. You have to defeat them by punching or kicking. The monsters have variable amounts of resistance to your blows, and variable strength with which they hit you. You've got to battle them carefully; approach them, punch and then move away before they retaliate. If hurt, you can heal yourself by picking up the chalices which can also be found in the castle.

Your health, the health of the current enemy and the amount of gems you've collected is displayed at the bottom of the screen. Note that falling from big heights will harm you too. You have only one life - if you run out of health, you instantly die and it's game over.
title: Upiór

description:
Magia (Magic) is a Polish adventure game in which the player controls the knight Alakhin, transformed into a ghost via evil magic. To escape the chambers he's imprisoned within, the player needs to find the wizard Or Kirr and bring him the proper artifacts.

The gameplay is presented in isometric perspective. Most of the screen is taken up by the view of the chamber Alakhin is inside. At the bottom of the screen is a percentage that shows how far the player has progressed in the game, and a clock which shows how much time has been spent playing so far.

Some chambers have objects (treasure chests, windows, paintings, shields) or people inside them. These can be interacted with by pointing to them with the cursor and pressing "Fire"; this will cause a menu with various commands to appear. Usually chests, windows or shields have items hidden within that can be picked up, while people can be given items. Note that up to four items can be carried in the player's inventory. Sometimes "spells" can be found; using these will show a map of the game.

To enter another chamber, one points to a doorway, presses "Fire" and chooses the "go" option.
title: Magia

description:
Fireball 1k was developed for the annual Mini Game Competition and was an entry for the 1k size category.

In this shooting game, you control a ship which can move left and right along a blue line near the bottom of the screen. Bricks fall from the top of the screen; they have varying speeds - some fall slowly, some fall very fast. By pressing the Fire button, you can shoot a fireball which will destroy any bricks that get in its way. As time passes, more and more bricks begin to fall.

If a brick falls beyond the blue line, then the line will rise a little along with your ship. If you miss a lot of bricks, you'll soon find yourself close to the top of the screen, making it harder to hit bricks in time. The bricks harm you and decrease your energy when they touch you.

Shooting bricks makes the blue line descend back. If the blue line is all the way down, then shooting bricks will give you some energy.

sample_screenshots.caption: A lot of bricks have slipped by me, and...

title: Fireball 1k

description:
As a warrior of the Dimension X you are descended on Jaraloba planet to defend it from Rigillians. The planet is divided in 25 sectors (5x5 matrix), and each of them is filled with enemy forces. Controlling a ground skimmer, you should eliminate enemies in each sector and proceed through one of eight gates in surrounding mountains to another sector.

Sitting in cockpit of your skimmer, you may examine the view in first-person perspective, accelerate, decelerate your skimmer, turn left or right, and shoot the enemy vehicles. During your mission, radar helps you to detect the enemies out of your view, but fuel is exhausting, and shields are decreasing with enemy shots.
title: Dimension X

description:
The game is a remake of original Floyd of the Jungle with the following changes:

  • Game is rewritten in machine language and doesn't require BASIC anymore;
  • Now single or multi-player race is flown against computer Floyds (if number of players is less than 4 else all players are humans);
  • A demo mode is available;
  • In-game music is present;
  • Screens and fonts are slightly changed.

sample_screenshots.caption: Start of the level 1... Three computer Floyds are running in front of you.

title: Floyd of the Jungle (Version II)

description:
The first game of design icon Sid Meier within MicroProse Software puts you in the seat of helicopter to rescue captives trapped in the series of underground labyrinths.

The game is 2D shooter, where you are controlling the chopper from 3rd-person view. You may turn it left/right, move it up/down, shoot the missile, and drop the bomb. Mobile patrol drone defenders and fixed missile launchers are shooting at you, so avoid them and their bullets. People are standing in certain places and crying for help, so you should pick them up positioning the chopper over them. The chopper will crash if it will run out of fuel, or collide with the wall. There are ten captives in each labyrinth. Points are accumulated for captives rescued, enemy installations destroyed, and speed.

Three difficulty levels differ by points awarded. The game may be played by 1-4 persons in turns in Solo and Team mode. While in Solo mode each player controls all functions of his helicopter, in Team mode two persons are involved - while one person is controlling the chopper, another is shooting and throwing the bombs.
title: Chopper Rescue

description:
Eureka is a puzzle game where the player's goal is to arrange gems (which come in various types) into specific designs. The design to be created is displayed on the left of the screen, and the current arrangement of gems is on the right. By clicking on a gem here, the player turns it into another type of gem - clicked multiple times, it cycles between various types of gems (the sequence is displayed at the top of the screen) and finally disappears, with all the gems above it falling down. Clicking on a gem also changes the four gems around it - but these neighboring gems cycle forward by two types of gems instead of one.

There are 50 levels. If stuck, the player can press Space to restart the level, but this makes him lose a life. There is a time limit, and running out of time causes the player to lose a life and the level to restart.
title: Eureka

description:
Nuclear missile silos all over Europe are launching! Protect the USA by firing lasers from orbiting satellites to destroy both the missiles and the silos, as well as occasional bomber airplanes and alien UFOs, while protecting your cities as well as your satellites.

You control a crosshairs with the joystick and fire with the trigger; the closest satellite will fire a laser blast at your crosshairs and destroy whatever is underneath it, whether bomber, missile, or silo. To complete a wave, destroy all missile silos. You lose by either letting all your cities be destroyed or letting all your satellites be destroyed.

Sentinel plays basically like a two-screen Missile Command - on one screen is a map of Europe with several silos that launch missiles towards the top of the screen. Your satellites are arrayed in space near the top of the screen. Pressing a key on the keyboard will switch screens to a view of the other side of the world, the USA, where you can see your cities and any incoming missiles that you let get by on the other screen.

The dual screens adds an interesting twist to the Missile Command gameplay; you can see bombers and missiles take off in Europe and, when they leave the Europe screen, then appear on the USA screen.

sample_screenshots.caption: Destroy the silos and their missiles...
Stand By for the next wave!
Wave 2 - more silos, more missiles, faster bombers, and so on.

title: Sentinel

description: Mostly written in Atari BASIC (with a hint of 6502 assembly), this game was Brian Moriarty's first text adventure. Its player controls a private investigator on the trail of extra-terrestrial burglars who have stolen the Declaration of Independence! There are clues to be found in the "maze of streets" representing Washington D.C. and, of course, there is the upper dimension promised in its title to be traversed with the game's text parser interface.

sample_screenshots.caption: Finally on the trail of the aliens
And I just so happen to have exactly one dollar!  What are the odds?
I always make it a priority to read things I find on bathroom walls.  (Too many Al Lowe games as a kid, perhaps...)

title: Adventure in the Fifth Dimension

description:
Barkonid for Atari is the first game in the series. The gameplay is similar to Arkanoid and Breakout.

There are over 100 levels and a final assembly. The game can be played with a joystick or gamepad. The player can pick up bonus capsules that contain various positive or negative extras. These bonuses have to be taken with the ball and not just with the board to be absorbed. Examples include a laser, extra lives, level jumps, glue and much more.
title: Barkonid

description:
In the middle of the night, inside a bedroom in a nondescript building, dwells a frustrated man. He lay awake, unable to fall asleep, his restlessness growing exponentially each passing minute. Something is keeping him up.

It's those damn cats again.

In ZiMAG's Cat Nap, the player controls a person bent on revenge against three noisy alley cats—Puff, Pearl, and Brutus. The cats walk back and forth across the top of a picket fence, meowing constantly and loudly. The player starts with an inventory of six objects which he must hurl out the windows in hopes of knocking one of the felines off the fence, effectively silencing them for a brief period. The protagonist is never actually shown, but is represented by a hand that can be moved left and right between three windows. After selecting an object, the player then positions his hand in front of one of the windows and uses the fire button to chuck the object at one of the unsuspecting kittycats. If the player is able to continuously strike each of the cats within the 5 minute time limit, he wins the game and is finally able to catch some Z's.

But watch out for Scruffy! This lazy dog, who normally sleeps peacefully in the grass in front of the fence, will awaken in a fury of barks if one of the cats happen to fall on him, adding even more noise to the cacophony of meows.

sample_screenshots.caption: An ambulance comes to revive Puff

title: Cat-Nap

description:
The player controls a crewman on the USS Sea Moss, a nuclear submarine patrolling the icy waters of the North Atlantic. While conducting routine maintenance, the player finds themselves alive, alone, in a sealed hatchway, following an underwater gas attack by a treasonous saboteur. The player's Pyrrhic goal is to find and neutralize the saboteur and scuttle the vessel to prevent its military and technological secrets from being recovered by an enemy power. But the first problem is surviving escaping from the hatchway into the gas-filled interior...

The game's interface is via an appropriately claustrophobic windowed text system not dissimilar to Adventure International's, with certain screen areas indicating location, exits, inventory, and player input. The player communicates with the computer by using two-word VERB NOUN phrases. Though the interface is primitive, the game is still more sophisticated than Moriarty's earlier Adventure in the Fifth Dimension, which was written in BASIC -- this game employs machine language. Soon after, Moriarty would be working at Infocom.

This game was published in issue #5 of A.N.A.L.O.G. Computing as type-in code, and was inspired by cover artwork for a long-dormant submarine arcade game hanging in the magazine's offices. "Feelies" appearing photographed in the magazine helped in the solution of some of its puzzles.
title: Crash Dive!

description:
For decades the star system Chi Draconis has been held in slavery by the Vorrakian fortress built into an orbiting asteroid. Capable of destroying entire planets, the fortress has all but wiped out the Draconian Star Force and extorts a vast wealth of transuranic ore from the enslaved system. Recently, though, a ray of hope has been glimpsed: a fissure in the asteroid was detected by long-range neutrino scans. It could lead to the core of the fortress, to the emerald power crystal, to freedom for Chi Draconis!

Five brave pilots in tiny fighters are lined up to attempt navigation of the fissure and destruction of the power emerald. First they must face the patrolling Vorrakian squadron, then the mine field, and on through unknown dangers and defenses. One at a time you will guide them; if the first fails, then the second will start the approach. The one who succeeds, in the fine Sisyphean tradition of 1980's video games, gets to start all over again.

The game screen offers a cross-sectional view through the asteroid. If your fighter impacts the cavern wall, a mine, or any of the myriad hazards populating the fissure, the end is instantaneous; there is no flash of light, no debris, just oblivion. Suddenly you are back on approach toward the asteroid, guiding the next brave pilot, or on the score screen looking at your rating, which begins with "Ground Gripper." Forward movement is relentless. Thrusters will speed up the ship temporarily, but there is no stopping and surveying for the best route. Though the ships are each equipped with a laser, its range is hardly greater than the length of the ship. All your offense is point-blank, all your defense lies in dodging.

Two caves of increasing difficulty await those who conquer the first level, and the adept who surpasses all three meets the first cave again, but with sluggish controls. That's if you have the easy data access of the game's disk version. The cassette version can only work with what is loaded in memory, so defeating level one takes you back to level one.
title: Zardon

description: Plattermania is set in a circus and can accommodate one to four players. The player controls a clown up on stage who has 12 poles. As the clown, each player starts the game with 10 platters. Before the start of each player's turn, the number of platters which must be spun simultaneously is displayed. To reach the goal, the player must have the correct number of plates spinning at once for at least 8 seconds. Platters will fall if they start to wobble and the player does not move the clown to it and spin it up soon enough. They will also fall if they are spun too hard. If the player breaks three platters without achieving the 8-second goal, the turn ends. Otherwise, the turn lasts until a platter falls and breaks after the 8-second goal has been achieved. Bonus multipliers for score can be earned by keeping platters spinning beyond the 8-second goal. Once all players have had a turn, the scores of all players will be shown on screen. Each time a player meets the goal, the player is moved up one level. If a player fails two turns in a row, they will be dropped down a level. When a player runs out of platters, the game is over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game over; well, I didn't get any points this time...
Oops, a platter is starting to wobble!
Gameplay; so far, I have two platters going

title: PlatterMania

description:
The War of the Fifth Coalition against Napoleon's France have just begun. The Battle of Raszyn was fought on April 19, 1809 between the Polish army of Duchy of Warsaw (commanded by Prince Poniatowski) and the invading forces of Austrian Empire marching on Warsaw. Despite outnumbering the enemy 2 to 1, Austrian troops were defeated.

Raszyn 1809 is a turn-based tactical level strategy game for one or two players. You can command either Polish-Saxon or Austrian forces - infantry and cavalry, supported by artillery. Apart from the historical setup, fictional and random options are available. Player wins when the village is held until the evening (or when it's captured by troops - when playing the Austrian side).

The game comes with information about the historical background of the battle.
title: Raszyn 1809

description:
A.D. 2044: Seksmisja is an adventure game, loosely based on the Polish film Seksmisja. The protagonist is a man cryogenically frozen in modern times and thawed years later, in a world populated only by women. The goal of the game is to escape your imprisonment, and perhaps somehow restore your gender to existence.

The screen shows the room that the player is in, as well as the inventory on the left and a map on the right. The game uses a "point-and-click" interface: the player moves the cursor around using the joystick, and presses FIRE to bring up a menu with interaction options for the selected object. Frequently, the game shows closeups of objects such as drawers and lockers in a separate, small window. A button below the first-person view allows to walk in any direction where there's an exit. Up to four items can be carried at a time, and items can only be dropped in specific spots. The protagonist must regularly eat food, otherwise he will starve into a game over.
title: A.D. 2044: Seksmisja

description:
Axilox is a two-player board game. The game board is a picture covered with 81 tiles; each tile has a number on it, dark or fair in color. The players, in turns, remove tiles; the first player removes a tile from the topmost row; the second player can only remove a tile from the same column as the tile just removed; the first player then can only remove the tile from the same row as that tile; and so on. Removing a tile with a fair number increases the player's score by the number, while removing a dark tile decreases the score.

The game ends once the entire board is cleared, or when a player cannot make a move. The player with the higher score is the winner.

The one-player game involves the human player competing with a computer opponent, trying to keep winning throughout 10 levels with 5 different pictures. The two-player game is a single match.

sample_screenshots.caption: No more choice means end of the game

title: Axilox

description:
Adax is an arcade adventure game where the player becomes a special agent, dispatched by the Earth military to the planet Adax in order to blow up a secret alien base and recover several disks with secret info.

The agent must travel around the six sectors of the planet, dodging or killing dangers and finding crates with objects inside--such as keys, ammo, "spheres" or disks. The enemies can be dispatched by kicking or punching them, by shooting them with a pistol (though ammo is limited), or by tossing "spheres" that roll along the ground and explode on impact. The "spheres" can also destroy the ever-present landmines which otherwise have to be jumped over. The keys can open locked doors, but are one-use. In an adventure game fashion, there are also special items with specific uses.

Each sector contains a vehicle that can take the agent to any other sector.

Contact with an enemy or falling from a height drains the agent's health, but killing enemies restores health.

sample_screenshots.caption: Interlevel animation. Off we go in the car

title: Adax

description:
In the far future, humanity encounters a hostile alien civilization. With war imminent, Lieutenant Max Graham is sent to the Moon, on a mission to find a starfighter fleet hidden somewhere in an ancient moonbase.

Artefakt Przodków ("The Ancestors' Artifact") is an arcade adventure game. While searching the vast labyrinth of the game world and avoiding the ever-present monsters, the player must look for items (such as explosives for blowing up a wall) that will allow him to get deeper into the maze, eventually reaching the goal. Up to three items can be carried at once. The more rooms are visited, the larger is the "game completion percentage" displayed on the status bar.

The protagonist is equipped with a jetpack with unlimited fuel, allowing him to fly. His health drops slowly during contact with enemies and when it reaches zero, he dies and loses a life.
title: Artefakt Przodków

description:
Kampania wrześniowa (September Campaign) takes place during the invasion of Poland in 1939, marking the beginning of the World War 2.

The goal is to capture enemy headquarters. The game is played in turns (4 phases: movement and attack for Poles and Germans, respectively). The player commands infantry, cavalry, tank, armored car and artillery units (both sides available for play). Bad weather hampers movement. The map also contains minefields.
title: Kampania wrześniowa

description:
Alfa-Boot is an adventure game with a point-and-click interface; the protagonist is a special agent, sent out to stop a radioactive leak in a nuclear submarine down in the ocean.

The game uses a simple interface where the player can move a cursor around to select an object in the first-person-view image of the location he's in, and interact with this object in a number of ways. Many objects can be examined, with their descriptions appearing at the bottom of the screen. There is also an ever-present "go" option which allows the player to follow any exit out of the room, including those not visible on screen.
title: Alfa-Boot

description:
Barahir is a Polish adventure game; as warrior Barahir you have to sneak into a fortress where your friend, wizard Daeron, is imprisoned, and free him.

The game interface uses a row of icons at the bottom of the screen: the first icon allows to switch between two music tracks or turns on sound effects instead; the next icons allow to interact with people (talk/bribe/fight), examine an object in the inventory or in environment, use an object, walk in a given direction (choosing a direction on a compass-like selector), check inventory, pick up and drop items. Messages appear as layered text windows.

The player can carry up to six items at once. Encountered people can be fought, but each fight saps a little of Barahir's energy; if it runs out, it's a game-over.
title: Barahir

description:
Syn Boga Wiatru (Son of the Wind God) is a platform game, set in Inca cities and temples. The player is a professor who, on each of the game's four levels, is trying to find a priceless amphora. Jumping around and climbing ladders and ropes feature heavily. The main threats, apart from steep drops, are various enemies that walk around; falling a long distance or contact with an enemy drains the professor's health. Running out of health ends the game immediately.

The professor has two thrown weapons: rocks and knives, both of which kill enemies instantly. There is limited ammunition, and rocks have the additional demerit of being affected by gravity over long distances. Ammo can be replenished by collecting diamond-like pickups. There are also keys, used to open locked doors (each key is one-use, so it's necessary to decide which doors to open and which to leave alone). Finally, the player can find cups that replenish health.

sample_screenshots.caption: Jumping around with no fear of heights

title: Syn Boga Wiatru

description:
Bang! Bank! is a clone of Bank Panic, developed in Poland. Just like in the original, the player takes on the role of a bank security guard of the Wild West, protecting the bank's twelve doors on each level.

Three doors are visible on the screen at a time, and the player can walk right or left to reveal other doors. Customers and bandits come through the doors; bandits must be quickly shot before they do the same to you, but shooting an innocent person by accident results in losing a life. If a customer is able to enter the bank unmolested, they will deposit money; once all 12 doors have had customers deposit money through them, the next level begins.

Sometimes, messengers will come in with numerous hats on their heads; these can be shot down, eventually revealing a moneybag to be shot for points, or a bomb that makes you lose a life if you shoot it.

Certain levels are set during night-time, which makes it harder to discern the good guys from the bad guys.
title: Bang! Bank!

description:
Captain Gather is a puzzle game similar to Sokoban. The premise is that a space vehicle is to clean several planets of nuclear waste by pushing the waste together to make it detonate.

Each level is a small maze with crates of waste strewn about. The player's goal is to push the waste around in order to arrange it into the right pattern; every crate of waste has a fragment of a pipeline on it, and the waste pushed together must form a single continuous pipeline. When this is achieved, the player goes to the next level.

The player's vehicle can only push objects one block at a time, not pull them; if an object is stuck near a wall or in a corner where it shouldn't be, there is no choice but to restart the level. To make things more complicated, the levels also have ordinary, useless crates strewn around that have to be pushed out of the way. And every level has a time limit.

There is a limited number of lives, and a life is lost if the player runs out of time or restarts a level. Passwords are given every few levels to save progress.

sample_screenshots.caption: All of the level vanishes once it's completed.
The final planet is gonna be tough.
Every few levels you get a password.

title: Captain Gather

description:
Battle Ships is an unofficial port of Battleship by Elite Systems Ltd.. Like the original, it is a computer version of the pen-and-paper Battleship game. There are five ships for each player; they can be rotated between eight angles (horizontal, vertical and 45-degree diagonal), and some of the ships have a slightly more complex shape than just a line.

Also like in the original, in each turn the player, instead of firing at one square, gets to choose a number of squares to fire at (the more ships the player has left, the more squares they can attack each turn). An animated sequence at the end of the turn shows the shots being fired.

A two-player competitive mode is also available.
title: Battle Ships

description:
Android is a platform game, set in a space base filled with hostile robots; the player controls a remote-controlled android, out to gather spare parts for a computer. The player must explore the game world and search every nook and cranny for the parts; apart from jumping, the android can crouch. Climbing ladders is a little awkward, as the player has to jump from step to step.

Enemy robots deplete the android's health when they touch or shoot him; the android is armed with a gun, but ammo is limited, and enemies come back to life when the screen is visited again. Ammo and health can be refilled by finding appropriate pick-ups scattered throughout the base. Falling from a large distance also depletes health.

The game can be switched between colored and black-and-white mode at any point.
title: Android

description: Caveman is a platform game set in the prehistoric times, similar to Prehistorik. As a caveman, on each level the player has to find food for his family. The main protagonist wanders around the wilderness and explores caves in his search. Hostile animals and plants have to be avoided - contact with them drains health. There are also dangerous environment elements such as bonfires or deep water. There is a time limit on each level, and a specific amount of food to be collected before the level can be completed.
title: Caveman

description:
Cavernia is a platform game, set in a cave. As Teddy Arklethorpe, the player has to complete sixteen levels; finishing each level requires Teddy to collect all the treasures scattered throughout, then grabbing the key and getting to the exit.

The gameplay is typical for the genre, with leaping across gaps, riding on moving platforms and leaping up to grab ledges. Monsters such as ghosts and mutants, and dangerous environment such as spikes and falling stalactites await throughout; contact with them means losing a life.
title: Cavernia

description:
Change is a puzzle/arcade game. The protagonist is Tuptacz, whose plantation has been invaded by alien creatures known as Spheres. To save the farm from destruction, Tuptacz must repair the forcefield on each of the forty-eight levels by arranging the generator's elements in the right order. To complicate matters, he is allergic to the plants grown on his plantation and can only walk upon designated paths.

Each level is a mazelike path around which our hero can move, with the occasional crossroads. At will, the hero can rotate, by 90 degrees, the square section that he's in. The goal on each level is to rotate the elements until the maze forms a closed loop without blind alleys. The hero can walk through thin walls to accomplish his goal.

A deadly, roving sphere on each level must be avoided; colliding with it kills instantly. Every level also has a time limit. Going over this limit, or going off the edge of the screen, kills the hero as well.

sample_screenshots.caption: The sphere won't reach us here.
The levels can get quite complex.

title: Change

description:
The Citadel is a puzzle game where, on each level, the player has to get the protagonist to the exit. The way to the exit is usually blocked with various obstacles: rocks, boxes, pits.

Rocks can be pushed around, but only one at a time, and they cannot be pulled. Boxes are similar to rocks, but a row of them can be pushed around as one. Pits need to be filled with a rock or a box, depending on their shape. Teleporters transport the hero to another teleporter. Bombs can be pushed around, and explode when a trigger is pushed, destroying everything (and detonating other bombs) near them.

Every level has a time limit. Passwords can be used to skip to later levels.
title: The Citadel

description:
Crypts of Egypt is a platform game taking place in the secret depths of an Egyptian pyramid; the goal is to make it to the exit. Dangers await the protagonist, such as spikes and fire pits that slowly sap the limited health, monsters which also damage health, and mines that kill instantly. The protagonist has an unlimited supply of blue balls he can toss to destroy the monsters, but a destroyed monster regenerates elsewhere in the room. Bottles that refill health and grant score can be found.

There are also levers to be found; when switched, they have a variety of effects, such as temporarily deactivating a trap, or opening up a pit beneath the hero's feet.
title: Crypts of Egypt

description:
Cywilizacja (Civilization) is a tactic strategy game, similar in its gameplay to Empire: Wargame of the Century. The player takes control of the world's armed forces, opposing an army led by a rogue general.

The game takes place on the world map, covered with cities; depending on the difficulty level, the number of cities that belong to the player and to the computer opponent are different. Some of the cities already have military units stationed in them. Playing in turns, the players each move their units around and give building orders to the cities. The goal of each player is to take over all the cities and destroy all of the enemy military.

Each of a player's units can move during his turn, as long as it still has movement points left for that turn; units also use up fuel and regularly have to refill it by entering a city--an unit that runs out of fuel is immobile. Upon contact with an enemy unit, combat breaks out, ending with the opposing units losing some of its manpower. An unit is destroyed once its manpower reaches 0.

Cities can be ordered to construct units--ground vehicles, planes, and ships; the more population there is in a city, the faster it builds units, and the more room it has for stationing units. Stronger units take more time to produce.
title: Cywilizacja

description:
Fred is a platform game, where the player controls a caveman, walking horizontally through the levels. Like in nearly every platform game, there are hanging platforms for the caveman to jump on, though sometimes parts of the platforms give way. Climbable ropes also appear.

There are enemies on the way, such as birds and frogs; Fred can defend himself by tossing rocks that travel in an arc, though ammunition is limited, but Fred can pick up new rocks along the way. Another weapon is the spray can; when found, Fred can spray in front of himself, killing enemies this way. Contact with an enemy or a hazard (such as a cactus) costs a life and sends the player back to the last checkpoint.

Weapons can also be used to crack open jugs found along the way. There are pick-ups to find inside, such as rocks, ammunition for the spray can, a cap that protects from a single loss of life, or shields that make Fred immune to all dangers.

The game was originally released in 1990 as part of a compilation.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level 2 is more dangerous with water everywhere

title: Fred

description:
A compilation of two platform games, this being the original release for both of them:

  • Fred
  • Misja

Since October 1991, the games were sold in "enhanced" versions, originally created for individual releases on Western markets; both games have had music added, Misja's title was changed to Mission Shark, and Fred's levels were re-designed.
title: Misja/Fred

alternate_titles.description: In-game title in the Zeppelin Games Ltd. version
alternate_titles.title: Mission

description:
Mission Shark is a platform game where a covert agent is trying to find four canisters within an enemy base. The goal of the game is to find them all and make it to the exit.

Moving around the game world, the agent must watch out for enemy soldiers, landmines, electric fields and defense turrets. Getting shot or touched by those hazards results in losing health, which can be replenished by collecting the appropriate power-up. The agent is armed with a gun and some grenades; ammo is limited, but more of it can be found.

A mini-map at the bottom right shows the agent's position within the base, as well as the areas he's already visited.

The game was originally released in 1990 as part of a compilation.
title: Mission Shark

description:
Magia Kryształu (Magic of the Crystal) is an action platform game starring the mage Tannatos, out to get revenge on the demon Syrylak for long-time imprisonment. The goal of the game is to find Syrylak and defeat him.

The player controls Tannatos as he travels around the game world; similarly to a classic platform game, dexterity in jumping from platform to platform and in avoiding dangers is necessary. Touching an enemy or their projectile kills Tannatos instantly, and there are limited lives.

There are numerous items strewn around; Tannatos can carry up to three at once and use them wherever necessary to solve puzzles. Unnecessary items can be dropped in specific spots.

An indicator in the corner of the screen shows the progress made in the game so far.

sample_screenshots.caption: "Death is the quiet haven of us all." -- William Wordsworth
A wonderful transformation has taken place.

title: Magia Kryształu

description:
Soccer is an simulation of the sport with the same name. In contrast to many other simulations of its time, it keeps all 22 players. There are, however, important differences to the real game: the goalkeeper has no additional functions compared to the field players and there are no half-time or fouls.

If the player controls the athlete with the ball, he or she uses the fire button to shoot in the direction the athlete walks to. In the field, this can be used to pass to another player. When not in ball possession, pressing the fire button changes the controlled athlete to the one who is nearest to the ball (unless he is already controlled by a human player on the same team; then the second-nearest is used).

Available options are number of human players, three match times (10, 45 or 90 minutes) and four difficulty levels.
title: Soccer

description: River Rally is a top-down racing game that can be played by two players simultaneously. Players control a boat with throttle acceleration to race through a winding river and collect sunken treasure marked by a dollar sign. It is collected by driving over it and it needs to be taken to a bank to deposit it safely. The boats can also use ramps to negotiate the river banks. In a two-player split-screen game, players can lay down mines to hinder the opponent and collide to steal the opponent's money. In the single-player game the player needs to find a set amount of money before time runs out. Only one bag is visible at a time and a total of nine needs to be found.
title: River Rally

description:
Planet Attack is a side-scrolling shooter where the player pilots the space ship Star Eagle. The game takes place in 3216 AD and Earth is about to be destroyed by aliens from the planet Tritan. They have established their base on Mars and the pilot needs to travel there to take out the Time Scalers, devices that allow the aliens to travel to Earth. There are seven scalers to take out and there only two possible landing paths per scaler.

The game is a side-scrolling shooter over the surface of the planet Mars. After take-off, the ship needs to bomb radar dishes, time scaler tripods and fuel dumps, while taking out missile space cruisers and auto droids with a regular laser. The ship only has a limited amount of fuel and shields. Fuel is replenished by bombing fuel dumps. The goal is to survive until the time scaler devices have been destroyed, and also to avoid mountains while flying. When fuel is about to run out, it is possible to eject the pilot.
title: Planet Attack

description:
The empire of Xandor has been under siege by dark forces. Desperate, the King Gaelyn sent a request for help to the lords of the castles in his land. From each castle, three subjects - a prince, a knight and a page were selected to face riddles and dragons.

This is the background of the board game Trivia Quest. After selecting the difficulty and their castle, each of the participating players (one to four, there are no computer players) needs to choose the correct answer out of four options in the first so-called "wisdom round". This is necessary to accumulate enough gold and food to enter the game map with a character and be able to progress there. An incorrect answer starts the next player's turn.

On the board itself, movement is also dependent on answering the questions which are prompted by landing on one of the trivia question squares. These are divided into four categories (for example,a TV square means a question out of television, literature or movies), and the faster a question has been answered correctly, the more squares a player's character can move. It's possible to switch between the three different characters provided enough gold has been accumulated. There are also special squares denoting dragon lairs. These trigger an arcade sequence where additional gold can be gained if the dragon is defeated, but in case of a loss the dragon also takes gold from the player. The fighting ability is influenced by the character type, with the page being the weakest. Finally, there are squares and situations which can lead to a "wisdom duel", meaning a player vs. player question battle.The quest ends when all three characters have reached a home castle, the winner being the player with the most gold.

sample_screenshots.caption: As can be expected, the focus of the questions are often the United States

title: Trivia Quest

description:
Two mean hooligans, Butcher Bill and Ruthless Rick are spoiling all the fun at the carnival. These two characters try to murder the happy carnival crowds by dropping missiles on the ferris wheels and planting bombs on the roller coaster. The only one to stop them is Super Sam who has to save the rides' passengers from a gruesome death and then shoot the perpetrators.

Carnival Massacre is split into two parts. First Butcher Bill has to be stopped at the ferris wheels. The player stands at the ground below the ferris wheels and above them Butcher Bill will move in a sky lift. He will throw rocks at the passengers and as they fall out from the wheels the player has to try and catch them. At the same time the player has to avoid being hit by rocks since that will kill them. If you miss too many passengers a giant coil spring will appear and bounce around the screen. The player has to jump over it to avoid dying. When the ferris wheels are empty and the player has managed to save at least six passengers, they get the chance to take down the villain with a gun. After that the player moves on to the roller coaster where Ruthless Rick has planted some mines. When the cars hit the mines the passengers will be thrown out and the player has to catch them just like at the ferris wheels. Once again Butcher Bill appears and start throwing stones at the player. The rules are the same as for the ferris wheels.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the end a gun appear

title: Carnival Massacre

description: Formula 1 is a racing game that is most notable for being the first commercial game developed by Sid Meier, before the foundation of MicroProse. The game is played from a top down perspective and the player races against three AI drivers on five different race courses. Four of these are based on real race tracks from around the world; Indy, Monza, Watkins Glen and Monaco. The difficulty level can be set before the race and ranges from amateur to championship. The higher the level the harsher the competition from the AI drivers will get. The player also has to watch out for oil slicks and trees by the tracks. The racing can take place both day and night. The game is played with joystick and the player gets to steer, accelerate, shift gears and brake.

sample_screenshots.caption: Finishing using 3rd gear. To change gears I need to press Fire + Up or Down.
Start of the race: the colored objects are the cars.

title: Formula 1

description: States & Capitals is an educational game about the geography of the United States. The goal of the game is to identify all 50 states and their capitals. The player sees a map of the United States with one of the states outlined. The player will then have to enter the right name of it and then its capital. The game goes on until it has gone through all the 50 states. The states appear in random order.

sample_screenshots.caption: ...and then the name of the capital
First we enter the name of the state...

title: States & Capitals

description: European Countries & Capitals is an educational game about the geography of Europe. The goal of the game is to identify all 26 countries and their capitals. The player sees a map of the continent with one of the countries outlined. The player will then have to enter the right name of it and then its capital. The game then goes on until it has gone through all the 26 countries. The countries appear in random order.

sample_screenshots.caption: For some reason it gives wrong for Soviet but right for Russia.
The game asks for the name of the country

title: European Countries & Capitals

description:
Miecze Valdgira (Valdgir's Swords) is an action/adventure game, starring the gnome Aldir, who must find the five eponymous swords in order to free the castle Heldgor from a curse. Aldir must wander a labyrinthine dungeon, collecting one-use items along the way and using them in the right places, for example to open passages or give them to people for new items.

Most dungeon rooms have a swarm of tiny hostile creatures flying around in them. Aldir can shoot fireballs to kill the creatures one by one. Contact with the creatures drains health; when all health is depleted, Aldir loses a life. Every killed creature gives 100 points, and Aldir gets a new life every 10000 points.

The player can switch between music and sound effects.
title: Miecze Valdgira

description:
Paris in Danger recreates the 1814 campaign against Napoleon's France, when allied Russian, Prussian and Austrian forces of the Sixth Coalition were marching towards Paris. It is played on both strategical (on a map of entire France and today's western Germany; corps size units) and tactical level (battles, which can be also resolved automatically; division size units), from either side of the conflict. Effects of morale, unit facing and formation are taken into account.

The players gain victory points (the French for killing enemies, the Allies for capturing cities), which are summed up after 25 turns (each lasting few days) to declare the winner.
title: Paris in Danger

description:
Stellar Shuttle is a Lunar Rescue variant. The planet Ttam has drifted into a dangerous asteroid belt, requiring that all inhabitants be evacuated to a mother ship orbiting outside the belt. The player has the shuttle ships to work with, to fly through the asteroids and pluck the refugees one at a time from the surface. To help avoid the asteroids, the speed of the shuttle can be slowed down by using the shuttle's retro rockets. The retro rockets can also be used against dragons that start appearing at level two.

Once the player has picked up a refugee, he or she has to return up to the mother ship. Here players will get access to a blaster that can be used to clear the way through the asteroids, however there are also falling comets that require maneuvering and speed to avoid and drifting derelict spaceships that need to be shot.

For each level there are six refugees that have to be rescued one at a time. Once that has been done, the player moves on to the next level.

Scoring is as follows:

  • Each Landing: 200 points
  • Return of each refugee safely to the mother ship: 300 points
  • Large asteroids: 20 points
  • Small asteroids: 50 points
  • Derelict Spaceships: 300 points
  • Dragons: 200 points
  • Every six rescued refugees: 1,000 points
title: Stellar Shuttle

description:
A compilation featuring two puzzle games following known concepts:

Cultivation follows the basic formula of Puzznic. The player has to clear a level within a time limit by moving symbols of the same design left or right, taking into account possible ways in which they may fall if there is no space beneath them. When symbols of the same design come in contact with each other, they disappear. An editor for constructing levels is included.

Chromatics is a standard falling blocks game based on the Columns concept. Different colored blocks need to be arranged into sequences (horizontally or vertically) of at least three to make them disappear. If the player isn't successful, the number of blocks stack until the top, at which point the game is over. The number of colors in play can be adjusted from three to five.
title: Cultivation + Chromatics

description:
Rommel: Battles for Tobruk is a turn-based strategy game with hexagonal cells. It is set during World War II and covers the battles between Rommel's Panzerarmee and the British 8th Army over Tobruk (Brevity, Battleaxe, Crusader and Gazala). The player either takes the role of one war party or battles against another fellow wargamer.

During each turn, both sides give detailed orders to their units which are then performed simultaneously. Order are assigned on the tactical map, but for planning there are also four strategic maps available which either show the terrain, Allied units, Axis units or all units. Additionally there are tables about corps (a list of all units), supply and airplanes. The simulation of the two latter are a focus of the game model. Of course there are also a number of other factors, including morale, unit capabilities, or, fatigue. A variety of options can be used to change the complexity of the game, including the AI level or if enemy units are visible. Supply and airplane effects can also be deactivated.
title: Rommel: Battles for Tobruk

description: Chancellor Of The Exchequer is an economic simulation in which the player takes the role of the financial and economic minister of Britain. The game begins in 1805, i.e. at the beginning of the industrial revolution. The player manages the production in the eight provinces; the goal being to industrialize them in order to make the country a big player and increase the population. If a province is advanced enough, it will merge with Great Britain which simplifies the administration. The game is almost completely text based and all time is spent in menus in which the player makes production and resource distribution choices.
title: Chancellor Of The Exchequer

description: The Battle of Chickamauga is a turn-based strategy game. It is set during the American Civil War and covers, not entirely surprising, the battle of Chickamauga from 1863. The player either takes the role of the Confederates or the Union troops and tries to defeat the enemy. During each turn, both players (or one player and the AI) give orders to their units and then they get performed simultaneously. The simulated aspects of war include morale, unit abilities, war tactics, morale or fatigue. Various options can be set before and during a match, e.g. switching certain game mechanics off like the invisibility of enemy units outside sight.
title: The Battle of Chickamauga

description:
Excalibur is a strategy game in which the player takes the role of legendary King Arthur. Britain is divided between 16 kingdoms, but because everyone wants to reign the whole country, a violent dispute is inevitable. So King Arthur manages his kingdom, builds up an army and prepares for the things to come.

The majority of the game is spent in the menus of Camelot: Merlin's room (magic is used to put negative effects on other kingdoms, but usage is restricted), the treasury (all financial aspects including taxes and army management), the throne room (official communication with other kingdoms like paying tributes or declaring war), the round table (monitoring and managing the contentment of the knights; a revolution would be unhealthy) and the trap room (only used when the kingdom is under attack). Arthur can also move outside the city and visit his vassals or other kingdoms (the latter with non-friendly intentions). The last component is the battle system which, just like the rest of the game, is in real-time. Similar to Legionnaire; the player commands the army on a overhead map.
