Enemy submarines will move one quadrant to a new location if they are threatened and not destroyed, and the player must ascertain the new location. The player has limited fuel to complete their task, as well enemy submarines will fire back at the player, and can destroy the player's ship. The player is victorious if they destroy all enemy vessels.
title: Anti-Sub Patrol

description:
Deluxe Invaders is a 1 - 2 player space-themed arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Based upon Space Invaders, the player controls a small ship which can move horizontally left and right, and fire vertically. There are 3 defensive shields which can block the aliens' or player's shots. The player's goal is to shoot all alien vessels on the screen, but as the player destroys enemies, the speed of ship movement increases, increasing difficulty. Alien saucers arrive and supply more combatants if they are not shot down. On later levels, invaders split in two when shot, and both craft must be destroyed independently. The player starts with 3 lives, but it's game over if all lives are lost or if the invaders reach the bottom of the screen. The player gains an extra life every 10,000 points. The player can start at any of 9 difficulty levels, and each stage is progressively more difficult.
title: Deluxe Invaders

description:
Nautilus is a 1 - 2 player split screen submarine arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Game is displayed in a split screen, with the top portion devoted to the destroyer Colossus, with the bottom half of the screen for submarine play. In a 1-player game, the player controls the submarine Nautilus, and must avoid depth charges dropped by the destroyer Colossus above. In a 2-player game, the second player controls the destroyer, and attempts to hinder the first player's progress.

The Nautilus is equipped with Thunderbolt torpedoes, which are used to destroy underwater cities and collect the Proto-Energy Pods at their center, and power the sub's engines. These torpedoes are also used to defend against enemy attacks. The destroyer's purpose is to transfer city repair crews from the right to the left side of the screen, while avoiding attacks from the submarine and its support helicopter. It is further armed with depth charges and Barracuda torpedoes to defend itself, but if it is damaged it will automatically return to the right of the screen for repairs. When repair crews are successfully transferred, an underwater city is rebuilt, scoring the second player 100 points. A further danger for the submarine is Limpet Lurkets, autonomous droids which inhabit the depths and seek out the submarine.

The destroyer is armed with sonar, which tells the player when they are above the submarine, to encourage the dropping of weapons. There are 9 difficulty levels, and gameplay is timed, with the winner being the one with the most points at the end of a session.
title: Nautilus

description:
Intruder Alert! is a 1-player science fiction themed arcade game for the 8-bit Atari

The player must escape from the Dreadstar with its plans, or the Rebellion is doomed. Game consists of 2 screens of robots, with the goal to reach the second screen and escape in the shuttle. The player can move and fire in the 4 cardinal directions, and must avoid droids. There are a total of 5 difficulty levels, from Sand Scout to Gamma Knight. On the easiest level, droids are stationary, and can only fire in 4 directions. On more difficult stages, droids approach the player, and can fire on angles. The player receives a score based upon the time for escape and the number of droids destroyed.
title: Intruder Alert!

description:
Ghost Encounters is a puzzle game for the 8-bit Atari.

This is the sequel to Action Quest. Played from a top-down perspective, the player controls a small ghost within a haunted mansion, who is tasked with collecting a number of treasures. The ghost is armed with a small gun, which can fire in 8 directions, and can be used to defeat monsters and solve puzzles. New in this game, the ghost can further transform into useful objects, including: a shovel, a torch, a key, and can make itself thinner. Each room has a short description which might provide a hint, and the player has a limited timeframe to gather the treasure on each level before turning from white to dark and losing a life. The player starts with 10 lives, and if all are lost it's game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Avoiding Monsters to get a Treasure
Becoming a Key to Unlock Doors

title: Ghost Encounters

description:
Chomper is an arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls the Chomper, who must eat all of the dots in a maze. 4 monsters hunt the player, and try to prevent them from this task. If the player contacts a monster, they lose a life. If the player eats all the dots, they move to a level with faster and more intelligent monsters. The player starts with 3 lives, and when all are lost, it's game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: You can see a Bonus Heart

title: Chomper

description:
Asteroid Miners is a space-themed arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Your home planet is in dire need of specific resources, which can only be found in an asteroid field in a dangerous realm of space. The player controls a large mining vessel, and has a limited time span to scoop up the valuable gold and blue asteroids, while avoiding the unstable and worthless white asteroids. If the player scoops up all asteroids with time remaining, they enter a bonus round on a secondary field, where they try to gather additional resources for bonus points. There are 3 difficulty levels. On level 1, asteroids are stable, and time is plentiful. On the higher levels, new asteroids appear during gameplay, and can damage the mining vessel. Furthermore, white asteroids might explode on impact with the miner.
title: Asteroid Miners

description:
A 2D side-scrolling shooter where you must explore caves to find the three pieces of the crown for the king. The large playfield is notable for an enormous amount of movement, with flowing water and swaying vines. Hidden triggers will cause explosions or lightning bolts to strike that will injure the player, as well as falling stones, and two dreaded birds that keep spawning to harass you. The player looks like they are riding on a stork and have a lance, similar to the characters in Joust, though the translated story says you are on a winged horse.

Though the game is short, it is known for being very difficult. It has three difficulty levels, named slightly different depending on translation, corresponding to easy, medium, and hard, which controls how regularly the explosions and lightning bolts go off, as well as the speed the birds spawn and move. In two-player mode, the controls for movement and shooting are distributed between the players.

The game was released in Germany, but Wikipedia offers a rough translation of the story in the game: The player controls the hero Telos on his winged horse Pegamis and has to explore two caves within a large scrolling playfield. While exploring the caves the player is threatened by flying creatures called "Nemesides" that appear occasionally.

sample_screenshots.caption: Getting hit by a triggered explosion
Finding the last piece of the crown
The gate to area 2 is opened with 50 gold
Where you show up when you go to area 2

title: Cavelord

description:
A compilation of:

  • Electrician
  • New York City
title: N.Y.C.: The Big Apple / Electrician

description:
The castle of Schreckenstein has been taken over by black sorcerers and creatures of the underworld. The magical eyes of the Necropolis ward off visitors to the castle, but it might just be possible for one or two brave souls to enter the castle dungeons. And with the help of the white sorcerers, perhaps they can restore peace to the castle.

Schreckenstein is a platform maze game designed to be played by two players, with each player's surroundings shown in either the top or bottom half of the screen. If a single player is selected, the computer operates the second player. In each level, the players must traverse the maze collecting health elixirs and level specific objects while avoiding spooks, bats, spiders and miscellaneous traps. Each player can throw a weapon to dispatch their enemies.

On each level, the collected objects are either used to activate sites or give them to a white sorcerer for use. When enough have been collected, a key appears somewhere, and once collected this allows the door to the next level to be opened. For the first level, the players collect torches and use them to activate giant skulls. On the second level, gems are collected for the white sorcerer, who appears randomly and infrequently as a ghostly apparition. On the third level, tokens must be deposited into magical wells. On the fourth level, the player must again collect crystals but they are enchanted, and cannot be picked up unless the player is first given the ability by a white sorcerer. In the final level, the players must find magic eyes for the white sorcerer.

Each player has a health meter, which trickles down with time or drops after contact with a monster. Once the energy reaches zero, the player dies. If this happens to the computer or in two player mode, the first player to die eventually re-animates as an undead creature who pursues the other player. If the living player completes a level, their companion is given extra energy and returned to life with a small amount of energy for the next level.

sample_screenshots.caption: Player 1 has the key and is about to leave the level.

title: Schreckenstein

description:
Space Cowboy is an arcade game for the Atari 8-bit systems.

In the galactic year 7401, a free-roving private spacer, known as a Space Cowboy, landed his vessel on the feudal planet Dungeon. Space Cowboy was looking for adventure; he was not expecting to be arrested on false charges as soon as he landed his ship. Before being incarcerated in the cells of Castle Langour, Space Cowboy did manage to seal his ship so that it would open only to his body aura pattern. For three years Space Cowboy was a restless prisoner planning an escape to his waiting ship, to lift off and find a more cordial planet. Finally the moment to escape arrived and Space Cowboy broke out of the castle. But, there was still the gauntlet ahead of him.

The player must move along the narrow ramparts of the castle, avoiding a number of lasers which fire from the left hand side of the screen. The player must time their moves carefully to not get shot, and they are also at danger of falling off the ramparts. The player starts with 10 stamina, and every time time they are hit or fall off a platform, they lose a point. If the player loses all of their stamina, it's game over. The game shows the player's speed and the distance to their awaiting space ship on the bottom of the screen.
title: Space Cowboy

description:
The Curse of the Pharaoh is a graphical adventure game. Many years ago, a lone thief defiantly entered the tomb of Pharaoh Ickabathan and stole the two rubies which had been placed as the eyes of the mummy. The thief, however, became hopelessly lost trying to escape the tomb of death, and in the process, dropped the rubies. Sightless, the mummy instinctively sprang to life and sought out the intruder, viciously slaying him on the staircase. Avenged, the mummy returned to its sarcophagus, but placed a curse upon the land until its eyes should be returned.

The player must enter the pyramid, and explore in search of the two lost gemstones. These must be returned to the mummy, to lift the curse that haunts the land. All items and locations are graphically displayed on the screen. The player must type in all commands as a single word, and there are several inventory based puzzles. There is no save or restore feature.

sample_screenshots.caption: Finding a Flashlight in the Desert

title: The Curse of the Pharaoh

description: Time Bomb is an action game where you need to rescue sixteen ammunition depots from bombs that are set to explode. You may have landmines placed in your path, while aircraft can also attack from overhead. The game has five difficulty levels, which determine how many landmines are in your path. You can also choose between a daytime mission or a night mission. At night, visibility is low, and you need to use sound cues to avoid hazards.
title: Time Bomb

description:
In Galahad and the Holy Grail Sir Galahad has been charged with finding the holy grail. This is done in a flip-screen style traversing over many screens, being chased by three evil knights, a moth, many spiders, a deadly bunny, and a dragon all trying to stop you from completing your quest.

The game is a derivative of Adventure by Atari, released in 1980. Your character can only carry one item at a time, but there are a shield, sword, speed wedge, three keys, a holy hand grenade, and the titular Holy Grail to pick up. The shield defends you from taking any damage, the sword can face left or right and kills any enemies but the moth if you touch it with it. There are about 100 rooms.

sample_screenshots.caption: Battling an Enemy with my Sword

title: Galahad and the Holy Grail

description:
Gem Drop is a fast-paced puzzle game and is based on the concept of Magical Drop III. The goal is to clear all gems on the screen before they squash the character at the bottom of the screen.

The player controls the character at the bottom and can collect up to ten gems of the same color. These are then launched at the ones at the top to knock them off the screen. When three of more gems of the same color connect, they match and explode. Any adjacent games of the same color will also explode, causing chain reactions. A higher score is provided for making more gems disappear in one go.
title: Gem Drop

description:
Invenies Verba (Latin for "find the words") is a fast single-player word puzzle game based on the mobile and web based game LEX by Simple Machine. The objective is to produce words by using a collection of random letters. Meters fill up next to unused letters as time progresses, encouraging the player to use them. When a single meter next to letter is filled up completely, the game ends.

A different score is provided for using each letter based on the letter's frequency in the language. Rare letters are worth more that way. Letters' frequencies also determine how quickly their meters fill. Every third word you enter takes you to the next level, where points are multiplied, but meters also fill more quickly.
title: Invenies Verba

description:
Wingman is a split-screen side-scrolling flight game for one to four players.

Played from a split-screen perspective, two planes fly independently. In a single-player game, the second plane is controlled by the computer and aids the player. With more players, players can choose to play cooperatively or compete against each other. One team controls five sectors on the left of the gameplay area, while the other team controls five sectors on the right, with two empty sectors in between. If the wingman is computer controlled, he can be given different control instructions, such as defending friendly territory, attacking enemy territory or protecting the human player.

Planes can be armed with high-explosive bombs, air-to-air missiles, or 20 mm cannons. These have different efficiencies against ground and air targets, and also heavier weapons slow the plane's speed. The player scores points by destroying enemy aircraft and ground installations, with buildings further into enemy territory worth more points. Each team is provided 3 flight squadrons (2 aircraft) to try to maximize their score, and in versus games, the player who scores the most points is victorious.
title: Wingman

description:
Starbowl Football is an arcade football game for one or two players.

Played from a side view, each player controls their individual football team. Each game is divided into four 15 minute quarters, and scoring follows similar rules as American football. The player can select which player on their team to control, but there is no option to setup plays or positions for the team.
title: Starbowl Football

description: Sludge is an action game loosely inspired by Pipe Dreams. The player needs to connect pipes to a sludge outlet to control the flow of a toxic substance produced at a factory. In later levels longer connections are required, with more pipes to connect, and the sludge starts flowing sooner.
title: Sludge

description:
Rosen's Brigade is a side-scrolling arcade game.

You and your men were on a secret bombing mission when the enemy struck. Your fellow flyers are overcome by the enemy's vast number, but you, the ace pilot, manage to escape. As you fly to freedom, your men are bailing out into the hands of the enemies.

The player controls a plane which can move in 8 directions and fire directly forwards. Friendly soldiers will intermittently parachute from the top of the screen, and you may pick them up for bonus points. On each level, the goal is to destroy all enemy vessels, and there are a total of 10 difficulty levels. Each level contains a lake and a mountain to navigate, and there are progressively more difficult enemies, including: transports, helicopters, tanks, and boats.

The player starts with three planes, and when all are lost, it's game over.
title: Rosen's Brigade

description:
Sea Bandit is an arcade action game where you challenge the mysterious forces of the vast, dark ocean as you search for and capture glittering lost treasures.

The player's goal is to capture as many undersea jewels as possible during a limited time frame. A white treasure energizer, or bouncing ball, moves about the screen collecting points and eliminating blocks as it hits waves and jewels. The player controls a probe which can be raised, lowered, and moved laterally to help direct the energizer. The probe can be destroyed by being struck by a mine. The player also controls a minesweep, represented by a red object at the top of the screen, which can be moved laterally. If the energizer hits the minesweep, it is destroyed, and the player has a total of 5 energizers per game. Intermittently mines will raise from the ocean depths, and if these are captured by the minesweep, the player will gain bonus time to capture jewels. The game is over when time runs out or all energizers are lost.
title: Sea Bandit

description:
Spider Quake is an arcade action game.

The player controls Eddie Eight Legs, a spider who must survive the threatening dangers and perils of the blazing countryside on his journey to Spider Mountain.

Similar to the arcade game Frogger, the player starts on the bottom of the screen with a spider that can move in all directions. The player must avoid the dangers of a busy highway, by moving precariously between cars. They must then avoid unsteady trashbins, and cross on logs across a fast flowing river, to ultimately enter a small cave at the top left of the map. As the player moves, the map is constantly shifting. Flies buzz around the screen, which can be picked up for bonus points. The player has three lives per game, and it's over when these are lost.
title: Spider Quake

description:
Air Raid! is a side-scrolling shooter which puts you in control of an aircraft and charged with the task of defending a city against waves of incoming bombers. Each level starts with your plane fully fueled and loaded with ammo, waiting for take-off. The bombers appear on radar in the distance to your left, and you must destroy them all before they take out your radar and both of your landing areas.

There are a total of nine levels, or "strikes" of increasing difficulty. On the first, there are only a small number of bombers, which cannot return fire. Subsequent levels have increasing numbers of bombers, some of which can shoot back. Later levels also introduce fighter escorts which move faster than the bombers and will change course to intercept you. Each level consists of two waves, with the second wave appearing only after the first has been cleared from the air. After the ninth strike, the final level repeats until all of your planes are destroyed.

Flying uses fuel, and shooting reduces ammunition. These can be replenished, up to a maximum of 100 units each, by landing on one of your air bases. Whilst flying, you also have the option of dropping an external fuel-tank. This decreases your fuel to 50, thereby reducing your flight time but also improving the speed of your aircraft.

sample_screenshots.caption: On the highest level, bombers are guarded by three fighters.
These bombers are guarded by a fighter.
I've been shot by the lead bomber!
Taking off from the airfield next to the city.

title: Air Raid!

description:
Battle Trek is a strategy space battle game.

You are captain of the USS Ranger on combat patrol in the sector. The player must engage Vegan battleships in strategy-based space combat. A difficulty level from 1-50 is available for the player.

The player must navigate to a number of star sectors using their warp engines to destroy all Vegan vessels. Within a sector, ship navigation can be automatic or manual by selecting thrust level and direction in 360 degrees.

The player 's ship is armed with positron lasers and a meson cannon for offense. A limited crew supply is available, and they are lost as the ship is damaged, and cannot be replenished. Shields help protect the vessel and limit crew fatalities when powered. When no enemies are present, the player can launch probes to investigate the local sector.

The player has the option to manually control power distribution of their vessel or allow the computer to automatically do this. The player's vessel has 4 separate shield and positron laser positions, as well as slots for the meson cannons, ion engine, light engine, and batteries. The player must redistribute power to these different ship sections to optimize ship performance. The ultimate goal is to defeat all Vegan ships present in space.

sample_screenshots.caption: Under Attack by a Vegan Shop

title: Battle Trek

description:
A group of spelunkers has been trapped underground on a strange planet. Your goal is to use a mechanical auger to burrow a tunnel from one side of the screen to the next to allow the group to get closer to safety. The escape needs to take place within a certain time, which is marked by the movement of the sun and moon. The fire button switches control between the auger and the fleeing human. Once all humans have been rescued, play continues in the next level or "quadrant".

Thwarting your plans for escape is an alien bird, who flies overhead and has two special powers. It can launch magna-titanium rods which penetrate the planet's crust and may either kill a human or block their path. It can also hatch a number of smaller probe-birds. These probe-birds can launch their own attack. They can deploy a nuclear rod through the rock, and once encountering a tunnel can release a space-fungus. The fungus is made of a relatively hard material, and grows haphazardly within the tunnel, blocking it.

There are two other important aspects of the game: boulders and bombs. Boulders appear randomly throughout each quadrant. They are made out of a super-hard rock which is extremely difficult to drill through, but also almost impenetrable by the nuclear rods of the probe birds. The part of a tunnel drilled under a boulder is therefore relatively safe. The cave explorers also start off with a number of bombs. If a bomb is deployed near the end of one of the nuclear rods, before it deploys the fungus, then the probe-bird above will be killed by the explosion. Extra bombs can be found floating around the tunnels in each quadrant.

A bonus life is given at the end of five successful quadrants, and there are a total of 99. There is also a multiplayer mode, where each additional player controls one of the three probe birds trying to destroy the first player.

sample_screenshots.caption: Later levels have many more boulders.
A human about to be hit by magna-titanium rods.

title: Boulders and Bombs

description:
Turboflex continues the Deflex formula by Jeff Minter.

The objective is to hit a target with a ball within a set amount of time, To do so the player places deflectors or bats in the location the ball is at the time of placement and the ball immediately changes direction.

The ball moves across the screen in either a horizontal or vertical direction, the player places one of two type of barriers in the location the ball is at any given moment and it immediately changes direction from horizontal to vertical (or vice versa). The type of barrier placed determines if he bounces up/down or left/right. Once the ball hits a barrier, it changes direction, so the next time the ball hits it, it will send the ball in the opposite direction.

There are five different modes of play, static targets and four types of moving targets (a mixture of fast/slow and with reverse). The difficulty increases with each phases of play, up to level 5.

sample_screenshots.caption: A gun appears to shoot the lost (last) life

title: Turboflex

description:
Beta Fighter is an action game for one or two players.

Set on a spectacular Martian backdrop, your mission is to destroy the dastardly Kreloids as they pass overhead. The player controls a small spaceship that can move horizontally at the bottom of the screen and fire upwards. Alien vessels approach from the left, and fire towards the player. If the player is hit, they are transported to the left side of the screen. The player receives 25 points for each enemy vessel destroyed, and they can take a total of 10 hits from enemies before game over.
title: Beta Fighter

description:
Forest Fire Two is a game for one or two players.

The player's job is to stop a rapidly spreading forest fire. The nearby countryside is displayed on an 18 x 9 grid, which includes woods, dry brush, lakes, your fire tower, a fuel depot, the governor's mansion, and a supply base. Each turn, the player is able to drop fire retardant, set up a ground crew, and dig a fire break. The goal is to minimize property damage to the surrounding countryside. The player takes a significant financial hit if the governor's mansion burns down, and if the fuel depot catches on fire all nearby areas ignite. If the supply base burns, then resources to fight the fire become more scarce. Wind conditions will affect the direction of spread and the speed of the fire.

The player can select stable, unstable, or very unstable wind patterns, and can also start a game with a fire caused by a mild, moderate, or severe thunderstorm. Terrain options include wide open, country, and congested.

sample_screenshots.caption: The Fire is Starting to Flare Up

title: Forest Fire Two

description:
Giant Slalom is a 1 - 9 player arcade slalom skiing game for the Atari.

The player must ski down a steep slope, attempting to cross through all the marked gates. The player receives a penalty for each gate they miss. If the player strikes a post on the way down, they are injured and cannot complete the race. There are 4 levels of difficulty.
title: Giant Slalom

description:
Maniac Miner is a 1-player side-scrolling arcade game for the Atari 8-bit system.

Working deep in the dark shaft of Goldbrick Mine, you are Rocky, the Maniac Miner. You are trying to make your fortune by collecting the shiny rubies, opals, gold, and diamonds within the mine. You must try to collect these treasures as quickly as possible, while avoiding swooping bats and jumping over creeping spiders.

The player starts with 6 men, and can lose a life if they contact a bat, spider, or if they jump into the ceiling. For every 5 treasures collected, a magic pole appears, allowing the player to descend one mine level. There are 9 individual levels of difficulty, and the collect is to maximize score by descending as deep as possible.
title: Maniac Miner

description:
Starbase Fighter is a top-down side-scrolling space fighter for the Atari 8-bit system

The player controls a small spaceship that can move in all directions, and fires straight forwards. The player starts within their home starbase, and must blast into space to seek out the enemy city. Deep in space, they must avoid attacks from alien vessels and dangerous asteroids. Numerous small alien outposts can be destroyed for bonus points. After encountering the enemy city, the player can fly inside to enter a side-scrolling stage where they must avoid enemy turrets and ships that attack from behind. After reaching the end of the city, the player encounters the Brain, which hides behind an energy wall that requires repeated hits to destroy. With the Brain destroyed, the enemy city is destroyed, and the player is free to destroy more aliens.

There are 3 levels of difficulty, and the player can choose to start with 3, 5, or 7 ships. The ship hols 99 torpedoes, but can be replenished by returning to the home base. It is game over when all ships are lost.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting at my Home Base - Watch Out for Asteroids

title: Starbase Fighter

description:
Encounter at Questar IV is a top-down arcade game for the Atari-8 bit computer.

The player controls a small vessel that can move in all directions, and fires a short distance directly ahead. A mobile blue alien and a stationary pink alien continuously fire towards the player, leaving a stream of deadly mines behind. The player must avoid enemy fire and mines to approach and shoot their enemies who later respawn. As gameplay progresses, more mines appear on the screen, making movement difficult. The goal is to maximize the score by shooting as many aliens before losing all 5 lives.
title: Encounter at Questar IV

description:
Rocket Raiders is a 1-player arcade game for the Atari 8-bit system.

The player is in control of a futuristic city surrounded by a blue force field. Alien bombs rain from above, and the player must shoot them out of the sky from the defensive turret located in the city before the bombs crash into the shield. As the bombs crash, they destroy the shield and the underlying city. Intermittently, alien spacecraft appear, which must be shot before they land in the city. If the central turret is destroyed, the player can no longer defend themselves, and the aliens can land with impunity. The goal is to survive as many bombs as possible.
title: Rocket Raiders

description:
Space Trap is a 1-player space-themed arcade game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

The player must destroy all Anthorian spacecraft before the black hole closes, and the player is lost forever.

The player controls a small spaceship that can move in all directions and fire directly forwards. Navigation consists of setting a ship's horizontal and vertical thrust, and the ship will continue in that direction until alternative force is applied. The ship can fire directly forwards, and turns by alternating thrust. A number of Anthorian ships sit outside the black hole, and the player has limited fuel to try to destroy all of these. If the player runs out of fuel, the black hole starts to close, and the Anthorian ships are restored. If the player strikes the green barrier, they are rapidly propelled in the opposite direction. When the black hole fully closes, it is game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: A Ship Appears in the Hole's Center as it Slowly Closes

title: Space Trap

description:
The Rings of the Empire is an arcade game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

The Empire has developed a series of robot-controlled battle stations called Rings. Each station is protected by one or more rings of energy, and they have been placed at strategic points throughout the galaxy to monitor and destroy all unauthorized movement. If they are not destroyed soon, they will doom the Rebellion.

You will attack the stations in your Y-wing fighter, which is armed with zydon torpedoes. The rings are a series of counterclockwise rotating shields which can be destroyed by a direct torpedo hit. The player must blow away layers of the shield to ultimately aim a shot at the well-protected station within. One hit, and the station is destroyed. You must combat a series of stations with progressively more rings up to 4 rings in total.

Each station is armed with a negi laser, which tracks the player, and drains a small amount of energy with each hit. The player's total energy is displayed on the side of the screen. Whenever a shield segment is destroyed, a powerful segfire missile is released, which will obliterate the player's ship if it connects. After 6 - 10 ring segments are destroyed, segfire missiles will begin to track the player. The player can shoot down these missiles, but also 4 times per game can warp off one side of the screen and appear on the other. If the player's ship is destroyed, it's game over.
title: The Rings of the Empire

description:
The E Factor is an arcade game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

Every planet in the universe has en "E Factor", which represents the amount of energy each planet possesses. Matter can neither be created nor controlled, but it can be converted into energy, and through this process dissipated. Certain planets have consumed almost all of their energy producing materials, and are in desperate need of fuel replacement. Your assignment is to deliver a massive "energy capsule" to each of these planets before their fuel runs out and the inhabitants are frozen to death.

From the navigation screen, the player must move to all 4 planets present on the space chart. Each quadrant has unique dangers including empty space, asteroids, Mondrogor Starfighters, and the planets themselves. The arcade portion is played from a top-down perspective, where the player controls a yellow starship that can move in all directions. The screen and dangers scroll vertically from above. A small green energy capsule is also present on the screen. The player's only ability is to make the capsule move towards the player, by pressing the joystick button. If the capsule touches the starship or any other object on the screen, the player loses a life. Furthermore, if the starship comes in contact with any enemy other than Mondrogor Starfighters, which directly try to attack the energy capsule, the player loses a life. The player has 5 lives, and if all are lost, it's game over.
title: The E Factor

description:
Galactic Avenger is a 1-player space-themed arcade game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

In the outermost regions of the galaxy X-Zorb, there is a quadrant made up of 10 consecutive sectors. At the heart of each lies a Galactic Federation starbase. Ten stardates ago, these starbases sent out a distress signal that the dreaded Krell Empire has overrun and captured the entire quadrant. You have been selected to command the Federation's elite strike force, to free the starbases from the 5 advanced Krell starships that guard each one.

The player controls a Federation battlecruiser, which can move horizontally on the bottom of the screen, and fire vertically upwards. Krell ships move horizontally, and fire towards the player. After the five defending ships are destroyed, the player must quickly use their tractor beam to capture the rapidly scrolling starbase, or the Krell will transform it into a Krell Battlestation and destroy the player.

The player has 5 ships, and loses one with each hit. With 5 ships lost, it's game over.
title: Galactic Avenger

description:
Stargate Courier is a 1-player arcade game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

The player controls a spaceship which can move in 8 directions and fire directly forwards. Gameplay occurs in outer space and on an alien planet. The player has a limited fuel supply, and fuel can only be acquired by landing on these alien planets. On the alien planets, the screen scrolls vertically from above, and the player can cruise at either high or low altitude, but can only acquire fuel at a low altitude. At low altitude, dangers including turrets and enemy fighters are present, but there are fewer dangers higher up. After acquiring sufficient fuel, the player can once again enter outer space. Back in space, the player must destroy a select number of alien fighters as demonstrated in the top right of the screen. After destroying these, a warp gate opens, which allows the player to progress to the next level. A compass on the bottom of the screen shows the direction to the fuel planet or warp gate.

sample_screenshots.caption: Foreign Planet and Star Gate Present

title: Stargate Courier

description:
Meltdown is a 1 - 2 player Frogger clone for the Atari 8-bit computer.

In the middle of the night at the Megalopolis nuclear power generating plant, all hell has just broken loose in the control room. The coolant system is failing, the cores are boiling, and unless the tremendous heat of the nuclear reaction in all five reactors can be dissipated, the reactors may begin to melt down.

The player can move in the 4 cardinal directions. They must move from their starting point avoiding radioactive mist and clouds, dash through a corridor containing bolts of atomic energy, and then through a series of moving floors (most of which disappear when stepped on) to reach the reactors. There, the player must extract the uranium core and return it to the lead box at the start of the level. A temperature gauge on the bottom of the screen continues to count upwards, and if it reaches 5200F, it's game over. Each rescued reactor will reduce the temperature. If the player is able to save all 5 reactors, they are able to move to a more challenging level. There are a total of 10 levels. The player starts with 3 lives, and if all are lost, it's game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Trying to Cross the to the Nuclear Reactors

title: Meltdown

description:
Astron IX is a 1-player side-scrolling arcade game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

The player controls a spaceship that moves in all directions, and can fire in 8 directions. The ship has inertia, and takes time and energy to slow down. The spaceship needs to be navigated through a number of tight caverns while combating enemy creatures. The player has limited firepower, men, and shields, but more can be picked up as the caverns are navigated. Caverns consist of a number of interconnecting scrolling caverns of varying design. Dispersed throughout are docking stations, which allows the player to equip acquired items to their ship. The goal is to navigate the entirety of the caverns before time runs out.
title: Astron IX

description:
Mountain Shoot is a 2-player artillery game for the Atari 8-bit computer

Two pieces of artillery line up on hilly terrain, and take turns firing at each other. The first player to hit the other wins. Each turn the player types the direction of their shot and how much powder they wish to use. Allows for 3 levels of difficulty, and the option for limited powder. Wind direction and strength is randomized each turn, and terrain is randomized each game. The program keeps track of score over multiple games.
title: Mountain Shoot

description:
Valley of the Kings: A Graphic Adventure is an adventure game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

You must journey to the far edge of Egypt. There, the player must brave many dangers and find their way through the many hidden exits of Saad.

Played from a top-down perspective, the player must explore a number of rooms. Clue squares provided help for the puzzles. There is an inventory system, and the player acquires many items, including: magic rings, swords, matches, and keys. Many of these items are used to solve puzzles. There is a scoring system, and if the player runs into too many dangers, they lose 50 points and are sent back to the most recent save point.
title: Valley of the Kings: A Graphic Adventure

description:
Stud Poker is a 1-player card game for the Atari 8-bit computer system.

Contains two separate poker variants played against a single computer opponent, stud poker and bid poker. In stud poker, players and opponent start with two cards and progressively receive more up to 5. The player gets a chance to bid on each card drawn. With bid-poker, the player is shown their 5 cards and 3 of the computer. The player can bid on who has the higher hand.
title: Stud Poker

description:
Shiloh 1862 is a 1-player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

This is a brigade level one-player simulation of the first day of the Battle of Shiloh during the American Civil War. The player directs movement and bombardment of the Union Army against the computer controlled Confederate Army.

The player controls all movements via the joystick, and each turn directs the movement of each of his units. The computer then takes a turn with all movements. The player wins by preventing the Confederate Army from occupying Pittsburg Landing.
title: Shiloh 1862

description:
Quintominoes is a puzzle game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Played on a 8 x 8 board, the player is presented with 12 possible shapes consisting of 5 parts. Each of these shapes can be rotated and placed on the board, but pieces cannot overlap. The player's goal is to fill the board by leaving as few empty spaces as possible. For added challenge, a random piece can be placed on the board at the beginning of the game, or the ability to remove a piece after playing is optional.
title: Quintominoes

description:
Nebs is an arcade game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

The player controls a small arrow, which can move in the four cardinal directions, and must shoot at and eliminate alien nebs. These enemies move unfailingly towards the player, and speed up as more of their brethren are eliminated. The player can set the number of lives they start with from 1 - 5, and can set which wave they initiate on. When all 20 nebs are eliminated, the player progresses to a more difficult challenge.
title: Nebs

description:
Alien kritters are attacking your planet, and only a small number of command ships are available to defend your star-base. Most of the aliens are in stasis. Left to themselves, they will slowly but randomly materialize from one of the eight transportation beams that terminate just above the planet's surface. Once they arrive, these spacecraft will make a kamikaze dive at your command ship. The alien kritters from these transport beams are impervious to your normal weapons, and must be avoided. Instead of waiting for the ships to arrive, you can activate them at a more convenient time by firing on them. Kritters from higher up in each beam are able to maneuver more quickly, and are much more likely to crash into you.

In addition to the menace from the transporter beams, there are free falling kritters. These slowly fall straight down from the top of the screen, and may be shot. They will destroy you if they run into you, and if they slip past your defences will cause you to lose points from your score. Both free falling and transported kritters are worth more points if shot higher up the screen.

You start the game with three command ships. Up to five extra command ships may be awarded by killing alien patrol kritters which occasionally move from right to left across the very top of the screen. Removing all aliens from the screen takes you to the next skill level (which ranges from zero to nine). Each level increases the number and speed of the free falling kritters but also provides you with an extra super-missile. Activating super-missiles allow you to destroy one of the normally invulnerable aliens from the transport beams.

sample_screenshots.caption: A bull-dozer sweeps away the mess after dying on level 9.
Only a few kritters left in the transporter beams.

title: K-razy Kritters

description:
Moon Probe is a 1-player text-based strategy game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player controls a small lunar landing vessel which must land on a specific point on the moon's surface. The player has limited fuel, and must carefully control their vertical and horizontal thrust to make a controlled landing.
title: Moonprobe

description:
Monarch is a strategy game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

Congratulations! You've been elected premier of Setats Destinu, a small communist island 30 x 70 miles long. Your job is to decide upon the country's budget and distribute money to your conutrymen from the communal treasury. The player's goal is to feed and manage their population. Each person needs 100 Rallods (a form of money) per year to survive. Each turn, the player must distribute land to foreign interests for industrial purposes, distribute money to your population for its survival, plant crops, and set money for pollution control. If the player does not keep enough population alive, they will be forced to abdicate at the end of the turn. The goal is to survive for a total of 8 turns. There are multiple difficulty levels available.
title: Monarch

description:
Midway is a 1 player versus computer variant of the board game Battleship for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Played on a 17 x 8 grid, each player places 10 ships, and each ship only takes up one space. Ships have different point values, and each player starts with 1 carrier, 1 tanker, 2 battleships, 3 destroyers, and 3 submarines. Each player takes a turn typing in a coordinate to see if they hit and destroy the enemy vessel. Previously played squares are shown on the board. Players get to decide how many turns the game will last, and the player with the highest score at the end is the victor.
title: Midway

description:
Go Fish is a 1-player versus computer card game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

The player and the computer take turns asking for their opponent for a card. If the opponent has it, the player receives all of their cards of that value. If not, they have to draw one card from the deck. The player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner. Cards are graphically displayed on the screen.
title: Go Fish

description:
Forest Fire is a one player strategy game.

The player's job is to stop a rapidly spreading forest fire. The nearby countryside is displayed on an 18 x 9 grid, which includes woods, dry brush, lakes, your fire tower, a fuel depot, the governor's mansion, and a supply base. Each turn, the player is able to drop fire retardant, set up a ground crew, and dig a fire break. The goal is to minimize property damage to the surrounding countryside. The player takes a significant financial hit if the governor's mansion burns down, and if the fuel depot catches on fire all nearby areas ignite. If the supply base burns, then resources to fight the fire become more scarce. Wind conditions will affect the direction of spread and the speed of the fire.

The player can select stable, unstable, or very unstable wind patterns, and can also start a game with a fire caused by a mild, moderate, or severe thunderstorm. Terrain options include wide open, country, and congested.
title: Forest Fire

description:
Computhello is a 1 - 2 player Othello game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Played on an 8 x 8 board, each player takes turns playing a black or white piece. The goal is to trap 1 or more of the opponent's pieces between your two pieces, thus making them your own. The game goes on until the board is full or there are no legal moves. There are two levels of computer difficulty, and the player can also set the computer to play itself.
title: Computhello

description:
Phobos is a sequel to Caverns of Mars, and has similar game-play. In the previous game, you had defeated the Martians on their home planet, but a group of renegades has escaped, and set up headquarters on the moon Phobos. Your new task is to descend into a heavily defended cavern on this tiny moon, and neutralize the control center at the bottom.

The cavern that you are infiltrating is marked by a number of stages, given in alphabetical order by the letters A to P. The game can be played at four difficulty levels, corresponding to the depth of the cavern. The Novice player is only required to reach stage F, while the Commander needs to complete all of the stages down to P. Each of the stages has a themed obstacle such as flashing barriers, moving walls or bricked up areas that must be shot through.

You control a space-ship, which may move around the screen in any direction. For the first four stages of each level, you are pulled by gravity towards the centre of Phobos and have limited vertical mobility. However this effect disappears as you get closer towards the centre. You also have the ability to shoot downward to destroy enemy infrastructure. But don't be too close to the TNT if you shoot it, or it will explode taking you with it and losing one of your lives.

In addition to dodging lethal obstacles, you are also in constant danger of running out of fuel. Fuel may be replenished by destroying certain bases that appear regularly throughout the cavern. Once you have reached the bottom of the cavern, the control centre, which is defended by a concrete bunker, must be destroyed. This ends the level, and your mission restarts at a higher level. Higher levels seem identical to earlier ones, except you are awarded with an extra flag which appears at the bottom right of the screen. Finishing eight of these levels ends the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: Strobing force fields block your path.
The first stage has lots of fuel available.
Shooting through to the central computer on Novice level.
The second stage has these stationary rockets.

title: Phobos

description:
Laser Racers is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

After years of torturous labor as a slave in the evil world of Death Complex, finally you have a chance to escape. You steal a Laser Racer and careen through seven deadly rooms of the Complex.

The player must navigate seven screens of mazes, but can only move from left to right, with the goal to reach the right hand side of the screen. If the player hits any obstacle, their vehicle is destroyed. Obstacles include moving and flashing walls, and warp pods. The player has 9 lives, and if all are lost, it's game over.
title: Laser Racers

description:
Final Exam is a multiple choice text adventure game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player has a big test coming up, and they must accrue 100 study units to successfully pass the exam. The player encounters a number of text-based scenarios, and must choose their response, and each response will cause the player to gain or lose a certain number of energy and time units. Events that can alter the player's energy and time include a kegger next door, disruptive flight patterns, a homicidal ex-girlfriend, your roommate's drug score, and your amorous girlfriend. These banked time and energy units can be converted to study units.

sample_screenshots.caption: Converting Time and Energy Units to Studying
How to Deal with the Kegger?

title: Final Exam

description:
Creepers is a 1-player adventure game for the 8-bit Atari.

You have arrived on the Island of Gant in an attempt to locate and recover the Golden Chalice of the Kingdom of Corpas. Somewhere within the ancient maze-like Temple of Kavinu lies the Chalice.

The player's party consists of the heir to the Corpas throne Prince Jaun VII, wielder of the Silver Sword Sir Denish, the martial artist Squire Cott, the holder of the Teleporting Ring Scholar Dell, the beautiful female archer Gala the Huntress, the great escape artist Dike the Thief, and the fireball casting Wizard Zigg. All characters must move as a group, and each one of these have individual offense and defensive strength.

Each character has a special skill, and if that character is lost, the skill is lost as well to the party. For instance the huntress can fire arrows, the thief can safely open chests, and the scholar can use special items.

As the player explores the dungeon, they must avoid deathtraps, and engage in combat with Creepers. The goal is to gather four different colored gemstones from the chests within the dungeon, and locate the treasure room, which contains the Chalice. The player must then return successfully to the entry staircase.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Discover a Ruby Within a Chest

title: Creepers

description:
Nazz is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small character who moves in the cardinal directions, and attempts to find the exit to each level of a variety of puzzles. The goal is to complete all the rooms to recover the chalice. The player has 60 seconds to solve each puzzle, and loses a life if they run into obstacles or take other damage. The player starts with 10 lives, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Nazz

description:
You have just discovered friendly droids on Quarxon, in a galaxy far away, when you have suddenly come under attack by other less friendly droids who want to take over the universe. Your task is to defend the friendly droids, currently protected by layers of bunker, from the attackers.

You control a single ship which can move horizontally, and to a limited extent vertically. You can only shoot vertically. Quarxon's atmosphere has several characteristics important for your battle. First, there is a boundary line that is impenetrable to blaster fire. Shooting at this will cause the blast to reflect back to your own position. Naturally occurring holes will frequently appear in this layer, allowing you to shoot the enemy on the other side. Second, shooting twice from the same location will cause a patch to appear, which allows your opponent to shoot through the boundary, even when there are no holes. Thirdly, getting hit by an opponent's shot will activate a crushing atmospheric disturbance which slowly moves inwards, and will destroy you unless you can maneuver between holes in the layer.

There are a number of configurable options for game-play, such as the difficulty (or speed), the number of starting droids, and the number of layers of bunker defending each side's droids and whether you play against another human or the computer. The game concludes when one side has shot all of the other's droids.

sample_screenshots.caption: The crushing layer has been activated on the bottom player.
Victory for the top player. All droids destroyed.
Starting a level with 8 droids each, and one layer of bunker.

title: Quarxon

description:
747 Landing Simulator is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player attempts to land a 747 on a narrow runway. They can control their plane's altitude and heading. Other commercial planes will frequently appear in the viewscreen, and the player must avoid midair collisions. The instrument panels display altitude, speed, distance to runway, and other information. There are 3 levels of difficulty.
title: 747 Landing Simulator

description:
Alien Egg is a text adventure game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

You're a biologist and the only non-engineer among the spaceship's crew. To make yourself useful, you've volunteered for the cryogenic deep freeze experiment. You've been on ice for fifty years, the time it has taken the crew to fly to the newly discovered planet Xepa, where they are to capture an alien egg and return it to Hoboken for analysis. Your time is up. The freezer lid opens automatically. You leap out, eager to take center stage away from all those engineers. But wait, something's wrong. A deadly silence replaces the normal hustle and bustle of the crew's activities.

All entries are via VERB NOUN entry, and the goal is to to figure out how to suit up, exit the spacecraft, capture an alien specimen, and return it to the ship's lab. There are multiple inventory-based puzzles to solve. The player can request hints in each room, for a clue on how to proceed. There is no save/restore feature.
title: Alien Egg

description:
Anthill is a 2-player maze navigation game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Two players, represented by a blue and green square attempt to navigate a rapidly changing maze to go from the bottom of the screen to the top. The first player to reach the top is the victor. If a maze piece appears on top of the player, they are sent back to the start of the maze.
title: Anthill

description:
Attank! is a 2-player tank game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Played from a top-down perspective, each player controls 2 tanks, and tries to destroy the enemy vehicles. Terrain is randomized, but includes tunnels that allow a player to warp across the field, heavy impenetrable forests, lighter forests, impassable swamps and large rocks. Hidden mines can destroy tanks, and terrain can be destroyed if shot or run over. The player can customize the number of hits each tank can receive, shell range, and tunnel configuration. There are options for random bombings, that can destroy sections of the map. There is also a nighttime option, where only tank position and shell strikes are displayed.
title: Attank!

description:
The Bean Machine is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari Computer.

The bean machine continually picks up beans from a tray on the bottom of the screen, and randomly drops beans at points throughout a maze of moving platforms, monsters, and doors. The player controls 5 platforms with pivot points in the center of the screen, and can rotate the platforms clockwise or counterclockwise. Beans will run along the platforms, and as beans move through the maze, their weight will move the platforms. If beans strike each other, one is destroyed and returns to the starting tray. The goal is to navigate all beans to the collecting tray towards the bottom. There are 3 levels of difficulty, and the goal is to guide all beans in the minimal amounto f time.
title: The Bean Machine

description:
Bellum is a 1-player side-scrolling space shooter for the 8-bit Atari.

Why has the dauntless Monty Gillespie-Smith volunteered for yet another hazardous mission? He's answering his Empire's call in its time of need! His vital mission is to deliver a cargo of India tea to the officer's club. He must navigate futuristic landscapes in his trusty biplane, Geraldine.

The player controls a small biplane, which can move vertically, as well as accelerate and decelerate. The ship has the ability to fire directly forwards and drop bombs. The player tries to clear six stages of futuristic alien landscape, while avoiding rockets, laser fields, asteroids, and other environmental dangers. The player has limited fuel, and must shoot fuel depots to recharge during longer missions. The player starts with five lives, and if all are lost it's game over.
title: Bellum

description:
Blackjack Casino is a card game for the 8-bit Atari.

A text-based blackjack game, where all controls are via the joystick. There is a $300 limit per game, and insurance pays double. Players can bet $1, 5, 25, or 100, and 5 cards to win.
title: Blackjack Casino

description:
Blackjack Tutor is a 1-player blackjack teaching game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player competes against a computer opponent, and can choose how the computer opponent will play. The player chooses how many decks to use from 1 to 8. The player can use 4 strategy choices, including: tens count strategy, basic strategy, no strategy, or allow the computer to play. The player can bet from $1 - 1000 at the beginning of each round. The player can receive betting strategy advice.
title: Blackjack Tutor

description:
Bumper Pool Tournament is a 2-player bumper pool game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The goal is to be the first person to sink all 5 of their balls into the opposing side's pocket. The player controls which numbered ball they would like to shoot, which of 8 directions they wish to shoot, and how much power in their shot. Each player takes a turn shooting.
title: Bumper Pool

description:
Bumpomov's Dogs is a 2-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Two dogs must move through a maze, trying to pick up the small bones lying on the ground. Each dog can hold a maximum of 30 bones at a time, and the player must return their collected bones to their doghouse for safety. Each dog can throw dog treats, which if they strike their opponent, will cause them to drop all their collected bones. The dogs cannot stop nor reverse direction, and can only change direction when they encounter an intersection within the maze. The first player to safely return 100 bones to their doghouse is the winner. When two characters become separated within the maze, the game switches to a split screen mode.
title: Bumpomov's Dogs

description:
Burgers! is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player controls a nebulous cloud which, scrolls horizontally at the top of the screen. Below the player, numerous hamburgers take flight, veering off on strange angles. The player must fire down and destroy the hamburgers. If the player comes in contact with a burger, they grow larger. At the end of each round, the player shrinks a bit, but if they grow too large, they will explode, ending the game. Waves have progressively more burgers, and the player begins to encounter larger burgers which split into smaller burgers when hit. Finally, on the last stage, the player encounters the boss burger, which is the width of the game field. There are 4 levels of difficulty.
title: Burgers!

description:
Can't Quit is a 1 - 2 player gambling game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The goal of this game is to move your playing piece from the left to the right on 3 or 4 rows of the game board. The game board is designed in a hexagon with rows numbered 2 to 12. Rows 2 and 12 have 5 spaces, rows 3 and 11 have 7 spaces, all the way to row 7 which has 15 spaces. The player rolls 4 dice, and the player can choose whichever 2 rows contains a sum of 2 of the dice rolled. Depending on the rows chosen, the playing pieces will march one space to the right, or 2 spaces if a double is chosen. On the first rolls, the player chooses the 3 or 4 rows that will be their goal to move a piece all the way to the right. The player can choose to quit after any roll, and forfeit the next turns to their opponent. If the player rolls a dice combination that does not allow them to progress on their chosen rows, then that player loses all progress during their recent turns. The goal is to take a number of spaces, but not to be too greedy and lose all progress. The first player to march across their 3 or 4 chosen rows is the victor.
title: Can't Quit

description:
Castle is a text adventure for the Atari 8-bit computer.

You're vacationing in Pomerania, and desperate to escape your tour guide, you sneak out of the country inn to take a walk alone. Unknowingly, you wander into an enchanted forest down the lane. Up ahead, you can just make out the outlines of a castle shrouded in mist. Even though you know better, you decide to take just a quick peek into one of the castle's heavy-leaded windows. As you step into the dark castle, the door slams shut behind you. The forest's evil wizard has lured another victim into his trap! Your only chance for survival is to escape the castle before the wizard turns you into a newt.

All entries are via VERB NOUN entry, and the goal is to to figure out how to exit the haunted castle. There are multiple inventory-based puzzles to solve. The player can request a hint in each room, for a clue on how to proceed. There is no save/restore feature.

sample_screenshots.caption: A Hint in the Banquet Hall
Examining a Tapestry in the Great Hall

title: Castle

description:
Centurion is a real time strategy war game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player takes on the role of a Roman centurion warrior assigned to destroy ten hordes of barbarians before they destroy the player's ten legions. The player's legion occupies 10 positions on an 11 x 18 grid of hexagons, and you don't know the location of the enemy units until your legion nears them. Enemy units are constantly moving, and you must focus multiple units on single enemy legions to be successful.

Centurion has ten levels of difficulty. Higher levels allow barbarians greater strength, and allows the player less time to plan their moves. Units move by inputting their next moves, up to 4 movements in total. These then progress in realtime.
title: Centurion

description:
Chambers of Zorp is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The planet of Zorp is in grave danger. Only you, the space physician, can prevent a deadly epidemic. Infectious single-celled organisms have propagated in chambers beneath the planet Zorp. Equipped with a nimble probe vehicle, you can fire hypervaccine into the chambers to eradicate the creatures. Unfortunately, the organisms sense your presence when you enter their chamber, and rapidly begin to multiply and mutate into aggressive predators. Can you save the planet from peril?

The player moves a small vehicle, which can move in all directions, and shoots two streams of bullets forwards. The player moves between chambers, and has 99 time units to eradicate the dangers in each chamber. At the beginning of each stage, a number of alien eggs appear, which begin to hatch if the player can't shoot them in time. These creatures begin to assault the player. There are three levels of difficulty: intern, doctor, and surgeon. The player starts with 3 probes, and when all are lost, it's game over.
title: Chambers of Zorp

alternate_titles.title: Block Buster: A Cube-Solving Puzzle Game

description:
Block Buster is a Rubik's Cube game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Players can scramble and solve a Rubik's Cube. The game tracks the length of time and number of turns to solve a puzzle. Moves can be placed via text entry or via joystick.
title: Block Buster

description:
Block 'Em contains 3 arcade games for the 8-bit Atari computer.

  • Blockade: Similar to the arcade game Tron, two players navigate an icon about a field, while they leave a progressively elongating tail. The goal is to destroy the opponent by forcing them to run through one of these tails. Game speed, number of points for victory, and block size are modifiable.
  • Captive Sssnake!: Move a progressively elongating and accelerating snake through a maze, and try to navigate it into the constantly moving black dot representing a hole. The player loses if they strike a wall or a snake tail.
  • Ghost Wall: Compete against a computer opponent which can move through walls with impunity. The goal is to survive as long as possible while both characters leave an elongating tail.
title: Block 'Em

description:
Bootleg is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The speakeasies are counting on you! Unless you can deliver the moonshine, they can't open tonight, and they don't like to be disappointed. The player must thread their way through city streets in their delivery wagon trying to gather different types of booze. While doing this, the player must avoid the Prohibition agent who cruises the streets. He's faster than you, and can set up roadblocks, and will give chase if you approach too close. You can thwart his pursuit by throwing out traps and monetary bribes to slow him down temporarily. After picking up 10 drinks, the player can exit the level to the right, and enter the next city district. Intermittently, an electrical storm passes overhead and disorients the Prohibition agent. The player has limited gas, and must complete the maze quickly, picking up fuel pumps. The player starts with 5 lives, and when all are lost, it's game over. There is a total of 20 different levels.
title: Bootleg

description:
Checker King is a board game for the 8-bit Atari Computer.

Follows standard checkers rules, and allows for 2-player or 1-player versus computer games. There are 5 levels of computer opponent, and the player can chose whether black or red plays first. There is an option to manually set up the board. Only legal moves are allowed, and the computer forces the player to jump an opponent if available.
title: Checker King

description:
Chinese Puzzle is a text adventure for the 8-bit Atari computer.

You just spent the last five days competing as a finalist in the World Cup Pro Am Jigsaw Puzzle Competition. You've devoted all your waking hours in the past year to working on puzzles, but your discipline has paid off. You walk away with the grand prize, an all expenses paid trip to the Orient. After landing in the Orient, you hail a rickshaw to take you into town. The driver offers some light refreshment during the short journey. Gratefully you gulp down the golden liquid, and that's the last thing you remember before you wake up in a dimly lit, paneled room. It turns out the rickshaw driver was hired by the runner-up, who is sore at losing, and wants a little revenge.

The player must navigate a series of colored rooms and mazes to try to escape this trap and reach freedom. All entries are via VERB NOUN entry, and there are multiple inventory-based puzzles to solve. There is no save/restore feature.
title: Chinese Puzzle

description:
Codecracker is a 1 - 2 player code breaking game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player tries to crack a 3 - 5 character code, and can choose to have 1 - 9 turns to try to solve the code. At each turn, the player is told how many characters are correct, but in an incorrect position, and how many of these are in the correct position. In 2-player games, one player gets to input the code, while the other tries to solve it.

sample_screenshots.caption: Four Numbers in the Correct Position
Numbers are Correct, but in the Wrong Position

title: Codecracker

description:
Cribbage is a 1-player cribbage game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Cribbage is a 1-player versus computer cribbage game. Cards and the cribbage board are graphically displayed on the screen. The player must manually move their peg to progress along the cribbage board.
title: Cribbage

description:
Cubbyholes is a 1 - 2 player arithmetic puzzle game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player tries to separate numbers in a 3 x 3 grid into cubbies, by drawing lines around numbers that have equal sums. Sums can equal between 6 to 18, and the player can choose the same number for each game or randomize them. The player can chose 2 - 20 games in total, and receives a final score.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Forgot to Submit my Answers

title: Cubbyholes

description:
Dice Poker is a 1 - 4 player dice game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Players take turns rolling five dice, and the player can reroll any or all of the dice twice more before selecting their scoring category. Scoring categories include the sum of all ones to sixes, 3 of a kind, 4 of a kind, full house, a 4 dice straight, a 5 dice straight, quinta (5 of a kind) and chance (which is the sum of all dice). A game is finished when all 11 scoring categories have been used. Dice are graphically displayed on the top of the screen.
title: Dice Poker

description:
Diggerbonk is a 1-player arcade maze game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

You are an alien, who has landed on Titan, the moon of Saturn. Your goal is to clear out the dangerous mine shaft, and collect the valuable Titan ore.

The player controls a small square who moves about a maze that continuously scrolls from the top. The player must move quickly, for if they get caught on the bottom on the screen, the game is over. The goal is to reach 30,000 points, and there are 9 levels of progressive difficulty. If the player hits the enemies of the maze, it's game over. Enemies include: purple gurples, yellow blinkers, and aqua-chasers. Energy fields and timebombs also provide dangers. Some powerups can temporarily make the player invincible, or allow them to break through a section of wall.

sample_screenshots.caption: The Fog Moves Off the Screen

title: Diggerbonk

description:
Dog Daze is a 2-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Two dogs appear on the screen, each controlled by a different player. Fire hydrants appear on the screen, and the first player to reach the hydrant makes it that color. Immediately a new hydrant then appears on the screen. On the top of the screen is a counter, and for every successfully tagged hydrant, it moves towards that player. The first person to take control of the counter is the winner. If the player runs into a hydrant previously tagged by an opponent, they also lose a point, until the screen is almost filled by tagged hydrants. Each player can throw a bone, and if it hits an untagged hydrant, the player gains the point. If the bone misses, it needs to be collected before it can be thrown again. At the end of a timed section, a car will begin to come across the screen, and if a dog is hit, it's game over.
title: Dog Daze

description:
Dog Daze Deluxe is a 2-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

A version of Dog Daze with improved graphics and sound. Two dogs appear on the screen, each controlled by a different player. Fire hydrants appear on the screen, and the first player to reach the hydrant makes it that color. Immediately a new hydrant then appears on the screen. If a target is not tagged fast enough, a car will drive across the screen, and if it hits a dog, it's game over. On the top of the screen is a counter, and for every successfully tagged hydrant, it moves towards that player. The first person to take control of the counter is the winner. If the player runs into a hydrant previously tagged by an opponent, they also lose a point, until the screen is almost filled by tagged hydrants. Each player can throw a bone, and if it hits an untagged hydrant, the player gains the point. If the bone misses, it needs to be collected before it can be thrown again.
title: Dog Daze Deluxe

description:
Domination is a 1 - 5 player strategy war game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Players compete to be the richest superpower after a specified number of years or turns. All commands are via menu structures, and each turn is timed, giving players a time limit to enter commands. Gameplay occurs in three phases. In the event phase, either a recession occurs and player resources are limited, or a nuclear conflict occurs. If nuclear conflict occurs, the player can declare war against an opponent.

The second phase is the asset phase, where the player can buy or sell factories, energy and gold. They can also divert resources to their army. Finally, in the domination phase, the player can choose to utilize diplomacy to try to gain power with a rival country, or can declare war to forcibly take their resources. When declaring war, the player allocates divisions to attack, and each division allocated provided 1 second of attack time, where the player enters an arcade sequence to shoot at enemy installations with a large cannon. If attacking successfully, the player gains resources from this nation yearly.

The winner is the nation that has amassed the most resources by endgame.

sample_screenshots.caption: Attack or Diplomacy with Another Country

title: Domination

description:
Downhill is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player controls a timed downhill skier, who attempts to navigate a wooded track while travelling through 10 gates. The player can steer themselves left and right as they travel downhill. If the player strikes a tree or gate post, they become slowed down, and must slowly extricate themselves from the obstacle. The player loses 10 seconds for every missed gate. The player can modify the slope and difficulty level of the course.
title: Downhill

description:
Dragon's Quest or a Twist in the Tail is a graphical text adventure for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The king has come to power after the loss of his sister, the former regent. The player is tasked by the king to find his sister's lost magical pendant, the sign of the monarch's right to rule. He claims it was stolen when his sister was killed by a dragon during a hunting party. The king grants the player 500 gold, and tasks him with slaying the dragon. The player heads out into the wilderness, and must explore a number of locations, including an underground cave, an abandoned abbey, a perilous dungeon, and other dangers hidden in the woods.

As the player explores, they learn that the new king has brought his kingdom to ruin, and that the princess has actually been transformed into the dragon. The player must struggle to restore the princess to her true form and regain her throne.

All entries are via VERB NOUN entry. There are multiple inventory-based puzzles to solve. There is a save/restore feature available.
title: Dragon's Quest or a Twist in the Tail

description:
Ennumereight is a 1 - 2 player board game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Two players, or a computer opponent, play on a figure-8 board containing 8 separate spaces. Players take turns choosing one of the 4 spaces on their side of the game board. The numbers of that space are then counted around the board, with one point going to each location until all pieces. If the player plays so that the last space becomes a 2 or a 3 on their opponent's side of the board, they gain those point. The points are removed from the board, and gameplay continues until all points are removed from the board. There are 7 levels of computer opponent difficulty, and the player can start with 4 - 8 points in each space on the circle. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.
title: Ennumereight

description:
Equestrian is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player controls a show horse, as they attempt to jump over and avoid obstacles. Played from an isometric perspective, the player can move in all directions, and can jump to avoid obstacles. There are three horses: Pokey Pete, Aunty Antic, and Gtia Royale, whom have different speeds and jumping abilities. There are two set tracks, and a third track which includes a random assortment of jumps. The player receives penalties for every object hit, and how hard they are hit. The goal is to complete each track with as few of penalties as possible.
title: Equestrian

description:
Escape to Equatus is a 1-player educational arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Many light years ago in a distant galaxy, the planet Mathema collided with a meteor. The planet was completely destroyed, but for a small band of Mathmen who escaped aboard the giant robot ship Metrica. While searching for a new home, the Mathmen landed within a crater of the moon Equatus. As they were exploring, an Equacion battlecruiser attacked, roaring across the mouth of the cavern expelling a mathematical problem, and unleashing a lethal number line that plummeted towards the Mathmen.

The player controls a Solutus fighter ship tasked with defending the stranded Mathmen as they await rescue. As the numbers streak towards the player, the spaceship must be maneuvered horizontally to shoot the correct digits before they reach the Mathmen to answer the question displayed at the top of the screen. Every incorrect answer causes Mathmen to perish, and after three incorrect answers, it's game over. There are 4 levels of difficulty, allowing for more difficult questions, and the numbers descend faster.
title: Escape to Equatus

description:
Game Show is a 2-player game show for the 8-bit Atari computer.

A computerized version of the TV show Family Feud. Players take turns trying to guess the results of survey questions. The first player to ring in and answer correctly can either choose to guess as many survey answers as possible, or can give the opportunity to the other team. After the guessing team has gotten 3 wrong answers, the opposing team has one opportunity to steal their points if they can guess a single further answer.
