The player with the most points at the end is the winner. Players can set the length of turns.
title: Game Show

description:
Gridiron Glory is a 2-player American football coaching game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player starts by choosing 1 of 28 American football teams, and the game attempts to simulate their skill level in a variety of statistics. Gameplay is divided into four 8-minute quarters, and gameplay follows typical American football rules. Each turn, the players have a limited time frame to choose from 8 offensive or 6 defensive plays, which are hidden from their opponent. A player can also select to try for a field goal, and can choose from 3 different kickoffs.
title: Gridiron Glory

description:
Impact is a 2 - 4 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Each play controls a skimmer, which can move in all directions, and has inertia. Each skimmer is armed with a bumper, which will temporarily enact a forcefield around their vessel. If the player hits an unshielded vessel, they'll destroy it. After the shield expires, that vessel is temporarily defenseless until the shield can recharge. If 2 unshielded vessels collide, both are destroyed. Each player starts with the same number of vessels, and the last player standing is the victor. Players can set a timed game, and can give different players a handicap, allowing their shields to last longer. There are 17 different game boards to choose from.
title: Impact

description:
Ion Roadway is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

You are Zarg, the foremost landracer in the star system Althea. You've been given 5 ion-cars, and are tasked with representing Althea in the Galactic Robot Races. If you win, you'll be set free to race again, if not, you and even your memory will be erased from the universe.

The player controls a car than can move left and right, and is capable of reverse, neutral, and 4 speeds. The player must race along the track while avoiding opponent antimatter cars. The player has 5 vehicles, and it's game over when all are lost. The player has limited fuel, and must refill every lap by stopping in the pits. The player gains bonus points by hitting green bonus posts, but these temporarily spin out the vehicle.
title: Ion Roadway

description:
Jax-o is a 1 - 4 player version of the game Jacks for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Each player takes a turn tossing a ball from their side of the play field. They must then quickly move out, grab the required number of jacks, and return to intercept the ball before it hits the far wall and bounces back. As the player completes a field, they are required to pick up more jacks for the next field. If a player makes a mistake, the jacks are rethrown. Make a mistake 3 times, and the turn passes to the next player. There are 7 levels of game difficulty, and players can choose from 4 different sized playing fields. The ball can be fast or slow.
title: Jax-O

description:
Lemonade is a business simulation for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player controls a lemonade stand on a busy street. Every turn, they must decide how many glasses of lemonade they will try to sell, the cost per glass, and their advertising budget. Different weather and road conditions can promote or dissuade sales. The goal is to maximize profit.
title: Lemonade

description:
Letterman is a 1-2 player hangman game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player must try to solve a word by filling in the blanks before the apple sitting atop a person's head is hit with an arrow. Players can choose a random word or can use their own words. Every incorrect answer causes the arrow to approach closer. Players can choose from 3 different levels of difficulty, and can play with or without hints. There is an option for a time limit to games.
title: Letterman

description:
Lookahead is a 1 - 2 player strategy came for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Played on a 7 x 7 game board, the playing field consists of numbers and unknown squares. Player one can only move horizontally, and player 2 can move only vertically, and players score points depending on the square they land on. The goal is to have more points than the opponent when no plays are left. There are 3 levels of computer opponents, and the player can choose the highest available number, and whether there are unknown squares.
title: Lookahead

description:
Mankala is a 1 - 2 player board game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

A computerized version of the ancient board game Mancala. Each player owns six small playing bins and one large home bin, which are arranged in parallel sets. The player can choose for the starting bins to contain 3 - 8 stones, where higher stones creates a more difficult challenge. Players take turns picking up all the stones in a bin, and dropping one stone in each bin in a counterclockwise direction. Each stone dropped into a home bin remains there permanently. There are 4 levels of computer opponents.
title: Mankala

description: Freaky Factory is a maze/exploration game. You play as the head scientist at a factory controlled by a computer. The computer malfunctions and all the automated tools go crazy. You need to work your way through the complex to find the shutdown control for the computer, while collecting the right keys along the way. You must avoid or shoot the rampaging tools, which are also somehow shooting back.
title: Freaky Factory

description:
Mastermatch is a 1 - 2 player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

A computerized version of the board game Mastermind with 6 levels of difficulty. The player attempts to solve a password of different colors squares by each turn guessing what the password each. Each turn the player is told how many squares are correct and in the correct position. Difficulty levels are defined by the number of rows or turns available to solve the puzzle, the number of columns of pieces to try to solve, and the number of possible colors within each square.
title: Mastermatch

description:
Math Mission is a 1-player math learning game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player must answer math questions as their spaceship flies across an alien landscape at the bottom of the screen. The player has a limited fuel supply which can only be replenished by quickly answering math questions correctly. Wrong answers and slow answers cause fuel drainage. The players receive a bonus for answering certain numbers of questions correctly, and for successfully completing a number of worlds. As the game progresses, math challenges become more difficult. If the ship runs out of fuel, it's game over.
title: Math Mission

description:
Math*UFO is a 1-player arcade math educational game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

A UFO with a mathematical equation moves vertically up and down on the screen. On the left of the screen are multiple possible answers. The player moves a turret vertically until it aligns with the correct answer. They must then shoot the UFO as it passes by to destroy it. Each game is played with 10 equations, and there is the option to do addition, subtraction, multiplication, or division questions. The player receives a final score out of 100.
title: Math*UFO

description:
Mathematic-Tac-Toe is a 2 player Tic Tac Toe game for the 8-bit Atari

Each player takes turns playing an X or an O on a 3 x 3 game board. A player wins by scoring 3 in a row. Each turn, the player must answer a mathematics question correctly, otherwise they forfeit their turn. There are 15 levels of difficulty, and players can choose addition, subtraction, division or multiplication questions.
title: Mathematic-Tac-Toe

description:
Melt-Down is a 1-2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

You're a night watchman alone in a small-town nuclear power plant. You discover a leak in the cooling tower, and are tasked with maintaining a safe level in the tower to prevent a nuclear disaster. You do this by carrying buckets of water from a sink at the bottom of a series of platforms and ladders, and dumping them into the top of the tower.

Mutant radioactive mice crawl from both sides of the maze, and the player must jump over them. The player receives bonus point for jumping over a mouse and each bucket filled into the tower. There are 4 skill levels.
title: Melt-Down

description:
Memory Match is a 1 - 2 player matching game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Players try to match items on a 6 x 7 grid by typing in the number of a box. Players can choose to match symbols, pictures, words, or letters. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.
title: Memory Match

description:
Micro Sailing is a 1 - 2 player sailing game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player controls a small sailing vessel, which they must navigate past a number of pylons in the order demonstrated by a lead vessel. The player must then chart this course, while dealing with changing wind conditions. The first player to chart the correct course is the winner. Players can choose standard or advanced rules, as well as clear or stormy weather.
title: Micro Sailing

description:
The Midas Touch is a 1 - 2 player phrasal guessing game for the 8-but Atari computer.

Two human players can compete, or the player competes against themselves. The player takes turns spinning a wheel that has numerous stones and other valuable material written it, and the value of the material corresponds to the score the player receives for each correct letter guessed. Vowels must be purchased. The first player to guess the entire phrase wins points for the round.
title: The Midas Touch

description:
Moon Marauder is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Prestrike expeditionary force from the Omega-J5 system have invaded our moon! They're building military installations to prepare for a full scale assault on the Earth.

The player controls a spaceship hovering over the surface of an alien planet. The ship can move laterally and forwards as the alien landscape scrolls underneath. The player tries to destroy enemy military installations while avoiding attacking vessels and environmental hazards. The player has a limited fuel supply, and earns extra fuel by destroying enemy fuel depots. The player starts with 3 ships, and when all are lost, it's game over. There are 4 levels of difficulty.
title: Moon Marauder

description:
Mugwump is a 1-player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

You've been mugwump hunting all weekend. It's damp and cold in this swamp, but at last you have four of the critters cornered. They are hiding in a 10 x 10 swamp, and each turn you search one location in the swamp, and are informed the distance you are from all 4 creatures. Using this information, you must try to catch all the mugwumps in 10 turns or less.
title: Mugwump

description:
Musical Pilot is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player controls a small airplane which can fly up and down on a musical scale. As the player flies, balloons which correspond to musical notes appear on the screen, and the appropriate note is played. The player tries to hit the balloon with their propeller. If the player strikes all balloons in a song, they advance to a more difficult stage. There is 4 stages in all, and the player gets a total of 4 chances to try to reach and complete the final stage. The player receives 1 point for each balloon destroyed. If a balloon is missed, the player must repeat that level, and can not advance to the highest rank.
title: Musical Pilot

description:
Number Blast is a 2-player competitive math game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Two players are given the same mathematical equation, and they must use their joystick to enter the correct answer as quickly as possible. Once they have an answer, they try to blast their opponent. If they are correct, they gain points, but if the blasting player is wrong, they lose pints. Gameplay options include: addition, addition tables, multiplication, multiplication tables, integer addition, and integer multiplication.
title: Number Blast

description:
Numberland Nightwatch is a 1-player educational game for the 8-bit Atari.

In a distant region of the kingdom of Numberland is a small outpost of scholars, gathered together in a castle to ponder mathematical problems. The king has charged them with solving a baffling mystery. When night falls, and the kingdom is quiet, a strange phenomenon begins. Numbers form in the atmosphere and fly across the sky. They take with them some of the kingdom's valuable energy. To stop them, you've built a generator and a pulsar, and now you have to bring the menacing numbers under control.

As a number speeds past, you can grab it with your generator. Then, race to the pulsar at the left, and set up a factor of one of the invaders. As the number flies past the pulsar, fire the factor at the number, and repeat until all factors have been exhausted.

There are 6 levels of difficulty.
title: Numberland Nightwatch

alternate_titles.title: Moonbase Io: the battle for the moons of Jupiter

description: Moonbase Io is a space shooter where you are a fighter pilot who has to defend the moons of Jupiter. Part of the game is a vertical scrolling shooter while part is a fixed screen shooter more similar to Space Invaders. The game code comes on either disk or cassette, but the disk version still comes with a cassette that contains speech and sound effects. For the cassette version, a single cassette contains both the code and the audio.
title: Moonbase Io

alternate_titles.title: Outlaw / Howitzer: Two games of marksmanship for 1-2 players

description:
Outlaw / Howitzer is a collection of two games for the Atari 8-bit computer. Each game allows 2-player or player versus computer.

Howitzer: Each player controls a tank on either side of a river. The tank can move in all directions, and the player can control the angle of their turret to fire towards the enemy. A point is scored by destroying an enemy tank..

Outlaw: Two gunfighters shoot at each other across a field of cacti. The outlaw can move in all directions, and can fire straight or on an angle. Cacti deflect bullets. A point is scored by hitting the enemy.
title: Outlaw / Howitzer

description:
Preschool Games is a series of video games for young children for the 8-bit Atari computer.

  • Battleship: Guess the secret location of the computer's battleship on a 3 x 3 grid before it guesses yours.
  • Counting: The computer plays a tune, and the player determines how many notes were played.
  • Piano: Play music using 9 separate keys
  • Musical Chairs: 2 player game, where the player tries to be the first to choose which of 9 stars has disappeared.
  • Rock-Scissors-Paper: A 1 - 2 player guessing game.
  • Soundbox: Press a number on the keyboard to head a different sound.
  • Tic-Tac-Toe: 1 - 2 player board game
  • Touch Me: Memory game using sound, with a goal to remember 8 or 16 notes.
title: Preschool Games

description:
Pro Bowling is a 1 - 4 player 10 pin bowling game for the 8-bit Atari.

Players take turns bowling 10 frames, with 2 balls per frame. The ball moves vertically across the alley, and the player chooses when to release the ball. The player can provide spin to the ball.
title: Pro Bowling

description:
Pusky is a 2-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player controls a small vehicle that can move in all directions, and can fire in the direction they're facing. Bubbles appear on the screen, and if a player shoots them, they're teleported to that location. The first player to hit their enemy 4 times is the victor.
title: Pushky

description:
Pushover is a 1 - 2 player puzzle game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

You're locked in a life-or-death struggle with your opponent high atop a two-sided cliff. As quickly as possible, you must interpret three or more command symbols. The player must as quickly as possible respond to the command with the joystick. Options include: arrows, numbers, letters, and a mix of these. When a player makes a correct answer, they push their opponent closer to the edge. When a player loses 3 rounds, it's game over.
title: Pushover

description:
Puzzler is a 1-player jigsaw game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player tries to unscramble 4 x 4 puzzles. The player can choose to work with or without answers, and pieces can only be placed in the correct location. The game tracks how many moves were needed to solve a puzzle.
title: Puzzler

description:
Rabbotz! is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player must avoid and destroy a number of rabbotz that continuously move towards and try to eat their character. The player is armed with a limited number of mines they can release, and if the rabbotz step on them, they are destroyed. The player can move in the cardinal directions, and must be careful to avoid their own mines. Smiley faces appear, which provide bonus points if gathered. The player earns more mines by stepping in the house icon, which moves each time mines are collected. There are 9 levels of difficulty, and player can define whether they start with 1 - 9 lives.
title: Rabbotz!

description:
Raid on Gravitron is a 1st person space shooter for the 8-bit Atari.

Played from 1st person perspective, the player tries to destroy a number of alien ships before their fuel runs out. The player fires a red laser, while alien vessels return fire which must be dodged. Only one enemy ship appears on the screen at a time, and when they are destroyed, a new enemy appears. The player has a limited energy supply, and the goal is to destroy all alien vessels before fuel runs out. There is a training and combat mode of gameplay. The player starts with 10 ships.
title: Raid on Gravitron

description:
Cypher Bowl is a 2 player American football game for the 8-bit Atari.

Played on a vertically scrolling field, each team has 5 players. Game play is divided into four 8-minute quarters. There are a total of 16 offensive and defensive plays each side can choose, and a number of offensive and defensive positions each team can utilize. During each play, the player controls one active character, while the computer controls the remainder of the team. Players can also try to punt or score a field goal for extra points. Closely follows the rules of American football, but does not contain kickoffs or penalties.
title: Cypher Bowl

description:
Reversi is a 1 - 2 player board game for the 8-bit Atari.

Players take turns placing tokens on an 8 x 8 board. A player is black or white, and each piece must be played so that there is an opposing colored piece between their square and a piece already played. The player receives all pieces between their two tokens. The player with the most tokens when no plays are left is the victor. There are 3 levels of computer opponent, and the player can compete against a human or computer opponent.
title: Reversi

description:
Ringmaster is a 1-player mathematics arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player selects a number, and must then move across a field of elephants by only stepping on those that are a multiple of the number selected. If the player moves to the top of the screen and back, they can chose a new number. If they complete all of the numbers, then they go to a higher challenge with more numbers available. If they miss an elephant or step on the wrong elephant, they must restart the challenge.
title: Ringmaster

description:
Rush Hour is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a car that must travel across 6 lanes of traffic and a railroad track in order to reach the fuel pumps on the far side. The vehicle will always travel horizontally within lanes, but can be steered left and right. There are 4 fuel pumps, and the player must navigate a vehicle to each of these. After doing this, the game becomes more difficult with thicker traffic. The vehicle has 2 speeds. The player starts with 3 cars, and it's game over if all are lost by hitting another vehicle. There's limited fuel to compete each level.

sample_screenshots.caption: One Vehicle is at the Pump

title: Rush Hour

description:
Saratoga is a 1-player strategy wargame for the 8-bit Atari.

Based upon the Battle of Saratoga during the American Revolutionary War in 1777. The player controls American forces against the British. The player controls units by moving them to a a different location. American forces are shown in white, while British forces are red and Hessian mercenaries are orange. Each set of units has a muster strength, which is maximum strength, and their actual combat strength. The player's score, and remaining American and British forces are displayed on the screen. The game consists of 48 turns from January 2nd - December 23rd. There are 8 different game types, which defines British and American troop strength. Player movement follows zones of control, preventing movement through enemy owned terrain. Combat occurs by moving a unit onto another opponent's location, and combat is effected by unit direction, terrain type, and unit strength.
title: Saratoga

description:
Seven Card Stud is a 1 - 2 player card game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

There are a total of 6 opponents, 4 - 5 of whom are controlled by the computer. Each player starts with 3 cards, all of theirs are displayed by the computer, but only the top card is displayed by each opponent. The players undergo 2 rounds of betting, and then 1 more card is added to the pile until a total of 7 cards are present for each player. Cards 3 - 6 are displayed to every player, while only the player's card 7 is shown. The player with the highest ranked poker hand is the winner.
title: Seven Card Stud

description:
Sleazy Adventure is a text adventure for the 8-bit Atari.

A friend of yours has just bought a sailboat, but it is in Thailand at present. You agree to sail it back, knowing that you can use it to import contraband. The more valuables you try to bring back home, the greater the risk.

The player must explore the streets of Bangkok looking for illicit goods including: a golden Buddha statue, "incense", and ebony. These are acquired by solving a number of puzzles. These must then be carefully hidden aboard your friend's boat and sailed back to America. There, the player is met by a number of people interested in purchasing, or arresting you for your cargo. There is no save or restore feature. All commands are via VERB NOUN text entry.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Discover a Flashlight in the Sewers

title: Sleazy Adventure

description:
Smasher is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the Atari 8-bit.

The Vorpons, enemies from a neighboring galaxy, are swarming through your Empire's intergalactic port. Their goal is to destroy the Empire. You control the most colossal weapon ever devised- The Smasher. Your job is to crush their tiny craft into oblivion and save the Empire.

Some of the enemy ships, Cruisers, command a crack Vorpon suicide squadron, and are filled with super-powerful explosives. They cruise between the jaws of The Smasher, hoping to deceive the player into crushing them.

The Smasher can be moved horizontally, and crusher whatever lies between its two arms. The goal is to smash all ships that aren't cruisers, to advance to the next level. The player has limited time to complete each level, as any ship that crosses the screen unsmashed twice allows the aliens to capture a part of the space station. If the player moves the smasher over a captured area, it is destroyed. These areas are removed if the corresponding ship is smashed. Its game over if 3 smashers are lost.
title: Smasher

description:
Seawolf II and Gun Fight are a series of previously released arcade games ported to the 8-bit Atari.

  • Gunfight: Two player controlled gunfighters face off across the dusty Western terrain. Each fighter has a pistol, and shoots at their opponent. The gun fighters can move in all directions, and can approach about half way to the center line. Cacti and stagecoaches can block bullets. Each player gets a point whenever they hit their opponent.

  • Seawolf II:: The player controls a submarine that moves horizontally at the bottom of the screen, and attempts to destroy passing boats by firing vertically upwards. The submarine must reload after 5 torpedoes, and the player must time their shots to avoid hitting moving obstacles.
title: Seawolf II and Gun Fight

description:
Snark Hunt is a 1 - 8 player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari.

Played on an 8 x 8 board, the player must determine the location of 1 - 9 snarks hidden somewhere on the board. To determine their location, the player fires vorpal beams from any of the locations around the outside of the grid. A vorpal beam travels in a straight line unless it comes near a snark. A vorpal beam that runs directly into a snark is absorbed. A vorpal beam that is fired next to a snark is redirected 90 degrees away from the snark. This information is marked on the screen as the player discovers it, and the goal is to solve the snark locations in as few of screens possible. After marking all snark locations, the player can ask the computer to confirm snark location.

Either a computer or a player can hide the snarks. A time limit can be set from 25 to 975 ticks, which affects the final score.
title: Snark Hunt

description:
Solitaire is a 1-player card game for the 8-bit Atari.

Simulates the 7-column card game Solitaire using a single deck. Uses typical casino rules, where the player draws 1 card at a time, but can only go through the deck a single time. The player is rewarded $5 for each card played on an ace. The player can choose to repeat the deck again, but does not receive further winnings. Each game is timed.
title: Solitaire

description:
Space Chase is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

You're in a beautiful, colorful galaxy. Your mission is to conquer all the planets for the Galactic Federation and then go to the next galaxy. The player controls a ship that can move in all directions. The player must watch out for Clone Robot Ships that will relentlessly pursue the player, destroying every planet in their path. If an enemy ship reaches the player, it's game over. The player can scroll off one edge of the screen to appear on the other side to avoid the pursuing enemy.

The player can release nukes, which act as mines to destroy the enemy clone ships if hit. The player can select the number of nukes they have at the beginning of each level. There is also an option for shields, which will protect the player from their own nukes.
title: Space Chase

description:
Haunted Hill is a 1-player arcade game for the TRS-80.

The controls a small character on the bottom of the screen whom moves laterally, and tries to shoot ghosts that move towards the bottom of the screen. Ghosts move horizontally until they reach a barricade, at which point they move down one level and continue to move. The field is full of tombstones. A shot ghost becomes a tombstone. When a tombstone is destroyed, it becomes a larger ghost that flies about the screen until it is shot. If the player is hit by any ghost, they lose a life, and the level restarts.

The player can choose to start with 3 or 5 lives, and there is a fast and slow gameplay mode.
title: Haunted Hill

description:
Space Shuttle: Module One is a 1-player space shuttle simulation for the Atari 8-bit.

The player can try to complete an entire spaceflight, including launch to achieve orbit, descent, and touchdown, or can attempt 1 of these 3 components as a training mission. During launch and touchdown, the player controls the shuttle's pitch and roll, while in the descent phase the player only controls the pitch. During launch and landing, the player plays from a first person perspective within the cockpit, and has a throttle, range finder, altimeter, indicator panel, and clock to help their mission. The descent phase is played from a side view, and the player most carefully maintain their shuttle within the glide path to avoid their shuttle being lost.
title: Space Shuttle: Module One

description:
Space Trek is a 1-player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari.

As captain of the U.S.S. Starship, you're our last hope for destroying the invading Oralop spaceships intent on capturing this galactic outpost of democracy!

Gameplay is on an 8 x 8 grid of 64 quadrants, and the player has limited fuel and stardates to complete their mission. Each quadrant can contain a sun which must be navigated around, a friendly star base which the player can recharge, and enemy Oralop vessels. The player's vessel is armed with long range sensors to investigate adjacent quadrants, or can call up a galactic report to review all quadrants the player has occupied.

The player does battle with Oralaps, and is armed with photon torpedoes and phasers. The player has access to a status report on the condition of their ship's equipment. The player must control their shield status.
title: Space Trek

description:
Spelling Genie is a 1 - 2 player language learning game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player creates a custom word list to be used in a number of word games. The player must correctly spell the words.

  • Mix Up: The player must rapidly unscramble words to score points.
  • Pop On: A word flashes every 5 - 6 seconds. The player scores points by rapidly spelling words correctly.
  • Tip Off: One letter in a word appears, with blanks for the remaining letters. Every few seconds a single letter in a different position is displayed.
  • Vowels: Words appear from the word list missing the vowels, and the player must fill them in.

The player can enter a tournament mode, where different games are used.
title: Spelling Genie

description:
Sultan's Palace is a 1-player text adventure for the 8-bit Atari.

The evil Sultan Abdul has captured the Shah's daughter, Princess Fatima and intends to marry her. Your mission is to locate and free Princess and escape the Sultan's palace. The player starts outside the Sultan's palace, the guards drugged, and a massive iron gate in their way. As the player explores the palace, they must contend with palace guards, find secret passageways, and explore more than one harem.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry. The player can ask for help at any time to get advice on specific areas. There is no save or restore feature.
title: Sultan's Palace

description:
Tact Trek is a 1 - 2 player tactical space war game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player engages in combat against 1 - 3 enemy vessels, or a human opponent. The player's ship, Enterprise, is always displayed in the center of the screen while enemy vessels approach. The ship is armed with phasers and torpedoes. Torpedoes must be armed into individual tubes before fired, and each command requires a specific amount of time to deploy. The player can lock onto the enemy vessel, or manually fire their weapons. The player must also control the heading of their vessel, and can launch probes, scan enemy vessels, and alter the energy distribution to their shields and weapons.
title: Tact Trek

description:
Three Holiday Games is a collection of 3 Christmas themed games for the 8-bit Atari.

  • Quick as a Wick: Try to light all the candles on a Christmas tree before the elf on the bottom of the screen skates across the screen. The player moves a burning coal to light candles, but if it's moved across a burning candle, they're snuffed out.

  • The Spy Who Came in from the Code: The player creates messages which are turned into cryptograms for their friends to solve.

  • The Twelve Daze of Christmas: A phrasal template game that creates a Christmas song to the tune of 'Twelve Days of Christmas', complete with music.

sample_screenshots.caption: The Spy Who Came in from the Code

title: Three Holiday Games

description:
Typo Attack is a 1-player typing arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Can you defend 8 bases at once from a bombardment of falling typos. The player controls 8 bases, each represented by a different letter or keyboard commands. When that command is pressed, a laser is fired vertically to destroy the descending typos. During the level, the letters representing the different laser silos changes. If a typo reach the laser, a piece of ground is destroyed. If the ground is hit 5 times in one spot, the player's defenses are breached, and it's game over. Game play becomes progressively more difficult as the game progresses.
title: Typo Attack

description:
Weakon is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

You've been shrunken down to subatomic size in search of the elusive Weakons. Your objective is to capture as many Weakons as you can, and deliver them to the generator at the center of the screen.

The player controls a small ship which can move in all directions and fires directly forwards from the left. The player must avoid dangerous mesons, gamma photons, and ionizing radiation. Every 20 seconds a Weakon appears. If the player successfully captured it, it can be brought to the generator that appears in the center of the screen, The player starts with 4 craft, and it's game over if all are lost. The player gains a new life every 10,000 points. The player levels up after capturing 2 Weakons, and there are a total of 10 difficulty levels.
title: Weakon

description:
Wizard's Gold is a text adventure game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player begins their adventure within the bedroom of a wizard's house, with the goal to find a hidden bar of gold within the dark catacombs beneath his home. The player must explore a variety of rooms, including: the broom repair room, a psychedelic room, an aquarium, and a fungus room.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry. The player can ask for help at any time to get advice on specific areas. There is no save or restore feature.
title: Wizard's Gold

description:
Wizard's Revenge is a text-adventure for the 8-bit Atari.

You have made a powerful wizard very angry. As punishment, he has placed you in a strange land. Your goal is to escape from there and return to the normal world alive. The wizard has placed many traps and a few hints in your way to make things challenging for you. The player has limited health, and starts at 50%. Smaller injuries deplete health leading to death, while major injuries lead to instant death. There is a basic combat system for monsters found throughout the land. There are numerous dead ends and ways to die, including: poisonous snakes, rock slides, spike traps, cave bats, and consuming too much water. The player must explore caverns and forests to escape to freedom.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry. The player can ask for help at any time to get advice on specific areas. There is no save or restore feature.

sample_screenshots.caption: What's an Adventure Game Without a Torch?

title: Wizard's Revenge

description:
Word Search Generator is a 1 - 2 player game for the 8-bit Atari.

The program generates custom made word searches up to 15 x 15 characters in size. The player then competes in timed or untimed games to try to find all of the words. Allows for multiplayer games.
title: Word Search Generator

description:
Wordgo is a 1 - 2 player word creation game for the 8-bit Atari.

Players are given the first part of a word, and must choose from 16 word endings in a 4 x 4 grid to complete a word. Each ending used will make it unavailable for future words. The player is rewarded points based upon how quickly they can make a word. There are 2 levels of difficulty. Each game presents 10 starting word options, and the player has 30 seconds to complete each word. It is not always possible to make a word with each selection.
title: Wordgo

description:
Wordmaker is a 1-player word construction game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player tries to create as many 3 or 4 letter words as possible in a specified time limit. The same word can't be used twice. The player gains 5 points for each correct word, and loses 5 for each incorrect word or duplicate.
title: Wordmaker

description:
Wyzle! is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small spaceship with limited fuel on a small horizontally scrolling level. Gravity invariably pulls the ship downwards, while upwards thrust uses limited fuel. The ship is armed with horizontally firing cannons, and can also drop bombs. Fuel depots refuel the ship if destroyed. The player starts with 4 ships, and it's game over if all are lost. The goal is to destroy as many enemy installations as possible.
title: Wyzle!

description:
Yahtman is a dice game for one to nine players for the 8-bit Atari.

Players compete against Yahtman, the computer opponent. Players take turns rolling five dice, and the player can reroll any or all of the dice twice more before selecting their scoring category. Scoring categories include the sum of all ones to sixes, 3 of a kind, 4 of a kind, full house, a 4 dice straight, a 5 dice straight, or a Zinger (5 of a kind) and chance (which is the sum of all dice). A game is finished when all 11 scoring categories have been used. Dice are graphically displayed on the top of the screen.
title: Yahtman

description:
Star Island is an Atari 8-bit version of the Cinematronics arcade game Star Castle. An enemy is hiding out behind three layers of shielding, with additional protection by homing missiles and a cannon. Your task is to pilot your ship to avoid the obstacles, take out the shields and destroy your foe.

The ship that you pilot moves about the screen by controlling the orientation and thrust, and has some inertia so it continues to move after stopping thrust. You can pass through the edges of the screen, which wrap to the other side. You can also collide with the island's shield without damage, but it brings you to a complete stop. Colliding with one of the protective missiles, or a shot from the cannon will lose one of your lives.

The three layers of shields are slowly rotating about your opponent. Shooting them will remove a section, which allows the next shot to pass unaffected. Removing all of the sections of a shield will trigger a new layer to be constructed. A single shot, passing through holes in all three layers of shields is enough to destroy your opponent. And then the next one appears, with slightly faster missiles and more effective cannons.

sample_screenshots.caption: About to be hit by the cannon.
Some holes have been shot through the shields.

title: Star Island

description:
Caverunner is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small character whom can run and jump. The goal is to run the levels of a multi-tiered cave. The player attempts to avoid a number of deadly obstacles including springs, waterfalls, water, and green slime. Each level is timed, and the player must quickly finish the level. There are 3 levels of difficulty, and 2 available caves.
title: Caverunner

description:
Dan Strikes Back is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Digger Dan's most prized possession was the Great Diamond, which he unearthed near Round Mount in the Australian outback. His arch enemy Brian the Blob found out where Dan kept the diamond and stole it from him. Brian took the diamond to his deepest vault and locked it away there.

The player controls Dan, as he travels steadily deeper into a series of caverns. On each level, Dan must trample the mushrooms and collect the small diamonds to open the passageway to the next deeper level of the vault. The player must avoid the creatures that roam the underground caverns, and all the while Brian the Blob slowly chases after the player. The player can move horizontally and downwards, they can also move vertically while in tight vertical shafts. If the player strikes an enemy, they lose a life. Three lives lost, and it's game over.
title: Dan Strikes Back

description:
Duellin' Droid is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Julian the Duellin' Droid has been assigned to rescue the members of his droid family from the clutches of the evil droids and monsters on the surface of the planet Zennor. Only by destroying the creatures with his tactical laser disruptor, can he collect the fleeing members of his family, escape through to the next planetary level and evade the aggressors of Zennor.

The player controls a small character that can move in all directions, and can also fire in 8 directions. The player must collect the small moving pink characters. Numerous enemies track towards the player, and the player must destroy all enemies to advance to the next level. Static anodes also present a danger to the player. The player starts with 3 lives, and it's game over when all are lost. A new life is gained every 10,000 points.
title: Duellin' Droid

description:
Escape from Perilous is a 1-player exploration and arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small character who moves in the cardinal directions. The character health is displayed in the top left of the screen, and if they touch an enemy, an obstacle, or move to a different screen, the health decreases. As the player explores different screens, they try to locate the sword, wand, cup, and pentacle. After obtaining all 4 items, they can leave the level via the northern gate. There are 3 levels in total: The Garden of Perilous, Lower Perilous, and Chapel Perilous. Items come in darkness and light variety, and if they are used in opposition, the player automatically loses the game.
title: Escape from Perilous

description:
Krazy Kopter is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

You are involved in a war with a neighboring country, which has captured 2 of your top secret agents. They have effected their escape by hijacking a green army truck and are desperately trying to navigate their way home. You have been scrambled in your helicopter to aid their escape by eliminating the fleet of cars in pursuit.

The player controls a helicopter that moves in all directions, and can drop bombs. The player must destroy any cars that appear before they can leave the bridge. A car when hit often immediately reverses direction. If a car escapes, hostile forces are alerted, and the player will be shot down by a missile. If the player shots the green army truck, they are also destroyed. There are 3 levels of difficulty. Level 1 has navy missiles. Level 2 adds anti-aircraft rockets, and level 3 further adds zig-zagging UFOs. The level progresses after destroying 75 cars. The player starts with 9 lives, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Krazy Kopter

description:
Steeple Jack is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player must ascend a series of ladders to climb higher on a brick chimney. The player must jump between ladders, trying to avoid gaps in ladders and ghosts and other enemies that approach the player. There are 4 levels of difficulty, and the player starts with 3 lives.
title: Steeple Jack

description:
Time Warp is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Attempt to capture the enchanted ring and banish the Time Lord.

The player controls a small character who can move in all directions through a number of maze-like screens. The player picks up offensive, defensive powerups, as well as bullets, treasures, and tools as they explore. Treasures and tools can be used to collect items and clues to the quest. The player gains experience by killing enemy creatures. There is a save and restore feature.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Need Treasure at the Lion

title: Time Warp

description:
Word Olympics is a 1 - 2 player spelling word game for the 8-bit Atari.

Players have to solve anagrams by rearranging the letters present on the screen up to 8-letter words. The player rearranges the letters by selecting them from a 3 x 3 box with the joystick, and each correct letter choice is kept on the screen. Each correct answer causes a character to run a set distance across the top of the screen. The first player to help their character run the length of the screen is the winner. There a are multiple difficulty levels available.
title: Word Olympics

description:
Balloon Pop is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small see saw that can be moved horizontally on the bottom of the screen. A character jumps from the side of the screen, and the player must move the upper end of the see saw under the character as they fall, to propel the character on the other side up into the air. On the top of the screen are a number of balloons that the player attempts to pop by bouncing their characters into them. If the character falls to the floor without the see saw properly positioned beneath them, a life is lost. The player starts with 5 lives, and it's game over when all are lost. There are 2 levels of gameplay, that have different see saw width.
title: Balloon Pop

description:
Barn Storm is a side-scrolling 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

The player attempts to fly through a number of barns, while avoiding dangers including fences, other planes, windmills, and animals. The game is timed, and a level is finished once the correct number of barns is reached. The player can accelerate or decelerate, and can move up and down to avoid obstacles. If the player strikes an obstacle, they are moved back and are temporarily pause. The goal is to minimize the time required to clear the barns.
title: Barn Storm

description:
Crypto-Mania is a 1 - 4 player word game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player takes turns attempting to spell words from a puzzle containing numerous letters. After each word is chosen, the opposing teams have the option to challenge it. Each player receives points for the length and quality of the words created.
title: Crypto-Mania

description:
Lazer Feds is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small spaceship which can move in all directions, and fires vertically downwards. As the screen scrolls forwards, the player must avoid and destroy enemy turrets while avoiding flashing mines. The player has 5 lives, and it's game over when all are lost. There are 2 levels of difficulty.
title: Lazer Feds

description:
Money $pin is a 1 - 4 player word guessing game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player takes turns guessing letters to try to solve a word. Each turn, the player can purchase a vowel, take a spin on a slot machine to determine the value of their consonants, or try to solve the puzzle. Players can chose to have previously guessed letters displayed or not, and players can make their own custom word sets. The first player to guess he word wins the round, and keeps their money for the next round.
title: Money $pin

description:
Cribbage is a 1-player versus computer cribbage game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Cribbage is a 1-player versus computer cribbage game. Cards and the cribbage board are graphically displayed on the screen. The player is required to count their own points after each hand, and the computer judges if the player's count is in agreement.
title: Cribbage

description:
Dominoes is 1-player board game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player starts with 6 dominoes. The player with the highest double plays first. Each player adds to the leading edge of the dominoes if they have a tile that matches that displayed on the screen. If they don't have a correct tile, they must draw one from the boneyard.

There are two game options. If the player draws from the boneyard it is their turn again, or the turn goes to their opponent.
title: Dominoes

description:
Darts is a 1-player skill game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a hand, which they must position on a dart board to score points. There are 10 levels of difficulty, which determine the shakiness of the throwing arm. The player also sets the level of the computer opponent. The player counts down points from 1001, 905, 501, or 301. The first player to reach a score of 0 is the winner, and the scoring points must be a double. The player can choose to require a double at the start of the game.
title: Darts

description:
Cribbage & Dominoes is a compilation of two previously released games for the 8-bit Atari.

Contains:

  • Cribbage
  • Dominoes
title: Cribbage & Dominoes

description:
European Scene: Jigsaw Puzzles Vol 1 is a jigsaw puzzle game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player completes two puzzles displaying either the Colosseum in Rome or the Arc de Triomphe in Paris. There are 8 difficulty levels, which define the size and number of pieces. Pieces are chosen from a moving belt, and on easier difficulty levels, the computer will correct pieces placed in the wrong location.
title: European Scene: Jigsaw Puzzles Vol 1

description:
European Scene: Jigsaw Puzzles Vol 2 is a jigsaw puzzle game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player completes two puzzles displaying either the Parthenon in Greece or Neuschwanstein Castle in Germany. There are 8 difficulty levels, which define the size and number of pieces. Pieces are chosen from a moving belt, and on easier difficulty levels, the computer will correct pieces placed in the wrong location.
title: European Scene: Jigsaw Puzzles Vol 2

description:
Hickory Dickory Dock / Baa, Baa, Black Sheep is a 1-player sliding block puzzle for the 8-bit Atari.

Players can choose a picture based upon either nursery rhyme. The sliding block puzzle can be 3 x 3, 4 x 4, 5 x 5, or 6 x 6. The player can choose from 6 levels of difficulty, which determines the level of mixing prior to starting a game.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hickory Dickory Dock - Mixed up 3 x 3 Puzzle
Baa, Baa, Black Sheep - Game Setup

title: Hickory Dickory Dock / Baa, Baa, Black Sheep

description:
Humpty Dumpty / Jack and Jill is a 1-player sliding block puzzle for the 8-bit Atari.

Players can choose a picture based upon either nursery rhyme. The sliding block puzzle can be 3 x 3, 4 x 4, 5 x 5, or 6 x 6. The player can choose from 6 levels of difficulty, which determines the level of mixing prior to starting a game.
title: Humpty Dumpty / Jack and Jill

description:
Kickback is a 1-player arcade football game for the Atari 400.

The player controls a single football player, as they attempt to bounce a ball past two rows of computer opponents guarding their own goal. The player scores points for every football placed in their opponent's goal. If the player hits stationary computer opponents, they are removed from the field. If the player has 4 goals on their own net, it's game over. There are 4 levels of opponent difficulty.
title: Kickback

description:
Pool is a 1 - 2 player billiards game for the 8-bit Atari.

Played from a top-down perspective, the player moves a crosshair, which controls the direction the white ball is shot. A meter on the left side of the screen determines the strength of the shot. There are 6 pockets, and each game starts with a break. There is a practice mode, where a single player can sink which balls they like. There is also an 8-ball, which is a 2-player game, and tournament, which counts scratches.
title: Pool

description:
Snooker & Billiards is a 1 - 2 player billiards game for the 8-bit Atari.

Contains two separate billiards games. Played from a top-down perspective, the player moves a crosshair, which controls the direction the active ball is shot. A meter on the left side of the screen determines the strength of the shot. There is a 1-player practice mode, where a single player can sink which balls they like. In the 2-player game, players take turns playing, and the game tracks score and total time played.
title: Snooker & Billiards

description:
Super Cubes and Tilt is a 1-player series of games for the 8-bit Atari.

  • Super Cube: a 1-player Rubik's cube game with 2 x 2, 3 x 3, or a 4 x 4 cube. There are 9 levels of skill, and the player can rotate individual parts of the cube.

  • Tilt: Try to roll balls into holes by tilting a maze.
title: Super Cubes and Tilt

description:
Labyrinth Run is a maze game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player must navigate 1 of 3 possible mazes in as little time as possible. There are 3 difficulty levels, that define the speed the player moves and what happens when a wall is hit. The player can choose a sprint, or attempt to complete the whole maze, and there is also the option for rotating doors.
title: Labyrinth Run

description:
Gin Rummy is a graphical 1-player card game for the Atari 8-bit computer.

Follows typical gin rummy rules, and individual cards can be selected via menu. The player and the computer take turns drawing and discarding cards from either the deck or the up card. Players try to play 3 in a row or 3 of a kind for points. The first player to use all 10 cards is the winner. Players must correctly count their cards at the end of a round.
title: Gin Rummy

description:
Casino Blackjack is a 1-player card game for the 8-bit Atari.

A card counting blackjack game versus the computer. The player has up to 5 card sets simultaneously versus the computer. Players start with $1000, and can play $10, $150, or $350 games. On each round, the player can stand, hit, double, or split. Players choose from 3 levels of game speed, and can use 1, 2, 4, or 6 decks for card counting.
title: Casino Blackjack

description:
Sentinel One is a 1-player side-scrolling arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small spaceship that can fly in all directions, and fires directly forwards. The player confronts progressively more lengthy enemy waves, but the enemies do not become more difficult. The player has limited fuel to complete each wave, and when enough enemy ships are destroyed, the player refuels, and starts a new wave. The player has 3 ships, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Sentinel One

description:
You have decided to venture into Dracula's castle in search of treasure. The halls are infested with vampires, werewolves and monsters, and your aim is to survive the beasties and accumulate as much gold as possible in this text based dungeon crawler.

The game begins in a shop in Room 1 of the castle, which sells various items. Food is important, as without this your health will drain quickly. Armour will protect your health against supernatural violence, but will slowly wear away with each attack. Then there are three types of weapon: silver bullets which can only be used to kill werewolves, wooden stakes for vampires and a sword for miscellaneous monsters. Like the armour, the sword will eventually wear out and needs to be periodically renewed.

Two special items are also available for sale. There is a cross, which will prevent vampires from attacking. There is also a magic ring, which when activated will teleport you to the nearest shop (and may actually create a new shop if an existing one is not handy).

Most of the game takes place in rooms of the castle. These are screens of text with a room number, a list of all of the compass bearings of the exits from the room, and a list of all of the monsters and gold present within the room. You can choose to attack the monsters, which automatically uses the correct weapons for dispatching the different types of foe. If you fail to kill the monsters, or if you try to leave the room without killing them, then they get a shot at you, and your life counter will decrease if they successfully attack. If you leave a room containing gold after killing all of the enemies in it, you will pick up some percentage of that gold (this percentage may be zero).

While visiting rooms, other effects may occur. Sometimes a demon will steal some or all of your money unless you kill it first. For this reason, it is a good idea to leave most of your money in the bank at the shop. Also, Igor will sometimes appear and steal your holy cross, making you more vulnerable to vampires. A map of all of the visited rooms is available, but it only shows the direction of your last exit from that room instead of showing all available exits.

sample_screenshots.caption: A random room in the castle.

title: Drac is Back

description:
Stratoblaster Outpost is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

You are the Earth's last defense. The player controls a small turret in the bottom center of the screen that can rotate 180 degrees and fire at enemies. Enemy alien vessels can approach vertically, horizontally, or at random directions. The player has a limited amount of fire available, and at the end of the game the play is shown their hit to miss ratio.
title: Stratoblaster Outpost

description:
Super Barricade is a 2-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player controls a small character which moves in the 4 cardinal directions, and leaves a tail behind them. If a player strikes the wall or a tail, then they lose the game. The game tracks wins for each player.
title: Super Barricade

description:
Sleuth is a 2-player puzzle game for the 8-bit Atari.

The game generates a 4 x 4 or a 5 x 5 puzzle containing letters. Players score points by spelling words while moving from 1 position to the next. The larger the word, the higher the point score. Each game lasts 3 minutes, and players compare and count their word list.
title: Sleuth

description:
Ricochet is a 1-player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari computer.

Hidden within an 8 x 8 grid lies 5 hidden objects. The player fires a beam into the grid from 32 separate positions, and must determine the location of the objects by the output. If the beam aligns directly with an object, it is absorbed. If a beam is fired adjacent to an object, it is reflected away by 90 degrees. Beams continue to ricochet until they exit the grid or are absorbed. At the end of the game, the player is shown the true location of items.
title: Ricochet

description:
World Series is a 2-player baseball game for the 8-bit Atari.

There are 8 speeds of pitches, and the player can throw straight or curveballs. In the outfield, the player can dive left, right, or jump to try to catch the ball. After each half inning, the computer displays a scoreboard which shows hits, runs, errors, and hitting percentage.
title: World Series

description:
Astromeda is an action game where the objective is to pick up fellow astronauts drifting in space, reach the alien mother ship and destroy it. To destroy the mother ship you must first destroy the aliens along way. Meteorites need to be avoided as they are deadly.

The game uses an overhead screen with a view of the playing area consisting of ten screens. You pilot a twin-cannoned craft from left to right while the scenery scrolls to the east.
title: Astromeda

description:
Double Cannon is a 1-player game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls two cannons, one from each side of the screen. A small target bounces about the screen, that the player attempts to shoot. The player scores a point for each target shot. The player has limited shots for each cannon, and has a limited amount of time to shoot as many targets as possible.
title: Double Cannon

description:
Speedello is a 1-player Othello game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player takes a turn placing a colored piece on the board, with the goal being to capture the opponent's pieces between two of your own pieces. When the board is filled, the player with the most pieces is the winner.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Break the Program by Taking all of the Computer's Pieces

title: Speedello

description:
Catacombs of the Phantoms is a 1-player roleplaying game for the 8-bit Atari.

The opportunities in Pettieville were certainly not great, but when asked about adventuring opportunities, the town's doddering old wizard mentioned the Catacombs of the Phantoms. Deep within, lies the Golden Goddess of Power that the sorcerer Agalinta was rumored to have hidden.

A text-based game, the player must move deeper through numbered chambers to reach the final prize. Each player has strength, which is a health variable, and agility which affects combat ability. Each room may have a monster, a treasure chest, and a fountain. Fountains can improve strength or agility, but there are limited drinks before they go dry. Treasure chests can contain items and gold, but may also be trapped, damaging the player.

In combat, the player's agility is compared with the monster's, which determines how much strength is lost in the fight. Phantoms can appear, which may help or hinder the player.

The player also has a limited number of worms, which can burrow to lower chambers, allowing the player to skip a section of the dungeon.
title: Catacombs of the Phantoms

description:
Angle Cannon is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

A small angled cannon at the bottom of the screen constantly scrolls left and right. The cannon reflects off the mirror at the top right of the screen, and tries to strike targets on the right side of the screen. Whenever a target is hit, new targets are placed on the screen. At the end of the game, the player's proficiency and number of hits are recorded.
title: Angle Cannon

description:
Changing Hearts is a 1-player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player starts on a 3 x 3 board with 9 hearts. At the start, the center heart is light, and the surrounding 8 are dark. The goal is to flip the image, by flipping individual pieces, so that only the center heart is dark. If the player flips the middle, all adjacent pieces flip. If a corner is flipped, all 4 pieces in that corner are flipped. If a side piece is flipped, all 3 pieces on that side are flipped. If all hearts are dark, it's game over.
title: Changing Hearts

description:
Number Battle is a 1-player game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player and the computer move to different adjacent positions on a 9 x 9 board, picking up points with each movement. The player picks up points based upon the size of the number. The board can contain 1 - 3 colors, where colored pieces have a 2 - 3 multiplication of the score. The first person to reach the displayed score is the winner.
title: Number Battle

description:
Bombardment is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a crosshair, and attempts to protect 4 cities from incoming nuclear warheads by shooting them down. If a city is destroyed, they are not rebuilt. After the player clears a level, they get a score multiplier on the next more difficult level with more missiles. The player gets a total of 10 intercepting missiles per level. The game is over when all cities are destroyed.
title: Bombardment

description:
Dodge is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Two vehicles travelling in opposite directions on a circular track. The goal is to collect as many gold pellets as possible without coming in contact with the opponent vehicle. The opponent vehicle will always try to change lane towards the player, and can move one lane per opening. The player can change two lanes per opening if driving slowly, or if travelling quickly can change 1 lane at a time. The player must outmaneuver their opponent. The opponent sometimes lays down diamonds, which the player must also collect. The player starts with 3 vehicles, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Dodge

description:
Lunar Mission is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

You are attempting to land your fragile spaceship on the rocky surface of the moon. The computer draws a random lunar terrain each game with 2 possible flat landing sites. Gravity constantly pulls the player downwards, and they must land with minimal vertical and horizontal velocity to be safe. The player has 200 units of fuel to successfully land each game.
title: Lunar Mission

description:
Space Lander is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

You are attempting to land your fragile spaceship on the rocky surface of an alien planet. The player attempts to land on 1 of 5 different landing sites, each one marked with a multiplier showing the landing difficulty and points scored. The player starts with 1500 fuel, and tries to make as many successful landings as possible before their fuel is depleted. More difficult sites score more points. All movement costs fuel, and losing a lander costs 400 fuel. As the player approaches a landing site, the screen zooms in on that location.
title: Space Lander

description:
Survive is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player must survive the attack of alien creatures in a minefield. There are 12 quadrants in total, and on each level the aliens move inexorably towards the player. Aliens can be destroyed by luring them into mines or shooting them with a laser. If the player is shot by an alien, they lose 20% of their health, and it's instant game over if caught by an alien. Every quadrant has a starbase which can be docked with to restore 5% health. Each progressive level has more aliens and fewer mines.
title: Survive

description:
Number Race is a 1-player math game for the 8-bit Atari.

A string of numbers up to 5 digits ticks across the screen. The player can move the central number up or down, and if the central number matches a number in the string, that digit is removed from the string. If the string reaches 5 digits, that round is over. Each round is slightly faster, and after 5 rounds, it's game over.
title: Number Race

description:
Death Star is a 1-player maze game for the 8-bit Atari.

You are a spy for the Rebel Alliance, and have just been transported aboard the Death Star. Your mission is to find and destroy the faulty reactor, and escape the ship, before the resulting chain reaction causes an explosion destroying the vessel.

The computer draws a randomized overhead view of the reactor, and the player must move from a 1st person perspective to the reactor, set a bomb, and then escape in time. The player can view the overhead map up to 8 times.
title: Death Star

description:
Kismet II is a 1 - 4 player implementation of the popular dice game for the 8-bit Atari.

Players take turns rolling five dice, and each turn can choose which dice to keep. The player can reroll the remaining dice for 2 more rounds, keeping the five dice they prefer before choosing their scoring category. Scoring categories include 6 categories within the lower section, which include the sum of all ones to sixes. In the upper section, the categories include 3, 4, or 5 of a kind, full house, full house same color, flush, 5 dice straight, and chance (which is the sum of all dice). A game is finished when all 11 scoring categories have been used.
title: Kismet II

description:
Outer Space Attack is a 1-player Space Invaders clone for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small ship which moves horizontally at the bottom of the screen, and can fire vertically upwards. A number of alien vessels scroll horizontally across the screen, and upon reaching the side of the screen move down one row and move to the other side, while firing at the player. If they reach the bottom of the screen or hit the player, one ship is lost. Three lives down, and it's game over.
title: Outer Space Attack

description:
Crypto is a 1-player word construction game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player tries to solve a number of cryptograms by rearranging letters.
title: Crypto

alternate_titles.description: Titles as part of Space Games compilation by Educational Software
alternate_titles.title: Robot Attack

description:
Robot Battle is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

An alien race, the Organians, have declared war against Earth. They have penetrated the Earth's Orbiting Space Station and stolen the cloaking device. The player must penetrate 5 levels of the Organian spaceship, retrieve the cloaking device, and escape from the ship.

The player can move and fire in the cardinal directions. The player has 10 seconds, and a limited number of movement turns, each round. There are 3 levels of difficulty, and the player receives 4, 3, or 2 turns per round depending on the challenge. The goal each level is to evade or destroy the alien robots and spiders to reach the exit on the other side of the screen. The player has limited shield power, which is decreased when shot by enemies, making it game over when the shields are depleted. Some enemies require multiple shots to destroy, and enemies can become partially disabled. When spiders are shot, they become aggravated, and begin to fire wildly in all directions.
title: Robot Battle

description:
Just as you are flying Earth's ambassadors into the city of Canalus, hostilities with the Martians break out again and you come suddenly under attack by MAM missiles. Your goal is to make it past all of the dangers that are thrown at you across five Sectors, and destroy the enemy base.

Mars Mission II is a sequel to the vertical scrolling shoot-em-up Caverns of Mars. However, in this game the screen scrolls horizontally with gameplay more closely resembling that of the arcade game Scramble. You control a spacecraft with a forward firing gun, which may be used to destroy the various missiles and mines that get in your way. You can also shoot fuel depots, which will replenish your fuel, which would otherwise drain at a constant rate. Running out of fuel will cause the loss of a life. You may also lose a life if you collide with an enemy or with the terrain.

There are five different sectors in any given game: the country-side, the minefields of Chron, the Suburbs of Canalus (fuel is scarce here), downtown Canalus and the underground maze. At the end of the fifth sector, a hexagonal base will appear, which must be shot to complete the level. Once this is done, the game loops back to the beginning but at a higher difficulty.

sample_screenshots.caption: A near miss by a rocket.
Now to loop back to the beginning.
Destroy the base at the bottom of the screen.

title: Mars Mission II

description:
Super-Snake is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a continuously elongating line that can move in the 4 cardinal directions. The player tries to pick up tokens as they appear on the screen, with more tokens appearing with each token tagged. If the player hits their tail, the edge of the screen, or goes back on themselves, it's game over.
title: Super-Snake

description:
Paranoia is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small character, which can move in all directions, and fire in the 4 cardinal directions. The player's goal is to navigate small levels, to escape from the level using the exit at the right. Each level contains 3 aliens that fire towards the player if they come within range. If the player shoots an alien, it will appear randomly in a new area of the same level. The player has to avoid running into electrified walls or mines. The player has 3 lives, and if all are lost, it's game over.
title: Paranoia

description:
Saucer Formation is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small vessel that moves horizontally on the bottom of the screen and fires vertically. Enemy vessels move toward the bottom of the screen, firing towards the player, and then appears at the top again. When the player destroys the 3 enemy vessels, 3 new ships appear slightly larger, and require 1 more hit to destroy. If the player is hit by alien fire, they are destroyed. Three ships lost, and it's game over.
title: Saucer Formation

description:
Dawn of Civilization is a 1 - 4 player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player controls a small stone age tribe at the dawn of civilization. Played on a 12 x 12 grid, each turn a player can build legions, cultivate food, or manage farms. Tribes can also be in direct conflict with each other. If tribes become too large for food production, starvation will occur. The goal is to have the largest tribe at the end of the player determined number of turns. Players can be assign to human or computer control.
title: Dawn of Civilization

description:
Around the World is a 1-player role playing game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player attempts to travel around the world from London in as little time as possible, by travelling between major cities and locations. There are a total of 40 locations to visit. In each location, the player navigates a small scrolling map, and each area has a travel booth, a general store, a food store, and a transportation store. The player has a limited supply of food and gold, and food supplies must be maintained, or the player starves. The player can buy weapons, armor, and other protective devices at the general store, and can buy a horse, which reduces food use, at the transportation store. The player encounters random enemies, who can either be persuaded to help the player, engage the player in combat, or be fled from. The player also encounters random chests, which can provide gold or be trapped. If the player is injured in combat or in random events, they lose time. If they are severely injured, they lose a life. The player can be resurrected 3 times/game.
title: Around the World

description:
After Pearl is a 1 - 2 player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari.

A World War II Pacific theatre strategy game pitting American versus Japanese forces. Contains 3 scenarios: World War II, Midway, and Yamato. On a large scrolling map are positioned American and Japanese bases and naval forces. Each turn, the player defines movement instructions for their battleships. After this, the computer shows automatic combat reports and ship damage. The goal is to take control of the theatre of war. There are 5 levels of difficulty.
title: After Pearl

description:
Munchkin Attack is a 1-player variant of Pac-Man for the 8-bit Atari

The player moves a small character through a maze, while trying to avoid randomly moving ghosts. The player must try to collect all the dots in the maze, as well as the 4 energizers which make the ghosts temporarily vulnerable. If the player collects the dots, they progress to a more difficult level that contains an additional ghost. The player starts with 3 lives, and a life is lost when they contact a ghost. It's game over when all 3 lives are lost
title: Munchkin Attack

description:
Space Lanes is a 1 - 4 player strategy trading game for the Atari 8-bit.

In the future, man has begin to explore and colonize the stars. He has set up outposts on different planets. But these outposts are not self sufficient, and must trade raw material with other planets for supplies and finished products. To move material and supplies from one planet to another, shipping companies were formed. As the shipping companies expanded, the grew into large multi-world corporations called Space Lanes.

The players start new shipping companies and buy stocks in them. As the companies grow, stock prices go up, stocks split, and mergers occur. At the end of the game, the player worth the most is the winner.
title: Space Lanes

description:
Car Race is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small car which moves horizontally at the bottom of the screen. A race track scrolls by, and the player attempts to keep their vehicle on the road, but there is no detriment for driving off of the course. There are 4 levels of difficulty, which control how quickly the vehicle can move laterally, and there are 4 driving speeds. The game tracks time and distance travelled.
title: Car Race

description:
Success is a 4-player board game for the 8-bit Atari.

At the start of each game, each player chooses a personality from: aggressive, impulsive, pragmatic, or romantic. They also choose their primary goals in life, including: money, knowledge and intellectual curiosity, and health and happiness. The personality traits determine how often a player gets positive or negative outcomes to their roles, as well as the associated modifiers to success or failure. One game play begins, each turn a player can choose to roll a dice, move the player, flip a card, or end the turn. The computer does not track whether a specific move is valid or invalid. The player moves around the board the appropriate number of squares each turn, and flips the card their playing piece lands upon.

Flipped cards include: chance, gamble, knowledge, money, health and happiness, intellectual curiosity, and romance. These options include trivia questions, short arcade sequence, or other activities which will increase or decrease a players' 3 goals.

The game ends after a randomized number of turns, and the player who scores the highest towards his desired life goals is the winner.
title: Success

description:
Trapped is a 1 - 2 player board game for the 8-bit Atari.

The game is played in a 10 piece board, which contains a 3 x 3 square and a tenth position jutting off the center right of the square. Pieces can move at angles and in the cardinal directions. There are 3 green chasers who start on the left side of the square, and a single blue runner that starts in the center of the square. The chasers try to pin the runner in the far right position for victory. If the runner is pinned in any other position, the runner wins.
title: Trapped

description:
Arachnid is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a highly-technical robotic spider clone, which the player must try to keep alive on a plexiglass viewing area filled with radioactive alien spiders. In order to stay alive, the player must eat fruit and other spiders that are colored brown or red, while avoiding blue and yellow colored items. Some of these items fluctuate in color. The player gains health when they eat the correct colored food, but lose health when moving, or eating the wrong colored food.

Every 1000 points, the player progresses to a more difficult level, with 10 levels in total. There are 3 speeds options. On higher levels, the player must avoid the green Flying Zapper, which instantly destroys the player. The highest levels contain 2 or 3 Zappers.
title: Arachnid

description:
Five Card Stud is a 1-player card game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player competes against 4 computer opponents in a game of five card stud poker. The players each start with 2 cards, with one of the opponents; cards face down. Each round of betting, calling, or folding, 1 more card is added until 5 cards are reached. The player specifies their starting bank.
title: Five Card Stud Poker

description:
Screamin' Demon! is a 1-player pinball game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a pinball machine which has 3 separate boards. The field has multiple paddles, all of which are used simultaneously. There are 2 hidden entrances to 2 other separate boards. The player gets a total of 3 balls.
title: Screamin' Demon!

description:
Chasm Escape is a 1-2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small character who moves laterally, and can jump to avoid arrows which come from the left of the screen. The player runs along platforms to reach ladders, and attempts to climb to a higher level. If the player is hit by an arrow 5 times, it's game over. The goal is to climb as high as possible. The player can choose from 9 speed levels.
title: Chasm Escape

description:
Space Mines is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

"The Vahrenians are heading for Earth!", comes the warning call on the intercom. Remembering your orders, you rush to your ship, the only survivor at your tiny spaceport. The player launches a small ship from the center of the screen, which can move up and down. The player must avoid space mines and other attacking alien crafts to reach the top of the screen to destroy a Vahrenian spaceliner. They then must return to the spaceport, and try again.

There are 3 difficulty levels, which effects the number of space mines. The player receives 5% damage whenever they hit an obstacle, and it's game over at 100%.
title: Space Mines

description:
Cavern King is a 2-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.
