Each player moves about a series of caverns arranged as a maze on the screen. The goal is to pick up gold nuggets, and bring them to one of the 4 drop points in the maze. Chasing each player is a quickly moving monster, which if it catches the player, brings them back to the starting point, and causes them to lose a life and the nuggets they've collected. The player with the most nuggests collected after all lives are lost is the winner. There are 3 difficulty level for each player.
title: Cavern King

description:
Rebound is a 2-player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player tries to maneuver a bouncing ball into the colored target at the center of the screen. As the ball is bouncing, the player can hit the joystick to redirect it. The player gets a total of 15 redirections, and earns 1 fewer point with each bounce required to get to the target. The player can choose the number of rounds to determine the victor. There are 10 possible skills levels for each player.
title: Rebound

description:
Astron IV is a turn based top down maze game. You play a space warrior tasked with cleaning out the pirate asteroid Astron IV by visiting four levels of the complex, destroying all of the power panels, and then escaping.

Each level is a randomly generated 5x5 maze of rooms connected by corridors and one-way elevators between floors. You start on the first level with three vehicles which can transport you through the corridors of the maze. However each step brings you closer to death. You start with a power of 100, and every eight moves of your ship this power is decreased by 1 until you reach zero power and you die. When this happens, you return to control the next ship from the starting position on level 1, or if you run out of ships the game ends.

Throughout the maze, there are robot guards. Every eight of your moves, the robots will get a chance to move also. They can move further than you, but are not very smart. On their turn, robots will directly rush at you until their movement is stopped, and then will deflect in a random direction. If you are hit by the direct rush, you will lose power corresponding to the strength of the robot. During your turn, you can fire Z-bolts at the robots, either horizontally vertically or diagonally. These will reduce the strength of the robot until it reaches zero, at which point it is destroyed. Firing these bolts will also reduce your power.

There are ways to revive your power, but these are relatively scarce. On level 1, small energy orbs revive you by 5 units, and energy transmitters by about 30 units. These increase in effectiveness on higher levels, but so do the robots and their attacks. One-way elevators can be found to take you between floors.

Other objects are found throughout the complex. There are some checkered rectangular objects, which give you points for collecting. There are also power panels, which may be shot and destroyed. Once all of the panels within the maze have been disintegrated, a count-down starts and you need to reach your original position on Level 1 to escape from the complex and win the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: A square is guarded by a robot.
One of the panels to destroy on level 2.
Starting room with your three ships.
Can use the walls to hide from this level 4 bot.
The end of a less successful game.

title: Astron IV

description:
At the Codfish Ball is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small character on the bottom of the screen who moves laterally and fires vertically. Several rows of fast moving targets move across the screen. The player has 300 ammo to try to hit all the objects. IF all targets are hit before the ammo runs out, the player restarts the game, but with 10 less ammo each time.

sample_screenshots.caption: A Whole Screen of Items to Shoot

title: At the Codfish Ball

description:
Pokersam is a 1-player poker game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player competes against a single voiced opponent, Sam, in a 2-player game of five card stud poker.
title: Pokersam

description:
Timber! is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

You're Blackjack Daniels, the greatest lumberjack that ever set foot into a computer! You work for the Upland Logging Corporation, and you have to clear the forest, chopping down trees into cords, so that the logging trucks may easily transport them to the mill. While trying to chop down trees, the player must avoid forest animals including snakes, bears, and birds.

The player starts with 3 lives, and they lose one whenever they touch a forest animal. There are 3 levels of gameplay.
title: Timber!

description:
Rat Race is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

You're the waiter in a busy fast food restaurant, so busy that the the chef just throws the food wherever he has room. The player controls a hand, and tries to move the food into the correct bins at the top of the screen. The player receives points for putting an item in the correct bin, and loses a point if they miss. Running across the screen in lanes, are the rats. If the hand gets hit by a rat, the player loses a life. 3 lives, and it's game over. The player has a limited time to clear each stage. There are 3 levels of difficulty, and 3 board designs.
title: Rat Race

description:
Pyramid Run is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

You're the first person in 3000 years to have successfully reached the bottom level of the Great Pyramid of the Egyptian Pharoah Cheotemkahmen, supreme ruler of the Fifth Dynasty. All of his jewels and riches are yours to collect. All that remains is to take whatever you can carry, and climb to the exit at the top of the pyramid, and safety. Unfortunately, the Great Royal Court Sorcerers of the Fifth Dynasty were charged by Cheotemkahmen with the responsibility of ensuring that his eternal sleep should be undisturbed. They ensured that the Demons of the Dark Places would be loosed on any trespasser of the hallowed corridors of the Great Pyramid.

The player attempts to run through multiple stages of a pyramid, while avoiding various dangers. A map on the top right of the screen marks the player's progress through the many layers of the pyramid. Each level is marked into multiple smaller screens that the player must pass, as they try to run around approaching enemies. The player can pick up items that grant temporary invulnerability, and they must avid environmental dangers including lightning bolts and flames. The player starts with 9 lives, and it's game over when all are lost. There are 5 levels of difficulty.
title: Pyramid Run

description:
Phoenix Lair is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a phoenix, who can fly and flap their way through levels. The player tries to collect all eggs in a level, and fly back to their starting perch. If they touch a wall, or the edge of the screen, they lose a life. Two local Pharis villains pursue the Phoenix at higher levels. The player starts with 5 birds, can choose from 5 speed levels, and there are 10 levels in total.

In between levels, the player enters a game of jousting against the Pharis Hailex, principal knight of the Kingdom of Pharis. Success in unseating the knight without hitting the mount yields the player bonus points.
title: Phoenix Lair

description:
Abraxas Adventure #1: Assault on the Astral Rift is a 1 - 4 player RPG for the 8-bit Atari.

An Astral Rift to a world of magic has opened near an old hotel. The evil sorcerer Xamplayn of the world of magic has begun to draw power from Earth through the Astral Rift, and if he is not defeated, both worlds will be destroyed. Professor Abraxas led a doomed party to investigate this other land, and only Abraxas, gravely injured, returned alive. Now the player must control a party of 4 adventurers to defeat Xamplayn

During character creation the player creates 4 characters, consisting of the classes Linguist, Seer, Pathfinder, and Spellcaster. The player can give each character a name, and must choose set their strength, endurance, and ESP ability, with a total of 30 points.

Players are moved from a top-down perspective, and the 4 characters can be moved independently, with the lead character controlling the camera. Each player has a psychic window displayed at the bottom of the screen, which demonstrates their remaining power. Each character possess several unique magic spells. Each player has individual inventory, and can get or drop items. Games can be saved in progress. During combat, individual monsters appear on the screen, and can be engaged in combat.
title: Abraxas Adventure #1: Assault on the Astral Rift

description:
Clipper is a 1-player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari.

The year is 1850, and you have been commissioned to sail a Yankee Clipper from New York to San Francisco via Cape Horn. At the beginning of the game, the player must choose their ship, the amount of cargo to carry, the number of hands to hire, and the amount of provisions to stock.

During sailing, the player must set their direction, and sail. They receive updates on their longitude, and latitude. There is an overlying map of the Americas, but sailing decisions are made from the deck view. The player must deal with crew mutinies, dangerous sailing conditions, navigation blunders, and other dangers of the sea. The goal is to make a tidy profit at the end of the trip.
title: Clipper

description:
Astro-Quotes is a 1-player puzzle game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player attempts to solve a famous quote by solving synonyms. The player has 4 words on the top of the screen with a number of blank spaces. The player must guess the synonyms for the 4 words. For every synonym correctly guessed, all letters of that word as displayed throughout the puzzle. As the player solves synonyms, letters of the famous quote are displayed. A player completes a puzzle by solving the quote.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Can Resist Everything Except Temptation

title: Astro-Quotes

description:
Bowling is a 1 - 4 player 10-pin bowling game for the 8-bit Atari.

Played from the top-down perspective, the ball on the left side of the screen rapidly scrolls vertically, and the player chooses when to release the ball. The goal is to knock down the pins on the right side of the screen. The player can choose to play with no hook, meaning the ball travels straight, with hook, which allows the player to curve the ball, or random release, which causes the ball to be released randomly, forcing the player to hook the shot into the pins. The game keeps track of score through 10 frames.
title: Bowling

description:
Captivity is a 1-player maze game for the 8-bit Atari.

The Olympics, in the year 2000, feature a new event - the first designed to test the athlete's mine. A robot is placed deep inside a maze and relays visual information to a computer in front of the athlete. With the aid of a 3-D view on the screen in front of him or her, the athlete must guide the robot through the maze as fast as possible. The event is called Captivity.

The player attempts, from a 1st person perspective, to escape a randomly generated 26 x 15 maze. There are 20 methods of maze generation. The player can move forwards, backwards, left, and right.
title: Captivity

description:
Swamp Chomp is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Deep in the swamp of Muckedoo, it's time to head for the feeding station.

The player controls a frog, which can move in the 4 cardinal directions. The player tries to move vertically across a field that contains various lines of horizontally moving dangers. The player must cross a busy road and river to reach the feeding area at the top of the screen, and position themselves into one of the feeding stations. After this, the player morphs into a larger creature, and attempts to reach their starting area. If the player reaches all feeding areas, they complete the level. The player starts with 6 lives, and it's game over when all are lost. The player has a limited time for each journey.
title: Swamp Chomp

description:
Starship Duel is a 2-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Two starships move about the screen in all directions, and can fire directly forwards. Each player scores a point by shooting their enemy. Each player has limited ammunition, and if this runs out the ship self-destructs. More ammunition can be acquired by shooting the 'x' that appears on the screen.
title: Starship Duel

description:
Star Crystals is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small spaceship that can move in all directions, and can fire vertically left and right. A shielded enemy space station sits in the center of the screen, with a small core inside. An enemy spaceship moves laterally on the bottom of the screen, and if the player shoots it, the enemy ship moves into the larger base, and the shields drop. The player can then shoot the core for bonus points. The player has limited fuel. Fuel items drop from the top of the screen, and if the player shoots them, their fuel stores are increased. The player starts with 3 ships, and it's game over when all are lost. There are 3 levels of difficulty.
title: Star Crystals

description:
Time Bomb is a 1-player word game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player most solve a word before a stick of dynamite explodes. The player takes turns guessing letters to fill in a number of blanks, and each guess shortens the explosive's fuse. After each letter, the player has a chance to solve the puzzle. The player can also add their own words to solve.
title: Time Bomb

description:
Preschool IQ Builder 2 is an educational game for young children.

Players try to line up an upper or lowercase letter, number, shape or word with one of those displayed on the bottom of the screen.
title: Preschool IQ Builder 2

description:
Sammy the Sea Serpent is a 1-player children's game for the 8-bit Atari.

Sammy the Sea Serpent is a young sea serpent that has lost his way, washed onto land after a big storm. The player must follow instructions to lead Sammy back to the sea.

Contains 2 additional games:

  • Catch Bugs: Move an elongating serpent to catch the bugs that appear on the screen.
  • Work a Maze: Navigate the serpent through ta maze
title: Sammy the Sea Serpent

description:
Attack at EP-CYG-4 is a side-scrolling arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

It was in 2056, that the world was startled by the first communication from intelligent beings on another planet. The beings, called the Ologians, hailed from Epsilon-Cygnus-4. They brought news from their planet, that to make war bloodless, all battles would be fought by machines, and limited to "means of production". Unfortunately, these machines, tired of being destroyed in the Ologian battles, revolted and called themselves the Tartillians. Not satisfied with just destroying the Ologians, the Tartillians have set their sights on the Earth. In 2072, the first Tartillian interplanetary bomb was detonated above the Earth's surface. Fortunately, the Earth has spent the last 16 years preparing for the counterattack, and the first squadron of Earth's attack force is now approaching EP-CYG-4.

The player controls a Gravitron Drive attack ship to attack the surface of EP-CYG-4. The ship can be moved in all directions, and the direction of its firing can be rotated 360 degrees. The player travels through a number of screens of alien terrain, and tries to destroy all of the alien installations
title: Attack at EP-CYG-4

description:
Castles and Keys is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small character who can move in all directions, and must maneuver through 10 separate levels of moving platforms and walls. On each level, the goal is to reach the castle, and some levels require the player to collect a key before doing this. Challenges include color changing platforms, electrical walls, dodging arrows, moving across floating platforms, and climbing moving ladders. The player attempts to complete as many levels as possible in 30 minutes, with each death costing 30 seconds. There are 4 levels of difficulty.
title: Castles and Keys

description:
Flapper is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small bird that moves sideways, and can flap its wings to gain height. The player tries to gather all the fruit on the screen before the sun in the background sets, while avoiding other creatures that move about the screen or fire on the player. The player has 3 lives, and it's game over when all are lost. The type of fruit changes each level.
title: Flapper

description:
Fortune Hunter is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a character that tries to acquire treasure from 6 separate vaults. The character can move in all directions, and can shoot arrows sideways or angled. The player must avoid touching walls. The player must acquire: a candle, cash, gold, a genie's lamp, and a treasure chest. There are 9 levels of difficulty, which control the speed of game play. The player starts with 5 lives, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Fortune Hunter

description:
Hot Lips! is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player moves a smiley-faced character through a small maze containing a big set of crushing jaws. Constantly chasing the player is 4 monsters. A number of squares on the map slow the player down, making it more difficult to avoid the monsters. The goal is to lure the monsters into the crushing jaws to destroy them. Bonus items randomly appear on the screen for a limited period of time. Each level the monsters become slightly faster. The player starts with 3 lives, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Hot Lips!

description:
Trion is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small spaceship which can move in all directions and fires vertically forwards. Divided into two levels, in the first section, the player must move through a series of canyons, while avoiding the walls and shooting enemies. Ammo and fuel power appear on walls. On the second section, the player is in an endless tunnel, and can shoot alien ships for fuel and ammo.while avoiding the walls.

The player has limited ammo and fuel, which can be replenished by shooting enemies and powerups. The game is over when all fuel is lost. There are 9 levels of difficulty, which control game speed.
title: Trion: In 3 Dimensions

description:
Sea Chase is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small submarine which can move in all directions, and fires vertically forwards. The player must avoid a number of mines and a ship which moves about above the water dropping depth charges that explode at random depths. The player has limited fuel, which is replenished by collecting bonus items. The player has to gather various items, and after collecting 10, a torpedo appears, which the player can fire at the battleship to complete the level. If the player misses with their single torpedo, they must restart the level. The battleship can launch an attack submarine, which also moves about firing at the player. The player can shoot and destroy the submarine and the depth charges. The player starts with 5 lives, and it's game over when all are lost. If the bonus score reaches 0, it's game over.
title: Sea Chase

description:
Spark Bugs is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls an electric cobra, who must reconnect the world's energy grid. The cobra moves horizontally on a series of platforms, and can drag energy conduits horizontally. The goal is to connect all of the conduits, so that they bring energy to the surface, activating the electrical field, and zapping the moth that flies across the top of the screen. To defend itself, the cobra can shoot electric bolts, which damage some creatures, but can also jump out of the way to avoid other monsters as they pass. The large moth at the top of the screen drops battery beetles, which will disconnect conduits by hauling them off to the side of the screen. The cobra can move up or down to any level that has been connected to conduits, but to travel higher, or to go lower if the beetles remove conduits, must use the elevators at the sides of the screen. The player starts with 3 lives, and it's game over if all are lost. The player loses a life if they are hit by an enemy or if the timer runs out.
title: Spark Bugs

description:
Starion is a 1-player sidescrolling arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Your goal is to rescue the asteroid belt castaways, by taking them four by four to the blue transporter tubes. The player controls a small spaceship which can move in all directions, including marginally backwards, but still steadily moves to the right. The player can only fire to the right. The player must maneuver past a number of dangers including alien lasers, moving walls, space vessels, and electrical fields. The player must reach into the cavern where the castaways are stranded, use their laser to pick up 4 each visit. After dropping off 4 castaways, the player repeats the level to gather 4 more. The player has limited fuel and oxygen. Fuel can be picked up by shooting depots. The player starts with 3 ships, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Starion

description:
Whiz Kid is a 1-player educational arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small character that moves in all directions, and uses their stick to slide letter blocks around the screen. The player tries to spell the word displayed on the screen, while avoiding monsters on the screen that move towards the player. Monsters can be temporarily disabled by sliding blocks into them.
title: Whiz Kid

description:
Bumperball is a 1 - 2 player action game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player horizontally moves multiple rows of angled bumpers to try to maneuver balls dropped from the top center of the screen into various bins. Each bin has a different score, and the player's final score is the accumulation of all 5 ball drops. There are 6 rows of bumpers, which can be maneuvered one at a time. Bumper position is reset each drop, and bumpers can only be slid when a ball is in motion.
title: Bumperball

description:
Space Ace is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small space vessel that can travel in all directions, and fires vertically forwards. Constantly scrolling asteroids move towards the player, which must be dodged or destroyed. The player must avoid Silurian Space Mines with alternating visibility, Silurian Warships which streak towards the player, and the large rotating Death Vortex. The player's score is based upon items destroyed, and gameplay becomes progressively faster. The player starts with 5 lives, and it's game over when all are lost. There are 3 levels of difficulty.
title: Space Ace

description:
Tax Dodge is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player must avoid 4 pursuing taxmen, while trying to pick up stacks of cash in a maze. On each level, the player is given a total of one year, as displayed in half month intervals, to collect a goal amount of cash. Every time the taxmen catch the player, they lose $1000, which the taxman brings to the IRS. If the player runs over the inflation or deduction squares, they lose $100. Red tape squares slow the player down. The player tries to have the goal amount of cash before the year is over to progress to the next level.
title: Tax Dodge

description:
Astrowarriors is a 2 - 4 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player controls a small vessel which can rotate 360 degrees, and accelerate and fire forwards. Each vessel is also armed with 8 uses of a shield that protects them from enemy fire. Each ship has limited fuel, used by acceleration and firing, and is destroyed if they run out. If a ship travels off the side of the screen, they appear again on a random edge. The goal is to shoot the opponent, and score is kept over multiple rounds. There are different terrains, placing an asteroid, sun, or black hole in the center of the screen. The sun and black hole will create gravity, constantly pulling ships in.
title: Astrowarriors

description:
Lifespan is a 1-player series of arcade games for the 8-bit Atari.

Lifespan is a game about living in which the player travels through Opportunities, Experiences, and Situations in 5 stages of life. During these stages, the player attempts to live life to its fullest potential against a clock of decreasing years.

The game starts with the Birth, represented by a spiral emerging from the blackness. The player can interact with the spiral's music during this stage, but Birth is otherwise not interactive for the player.

The spiral then fades, and the player enters a playpen representing Childhood. During this stage, the player tries to move 10 blocks around to capture 4 of the 5 rapidly bouncing character types in the corners of the screen. One of the remaining free character types when time runs out will become the player's character type. The number of captured character types determines the player's lifespan from 67 to 99 years. As the game progresses, and the player takes damage, years of life are lost.

The player now enters the Adulthood portion of the game, which consists of 3 separate mini-games. The player tries to make four passes through all 3 segments in an effort to collect all five initially glimpsed character types.

During the first game, the player travels through space, and can accelerate or decelerate. as they travel, they see different character types, with the goal to find one that aligns with the player's type in color and form. Once choosing a type, the player must travel through an opportunity gate, by positioning their pointer in the center of the gate. The closer the selected character type is to their own, the fewer common interest squares required in the next game.

From here, the player enters Situations & Conversations. This is represented by a grid densely populated by rapidly moving creatures. When three creatures come close together, they form a connecting link. The player must come in contact with common interest squares the same color as the connecting link. The player must enter the center of the conversation after acquiring common interest squares, and must stay there for 3 seconds, and you will be accepted into the group.

Finally, the player enters the Experience Corridor. Here, the player positions their character within a rapidly moving corridor. During the day, the player must avoid black enemies representing fear and doubt, while collecting the white characters representing hope. At night, all of these harass the player, and they must avoid all enemies. If the player survives the tunnel, the will restart adulthood, and try to gather the next character type until they have gathered all 4.
title: Lifespan

description:
Ozzy's Orchard is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Can you protect the fruit in the orchard from voracious fruit bees through 4 growing seasons?

The bees start at the left edge of the screen and randomly weave between rows of the orchard until they reach the bottom right corner of the screen. There, they will gobble up a piece of the 4 apples on the right side of the screen. Ozzy is armed with a spray gun, and tries to shoot the bees. The player has limited spray, and must refill at 1 of the 4 refill stations if empty. The white bees will shoot at the player, and if a white bee touches or shoots the player, they lose a life. If all apples are eaten, it's game over. If all lives are lost, it's game over.
title: Ozzy's Orchard

description:
Space Knights is a series of short arcade games designed to be played along with the scenes in a novel of the same name. Space Knights features newly graduated space cadet Jake, his second mate Lisa, and their antique artificial intelligence CLIDE, as they investigate and defeat a threat by the Gammalon Pirates.

Contains the following mini-games

  • Bug Buster: Control the friendly robot, Suzy, in a battle against nine deadly microbes. The challenge is to destroy as many bugs as possible before they escape off the screen to attack Hank's Cosmos vines. The player starts with 99 units of energy, and is depleted by a variety of actions. Options include slow or fast speed, using bug spray, or allowing the Protector.
  • Corridors of Time: Guide your spaceship safely left or right through the two ladder-like boundaries of the Corridor. The longer your ship survives, the higher it will climb up the screen. Levels increase as it ascends, until it reaches level 10 and the game's end.
  • Gammalon Encounter: Pits you against three Gammalon warships in a battle to the death. Before they can see the enemy, the player must decode 8 of the 9 squares of the Gammalon code. The player has 64 seconds and 16 missiles to destroy the enemy ships.
  • Impact: Descend a space lander to the surface of a planet from a first person perspective. Control the vessel using your side thrusters.
  • Mind Demons: The player tries to grab a symbol from the top of the playing field, put it in a treasure chest at the bottom, and race back for more. The player must avoid the sneak thief, jolly roger, bat, and alter ego.
  • Navigate: You can travel between 144 different possible combinations of planets. You must select the planet to head towards, and plot your course and burn vectors on the Galactic Map.
  • War Room: The player must travel through 3 to 9 rooms, and can have path hazards, electrified walls, both, or none.
  • Weomby: Land a shuttle on the surface of the planet. There are 3 gravity options, and the player controls the vertical and horizontal thrust. The player has limited fuel.
title: Space Knights

description:
Devil's Date is a 1- 4 player board game for the 8-bit Atari.

The players and opponents take turns placing tiles on a board of variable size from 5 x 5 to 16 x 16. The goal is to score 5 in a row. The player receives a score based upon the time required to beat their opponent. A computer opponent is available for 1-player games. .
title: Devil's Dare

description:
Bio-Defense is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player searches a human body for infection, and then controls a white blood cell to gobble up bacteria. Gameplay is divided into 2 parts. In the first, the player searches a human body divided into a grid, attempting to find an area of high infection. The patient's temperate and heart rate are displayed on the screen. After finding the infection, the player enters an arcade sequence where they move a white blood cell around a maze trying to gobble up the bacteria. Different-sized rod-like structures temporarily slow the player down if they come in contact. If too many contact the player the patient's temperature increases. There are 4 levels of difficulty, as determined by the patient's starting temperature .
title: Bio-Defense

description:
All Star Baseball is a 2-player baseball game for the 8-bit Atari.

The pitcher throws the ball, and can control its course left and right. The batter tries to hit the ball when it is over the plate. The player scores a hit if not caught by the 3 outfielders. The game tracks balls, strikes, hits, runs, and outs over 9 innings of play.
title: All Star Baseball

description:
Stun Trap is a two-player spacecraft shooter, which may be played against another human or against the computer. The players occupy different sides of the screen separated by a barrier, which is impenetrable to ships but not to their missile weapons. Shooting an opponent will temporarily disable them, and cause this barrier to shift towards their side of the board. The aim is then to stun the opponent sufficiently often that the barrier traps them with no room to move, at which point you win the game.

There are a few nuances to game-play. For instance, every missile shot causes hyperspikes to break out in the wall immediately behind it. These spikes are deadly to the touch, and can be used to restrict your opponent's movement. Also, while shooting at each other, either side may be occasionally attacked by rammers, space mines, streakers and smart bombs.

sample_screenshots.caption: Player 1 is getting the upper hand.
About even, but Player 1's hyperspikes are quite long.

title: Stun Trap
The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai: Across the Eighth Dimension!

description:
Matterhorn is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player must travel through 4 side-scrolling screens of dangerous obstacles to reach the top of the Matterhorn. The player must avoid dangers including laser shooting birds and bouncing boulders. Players can use nearby terrain to avoid enemy attacks, and can acquire weapons to defeat incoming birds.
title: Matterhorn

description:
Survival is a 1- 6 player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari.

You are stranded on the alien world of Coryphire. Your only chance of survival is to travel 340 km to an abandoned research station. Unfortunately, the planet has difficult terrain and is populated by several carnivorous and hungry life forms. Your skill and cunning are your main tool. You will salvage as much as you can from your starship and begin your trek. With a fair amount of luck, your supplies should last. If you hurry!

The player has a total of 6 days of food to reach their destination, and each day is divided into 3 turns: morning, evening, and night. Each player starts at a preset location on the overhead map, and they can only move during daylight. The player chooses their starting weapons with a limited weight restriction, with each piece having distinct ammo load.

Movement occurs on an overhead map, where the player specifies which direction to travel each turn. There are 8 terrain types, which effect movement speed and possible monster encounters. The player has 6 movement turns per round. During movement, the player can encounter dangerous alien lifeforms. These are fought in ranged and then close combat, where the player must select which weapon to use, and how much ammo they have remaining. Each hit will sap a single health point from the player or enemy.
title: Survival

description:
The War of the Worlds is a 1-player strategy war game for the 8-bit Atari.

Based upon the H. G. Wells novel The War of the Worlds, the player controls an infantry, cavalry, and artillery unit in combat against the attack emanating from an alien cylinder. Played on a terrain map, player units can move quickly along railroad tracks. Each turn, there is a chance for alien cylinders or player reinforcements to arrive. Troops can be moved, and brought into combat. Aliens will wreck terrain, and the player must defeat aliens as they emerge from cylinders.
title: The War of the Worlds

description: Star Trek 3.2 is a derivation of the classic mainframe Star Trek game from 1971. The Enterprise needs to fly around the galaxy searching and destroying a set number of Klingon ships in a specified timeframe. The Enterprise is outfitted with shields, phasers, and photon torpedoes, and the player can reference the library computer for scans and target analysis. Starbases are available at which the Enterprise can be refueled, unless the Klingons destroy them.
title: Star Trek 3.2

description:
The Alphabet Arcade is a series of 3 educational games for the 8-bit Atari.

Three fun, challenging programs that help develop alphabetization and dictionary skills. An excellent learning and reinforcement tool for elementary school children. In one game, putting letters in the correct order feeds a hungry animal. In another, alphabetizing letters and short words helps Diver Dan recover sunken treasure. Then children must alphabetize words in a program that presents lists of increasing length and difficulty.
title: The Alphabet Arcade

description:
You want to marry the Princess Dilayna, but her father hates you! In an effort to get rid of you, the king has set you a seemingly impossible challenge. You must defeat three evil wizards living in three separate castles. If you succeed, you may marry the princess. But if you happen to die in the attempt... oh well.

Castle quest is a top-down stealth game. You must solve a series of 10 rooms in each castle in order to get to the wizards. Each room contains a bunch of walls that are lethal to the touch, some unpredictably moving guardian creatures and two keys. The second key only appears once the first key is collected, and the aim is to get to each of these keys while avoiding the guards. This will open up an exit leading to the next room, which must be reached before a time runs out. Later rooms in the castle generally have more guardians and more complicated layouts. In room 10, collecting both keys will cause a wizard to appear. You must then destroy him and escape from the room to complete the castle.

The creatures in each room can move so quickly that you may need help in passing some of the rooms. A friendly wizard has given you a magic cloak with the power to slow down time. If you use this power too frequently though, its power will diminish and if it reaches zero will cost you a life. You start the game with three lives, and you receive another three for each castle completed. Losing all of your lives loses the game, but will at least make the king happy.

sample_screenshots.caption: A pause in the action after getting a wizard.
The wizard has appeared in Room 10.

title: Castle Quest

description:
Chicken is a simple arcade game about poultry in traffic. You control a chicken, who can move only in the vertical direction, and starts at the top of the screen. Cars pass horizontally along the road, and you must move the chicken through multiple lanes of traffic to the other end. The speed of the cars is roughly related to the difficulty level, which depends on your performance. The aim is to earn points by crossing the road as many times as possible within a time limit.

You start the game with 50 points, 30 time units (about 2 minutes) and the lowest difficulty. Each time you reach the bottom of the screen, you receive 10 points times by the difficulty, the difficulty is increased, and you are returned to the top of the screen. If you are hit by a car, you lose 20 points, the difficulty is decreased, and the game continues after shifting you slightly towards the top of the screen out of the way of the car. Every 300 points, you receive another 40 seconds of play time.
title: Chicken

description:
The megawump and his foul minions dwell in the creepy caverns, emerging only at night to steal from the local inhabitants and bring back their stolen loot. You have decided to rid the world of these loathsome beasts and have entered the caverns to find three magical items (an amulet, some arrows and a sword) with which to defeat the megawump.

You start the game in one of the caverns, with possible exits in each of the four sides of the screen. All of the caverns in the game are arranged within a 6x6 square grid. Most of them are populated with two enemies belonging to three possible types: pythons, trolls or hydra. Snakes will tend to leave you alone unless you are close enough, but hydra will follow you constantly. Contact with any enemy will result in the loss of one of your five lives. There are treasures of various sorts scattered around the place. Gold and jewelry provide you with points that add to your score. Other items include smart and dumb arrows, an amulet which gives you immunity to the megawump's lightning attack, a key which can be used to open a magic box, and a sword that can be found inside the magic box.

One of the caverns contains the megawump. On entering its lair, it will shut off all exits from the room, preventing your escape. To defeat the megawump, you must hit it with three arrows, changing its colour. Then, once it is in this vulnerable state, you can finish it off with the magic sword to win the game. To assist you in avoiding the megawump before you are ready, you can use the fact that hydras occupy the closest caves to its lair (with trolls further out, and then pythons) to guess its location.

sample_screenshots.caption: The box containing the magic sword.

title: Creepy Caverns

description:
Wordmania is a 1 - 2 player word game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player tries to rearrange a series of scrambled letters to create words. The player has a limited amount of time to solve each word, and a limited time to solve as many words as possible. The player gains points for each word solved. Each game starts with easier 3 letter words, but becomes more difficult with longer words as the game proceeds.
title: Wordmania

description:
Businessman is a simple trading game, developed in Poland. Starting with $1,000 and a debt of $30,000 (which rises at an exorbitant rate of 26% every turn), you need to buy and sell six different cargoes (tea, opium, tobacco, cannons, matches and cotton) in five different ports (Bangkok, Singapore, Madras, Calcutta and Manila). After buying and selling the cargo, you can travel to another port (each trip results in your debt increasing with interest); the prices in various ports fall and rise quite randomly. Your ultimate goal is to pay off the entire debt.

During travel, there is a chance of a storm which destroys half of your current cargo.

At any time, you can visit your creditor to repay or borrow some money.

sample_screenshots.caption: Visiting the creditor. Type in how much you want to repay.
The travel menu. Choose one of five ports or visit the creditor (called erroneously "debtor" here)
The victory screen: "Bravo! You've paid off the debt." (The second line flashes letter-by-letter below the first, and is not seen here.) You can restart the game here.
Buying the cargo. Type in a letter to choose the goods, and enter the number bought

title: Businessman

description: Fill 'Er Up is a variant of the Taito arcade game Qix. You control a cursor that can move around the outside of a 2D rectangular reservoir. In the centre is an angry starfish that moves randomly. You can make forays into the middle of the reservoir, leaving a path behind you. Once you return to the perimeter, the area formed by your path that does not contain the starfish gets filled with water. The path then becomes part of the reservoir wall. If the starfish touches you, or the path as you are making it, you will lose a life. Otherwise, once you have filled in a sufficient percentage of the reservoir, you move on to the next arena where the starfish is angrier, and you need to fill in a greater percentage of the total area.

sample_screenshots.caption: Doh! The starfish attacked my path.

title: Fill 'Er Up

description:
Roman Conquest is a 1-player strategy game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a Roman legion, and attempts to conquer and colonize at least 20 provinces to appease Julius Caesar. The player starts with 6000 Centurions, and must purchase swords, shields, horses, and sandals to supply their forces for marching and attacking. Each turn, the player can advance, where they encounter a foreign colony with a strength of 1 - 9. These colonies can be attacked, or the player can choose to leave. If the player attacks successfully, they gain citizens, slaves, and the city. If the player loses, they lose Centurions. Citizens can be drafted as new Centurions, and slaves can be sold. Each time the player advances, they must pay their troops 1 Sesterces per Centurion. It's game over if the player runs out of money.
title: Roman Conquest

description:
Speed Matter is a two-player game based on the Light Cycle minigame from the movie Tron. The two players control vehicles that are always moving forward without stopping, and leave behind a solid trail as they move. By pressing the Fire key a player can temporarily accelerate. The first player whose vehicle collides with the vehicles' trails, or with the borders of the arena, loses the round. When one of the players loses 9 rounds, the game is over, and the remaining player is declared the winner.

The game also keeps track of the players' score. Points are continually received for staying alive during a round (at the same rate by both players, making it purely cosmetic), and a player receives 100 bonus points when the opponent loses a life.

sample_screenshots.caption: Player 2 has crashed into a wall.

title: Speed Matter

description:
Knicker-Bockers is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Poor ole' Knick, all he wants to do is play. He has even found the perfect place for it, an old abandoned door factory. He just loves to go around flipping and kicking the doors all about the room until he makes them into nice colored little boxes. But no, he could not be left alone to his play, he is constantly menaced by the local toughs, "Wild Bill" and his nasty band of Grugs. They would like nothing better than to get a hold of Knick and put a stop to his door flipping fun - forever.

Knick must move from room to room flipping doors so that they make a box. He must avoid enemies. On each level, the player must make a specified number of boxes before time runs out or they are hit by one of the goons. Bonus items can be picked up on each level. The player has 3 lives each level.
title: Knicker-Bockers

description:
Midway Battles is a strategy wargame for the 8-bit Atari.

It is June 4th, 1942. You stand on the bridge of the carrier Enterprise observing your attack planes warming up on the deck, exhaust flames belching in the dawn light of this fateful day. The search planes have been out since early morning, looking for the fleet that was sighted by Midway planes yesterday. You feel terribly outclassed, seeking to engage the undefeated Imperial Japanese navy with your meager forces.

The player can participate with human or computer opponent. The Historical Midway Scenario, No Coral Sea Operation, and Random Encounter Scenario are available. The player can choose to add carriers, battleships, or both to either the American or Japanese forces. The player assigns their ships to a number of task forces. Each turn the player and Japanese forces move their ships on an overview screen, and can review the condition of their forces. The player can send out searches from Midway or their task forces, and can attack or send out a combat air patrol if enemy ships are detected.
title: Midway Battles

description:
Your spaceship is trapped in a maze on an alien world. To escape, you must pass through a series of chambers of increasing complexity (up to some maximum difficulty that is selected at the start of the game). In each chamber, you must destroy the sentry to open a door and escape through it. But if you are too slow to flee the level, the sentry is replaced, the door is closed, and you must try again.

The major difficulty in the game is in controlling your ship, which has a great deal of inertia. Accidentally colliding with a wall will cause you to bounce in the opposite direction, losing control and incurring a time penalty. Occasionally, the sentry will teleport to another part of the room. It will also teleport if you run into it.

There is no way of dying in the game. Instead, you need to escape from a certain number of chambers to win the game, and your overall score is the total amount of time used.

sample_screenshots.caption: Round 9 has the most complex layout.

title: Escape from Volantium

description:
Probe One: The Transmitter is a text adventure with graphics and arcade elements.

You are the commander of the Terran Confederation scout ship PROBE ONE. You have been sent to bring a newly developed matter transmitter to Terra before it can fall into the hands of the Drelgan Hegemony. The device is the only hope the human race has of averting extinction in their war with the Drelgans.

The player controls the probe via text entry, and each room is graphically displayed on the screen. Each room is labelled, and the player can examine and pick up items and move between rooms. Items can be picked up, used, turned off, and dropped. The goal is to escape with the transmitter, and receive points for collecting items and destroying sentinels.

The player will routinely get attacked by the defensive drones, at which point the player enters an arcade sequence where they move laterally at the bottom of the screen and attempt to shoot droids. If the player is captured by a droid, they are brought back to the starting antechamber. If the player takes too much damage, it's game over.
title: Probe One: The Transmitter

description:
Name That Song is a 2 player trivia game for the 8-bit Atari.

The players listen to a short segment of a well known song, and the first player to ring in and correctly answer the name of the song earns points. The sooner the player answers, the more points are earned. Games can go to 25, 50, or 100 points. Players can type in the name of the song or choose by multiple choice.
title: Name That Song

description:
Travel back to the days of yesteryear, to the very dark and mysterious days when out of the deep-seated fears of men grew myths of huge fire-breathing dragons and objects with unusual powers.

The player must venture to the Dark Forest to defeat the demon Ravana. The player encounters monsters from a side perspective, and must slay them using their powerful sword Fragerach. Fragerach also serves as the Answerer, and can tell the player the weakness of any monster they encounter. The player is armed with a shield that can be invoked for protection up to 5 times per game. The player is further armed with the Destroyer and Vapon powder which can harm demons. One of each must be saved for the final encounter with Ravana.
title: The Black Forest

description:
Sky Rescue is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The people of Irata are desperate and have called on the Federation for help. They are under attack by a Mad Bomber from Elppa. The Mad Bomber has shields far superior to those of the Federation, and survived all attacks from the fleet.

The Iratian's only chance for survival is if they can be taken to the shelter, where no Elpians may pass. Your mission is to transport all Iratians to the shelter using the Federation's newest rescue helicopter.

Played from a side-scrolling perspective, the player controls their helicopter to pick up Iratians one at a time, and bring them to shelter to the right of the level. The player must avoid attacks from the Mad Bomber, and if the shield is depleted the player's helicopter is destroyed. When all Iratians are rescued, the player receives a score and rating for the mission.
title: Sky Rescue

description:
Adventure on a Boat! is a simple adventure game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player sails on an 8 x 8 board, and each movement costs 5 minutes. In each location the player can choose to fish, where they randomly receive an encounter. Encounters each use 5 minutes of time. The player can find treasures and a variety of items to enhance or hinder their fishing expedition. The player can find keys to unlock chests, shields which can protect the player if they find a bomb, and enchanted swords that protect from pirate attacks. If the player moves off the map the fishing expedition is over.
title: Adventure on a Boat!

description:
Robby the Robot Catcher is an arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls Robby, a large robot at the bottom of the screen. Robby can move laterally, and tries to catch falling “baby” robots. The speed of the robots’ fall increases along with the difficulty levels. The game is over when ten are missed.
title: Robby the Robot Catcher

description: Ghostly Manor is a maze game for children. The manor is a group of boxes arranged in a 4 x 7 rectangle. Doors to the rooms are randomly generated at the start of the game. The object is to roam round the maze until you find a magic key with which to leave the room. Every room contains an object, and friendly or malign spirits.
title: Ghostly Manor

description:
Meteor Storm is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

A gigantic storm from space is approaching the planet Dracon at high speed. High above the planet's surface, a rescue ship waits helplessly, unable to penetrate the intense storm of meteor debris. You and your tiny fighter ship are the last hope for the people of Dracon.

At the start of each round, the rescue ship moves laterally at the top of the screen. Meteors and other dangers move laterally across the screen. The player must choose an opportunity to launch the tiny fighter ship, which rapidly descends towards Dracon, and must avoid dangers and land on one of the landing pads within the city. While landing, the player can move laterally and temporarily slow their descent. The fighter must then ascend to the waiting rescue ship, and during ascent can accelerate, temporarily become invisible, or fire upwards, left, and right.

Each city in Dracon has 10 survivors, and the player starts with 3 ships with a new one awarded every 10,000 points. During ascent meteors will rain on the city, and if the shield is down the player loses 1,000 points for each hit.
title: Meteor Storm

description:
Astro-Droid is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a small robot that can move in all direction and fires a shorts distance forwards. Terrain scrolls beneath the robot as it flies progressively towards the top of the screen. The player must avoid or destroy attacking enemy robots. The player can shoot items to gain brief power-ups, which increase the robot's offensive power. The player starts with 3 lives, and they are destroyed if hit and must restart a level.
title: Astro-Droid

description:
Crumble's Crisis is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

It's all your fault, Crumble! Now don't stand there snivelling and whining! YOU were in charge of closing up the Intergalactic Zoo last night. Therefore it's YOUR fault and yours alone that the timelocks on the Fuzzies cages weren't closed. Those Fuzzies may look cute and cuddly but they're mean little critters once they're loose and somebody, one of us, has to get them back in their cages. Now who do you think's got the job? Yeah, that's right Crumble, YOU!!

The player explores 5 separate mazes from a side perspective, each of which contains 6 hiding fuzzies. The player has a jetpack, and can move left, right, up, and down. If the player touches any wall or enemy they lose health from Crumble's Transversal suit, but this can be regained by picking up food. If the player spends too much time in any screen, time lighting will start to drain the suit. If the suit reaches 0, it's game over.
title: Crumble's Crisis

description:
A Day at the Races is a 1 - 4 player horse racing gambling game for the 8-bit Atari.

It's race day at Anvil Downs, and each day's card consists of 10 races. Players can start with 100 - 900 £, and can bet on one of 5 horses for each race. Betting odds and horse characteristics are displayed before each race. Each race is animated, and players win or lose their fortune based upon their bets.
title: A Day at the Races

description:
The Domain of the Undead is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

A side-scroller, where the player must combat an endless horde of skeletons, bats, and grasping hands. The player can shoot silver bullets and shoot or move laterally left or right. All shots are blocked by walls, even if these block neither enemy nor player movement. The player can duck to avoid bats, but can not shoot while ducking. The player starts with 5 crucifixes, and loses one each hit. It's game over when all are lost.
title: The Domain of the Undead

description:
Nightmares is a side-scrolling arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a flying fairy that can move in all directions and shoots horizontally. Played on a large level that scrolls left and right, the player tries to rescue 5 fairies and escape to the door that leaves the level. Opposing this goal, are large monsters at the bottom of the screen that fire upon the player, and a multitude of flying enemies that can damage the fairy. When the player's health hits 0, it's game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Died by the Exit Door

title: Nightmares

description:
Rocket Repairman is a 1-player action game for the 8-bit Atari.

Buried somewhere in the underground maze of caverns of the planet Leskos are essential components of your Astro-ship. Get into your space-suit, strap on your jet pack, and begin the most terrifying descent imaginable.

Played from a side perspective, the player navigates a series of tight caverns to gather all items for their rocket ship. The player can fire horizontally, and move in all directions, but steadily falls downwards. The spaceman can only hold 1 item at a time, which must be brought back to the launchpad. The suit has limited power, and it's game over after hitting too many enemies or walls. The suit also has limited oxygen, but this is replenished for each item returned to the launchpad. It's game over when the suit's integrity reaches 0.
title: Rocket Repairman

description:
Space Gunner is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The Earth is under attack! Flying saucers from Procryn 5 as assimilating its molecular structure for use back on their planet. They must be stopped! Strapped into your rocket suit, you cruise high into the stratosphere, waiting to blast the Alien ships to smithereens; but watch out for the Ram Star if you want to get back alive!

The player controls a spaceman who can fly in all directions and fire horizontally. Alien saucers fly about stripping pieces of the ground away. The player tries to shoot all saucers. The saucers are harmless for the player, but the Ram Star will intermittently fly across the screen, and will take the player's life if hit.

Contain the bonus game Mutant Bats, an arcade game where the player bounces a ball off a horizontally moving bat at the bottom of the screen. The goal is to destroy all blocks located above. Every missed ball costs a life.

sample_screenshots.caption: Space Gunner - Beware of Ram Star

title: Space Gunner

description:
Space Lobsters is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Captain Crumble has to fight off the Lobsters and all the other Guardians of the Colossus space ship with his plasma-blaster. He must locate computer terminals and log on to discover codes. 14 hidden codes have to be located so that Crumble can use the space station escape pod should the alien inhabitants threaten to overwhelm him. Teleport booths enable Captain Crumble to move to various corridor levels on the Colossus.

The player explores corridors, and must shoot approaching encountered aliens. The player has limited ammo and oxygen.
title: Space Lobsters

description:
Speed Run is a racing game for the 8-bit Atari.

Played from a perspective behind the driver within the vehicle itself, the player attempts to race around a single track and achieve a low time. The vehicle can accelerate and turn, and if the player tries to navigate a turn too quickly the car will stop. Automatic or standard shift is available.
title: Speed Run

description:
Sprong: The Quest for the Golden Pogostick is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player attempts to cross a number of screens from left to right on their pogostick. The player can bounce short distances or take a longer jump. If the player misses a platform they fall to their doom. Courses are complicated by moving and blinking platforms. The player starts with 5 lives, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Sprong: The Quest for the Golden Pogostick

description:
River Rat puts you at the controls of a speedboat as it races its way up a river to travel a certain distance before time runs out. You can move both ways towards the sides of the river, but can only move forwards along it. The speed with which you move forwards can be toggled between race and cruise modes.

While making your way up the river, your path will be obstructed by numerous obstacles. There are ducks, swimmers, ramps, row-boats, rocks and piers. Hitting a duck does nothing (to you), but hitting a swimmer will cause you to lose control of the craft for a few seconds, and going over a ramp will launch you into the air where your rudder no longer works. Hitting anything else will cause your boat to explode, and a loss of time when you change to the next boat. You start with three boats, and the game ends when all boats are lost.

Points are earned for distance travelled along the river. Surplus time at the end of each level is converted into extra points. Later levels become more congested, and require a further distance to be travelled.

sample_screenshots.caption: Sunk after hitting the side of a ramp.
The game begins. No obstacles in sight.

title: River Rat

description:
Assault Force is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The vicious Wan-Wrote attacked Earth without warning and destroyed all space installations. The blood-thirsty (and hungry) aliens are now rounding up the survivors of the planet for use as slaves and food. A dedicated band of scientists have created a self-repairing shielded attack vehicle to defend the Earth. The Wan-Wroth have no sense of honor or fair play, but they do have limits to the resources they can lose in their fight for possession of the Earth. Can you convince them that the Earth is too costly a prize?

Played from a 1st person perspective, the vehicle can rotate 360 degrees, move forwards and backwards, and fire. The player attempts to destroy all enemy tanks on the level to advance to the next. The player has limited fuel used by movement, and must be replenished at fuel depots. When hit by enemy tanks, the player takes damage, and if receives enough hits is destroyed. The player must also contend with enemy jets and helicopters.
title: Assault Force

description:
Collision Course is a sideways scrolling space based shoot-em-up. You control a fighter ship that is tasked with protecting a convoy of cargo ships that are hauling gems mined from the moons of Zeta III. The system is encircled by deadly mine fields, so during the trip out, you will be beset by mines of three types (regular, smart and "Mirus"). There are also time beacons, which when hit will alter your apparent velocity through space.

Your vessel is relatively maneuverable, possesses a rapid fire offensive weapon, and compared to the cargo ships is well armoured. You can sustain five or six hits during a mission, while the cargo transports will be destroyed in one hit. After successfully traversing a mine-field with at least one surviving cargo vessel, you will be given bonus points for extra ships, and a time bonus. Additionally, your shield energy will be replenished, and if you have lost one, you will be given another cargo vessel to defend. The game then continues with mines being encountered more frequently.

You can lose the game in two ways. Either your ship can sustain sufficient damage that your shields drop below zero energy, or you can arrive at a planet or space station without any cargo ships.

sample_screenshots.caption: You start the game with three cargo ships.
A cargo ship hits a mine!

title: Collision Course

description: Historia Polski is a historical educational game. The player's task is to select a proper answer from three available before the time runs out. The round takes 50 questions. The best result is added to the scoreboard.
title: Historia Polski

description:
Nineball is a pinball game with nine numbered bumpers. You start the game by shooting the pinball out of a cannon located at the bottom of the screen, which can be rotated before firing. After release, the pinball ricochets around the screen, and the cannon is replaced by a movable paddle. You can move this to prevent the ball from leaving the screen (ala Breakout ). Points are scored for your ball hitting the various bumpers. After all nine bumpers have been hit, a bonus obstacle appears which grants you extra points when hit.

There is only one level layout, but there are four game modes. Mode one plays like standard pinball. With mode 2, you lose a ball if you touch one of the bumpers you have not already hit during the game. Mode 3 adds a black hole that alternates from one side of the board to the other and will swallow your ball on collision. Mode 4 combines modes 2 and 3.

sample_screenshots.caption: Bumper numbers are hi-lighted when hit.
The black hole appears in some game modes.

title: Nineball

description:
Typing Tutor plus Word Invaders is a typing program and game for the 8-bit Atari.

Typing Tutor is a simple word typing program that registers typing speed in words per minutes

In Word Invaders, a spaceship begins to print out random words starting at the top left of the screen. When the ship completes a line, the words move down a line and a new line of random words begins to print. As the player types the words they are destroyed from the bottom of the screen. The goal is to destroy all of the words before they reach the bottom of the screen. The player receives a report on errors and typing quality at the end of each round. There are 4 levels of word difficulty and word speed.
title: Typing Tutor plus Word Invaders

description:
Gallery of Death is a carnival shooting game where the targets shoot back! You control a gun that moves back and forth across the bottom of the screen. Rows of targets scroll past, and you have to shoot them, and amass the highest possible score. You will lose a life if you are shot by a target, or if you run out of bullets. Losing all three lives ends the game.

The scoring system is a little complicated. Objects further away are worth more than closer objects. Red targets are worth less than yellow or green. And the different objects also require a different number of shots to take down, with targets in the second row taking 3 shots per hit. Targets in the final row will replenish your bullet supply by 1 to 4 shots depending on its colour.
title: Gallery of Death

description:
An earthquake has occurred in a small European town, and gold from the local bank has fallen through newly formed cracks in the Earth into a network of underground caverns and sewers. You have been hired by the bank to brave the subterranean hazards and return with the gold.

Gold Mine is a platform game, where the aim is to collect gold scattered about the level and return it to the bank to earn points. Extra points are earned for any gold returned to the bank before a timer has run down, and this timer may be reset every time $250 in gold is returned. Deadly creatures shuffle across each layer of the level, and these must be avoided otherwise one life is lost, along with any gold you had collected. As the game continues, the enemies increase in speed. The game ends once all lives are lost.
title: Gold Mine

description:
Big Math Attack is an educational math game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player can choose addition, subtraction, multiplication, or division questions. There are 4 levels of question difficulty. Enemy ships move across the screen and drop math equations that fall towards the city below. The player must answer the questions before they hit the city. Each question falls progressively faster. The player gets points for each question answered, and if the city is hit 5 times the game ends.
title: Big Math Attack

description:
Cribbage is a 1-player versus computer card game for the 8-bit Atari.

All cards are displayed via text symbols, but the cribbage board is graphically displayed on the screen. The player is required to count their own points after each hand, and the computer judges if the player's count is in agreement. There are 2 levels of computer difficulty, and on higher levels the player is penalized for incorrect counting.
title: Cribbage

description:
Fishing for Homonyms is an educational game for the 8-bit Atari.

Based upon the card game Go Fish, players try to match homonyms instead of playing cards. Each player starts with 4 words that have a homonym, and can ask the computer opponent if it has a match. If the player finds and recognizes a match, they score 2 points. If the computer does not have the card the player asks for then the player receive a new word from the pile. Gameplay continues until all matches have been found, and the player with the most matches wins.
title: Fishing for Homonyms

description:
Guessword is a 1 - 2 player word guessing game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player is presented a word by their teacher, and tries to guess the correct word with a similar meaning. If incorrect, the player receives an additional word and guess. The player receives 10 points for a correct answer on the 1st guess, and 5 points for the 2nd guess. The first player to reach 25 points is the winner.
title: Guessword

description:
Preschool fun contains 10 educational games for young children.

  • Color: Choose if 2 displayed colors are matched or different.
  • Counting: Type the number of items displayed on the screen.
  • Letter Match (capital or small): Type the letter displayed on the screen.
  • Matching: Choose which of 4 displayed shapes are different.
  • Odd Letter (capital or small): Choose which of 4 letters are different.
  • Shapes: Choose whether 2 displayed shapes are similar or different.
title: Preschool Fun

description:
Word-Scramble is a 1-player word game for the 8-bit Atari.

A robot gives the player 5 tries to unscramble a word. There are 5 levels of word difficulty. Each game has 1 - 15 words.
title: Word-Scramble

description:
Wordmate is a 1-player educational game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player and computer play Go Fish for compound words. Each player is dealt 10 cards, which can be combined to make compound words. If the player can't make a compound word they must take a card from the computer. The player with the most compound words at the end of the game is the winner.
title: Wordmate

description:
Avoid is a 2-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Each player controls a spaceship that moves laterally and fires vertically, one at the top and one at the bottom of the screen. Players must be careful not to move off the edges of the screen, and can fire only once per direction change. The player scores points by shooting their opponent or the 2 targets that move across the screen. Game play goes for 2 minutes, or until a player is hit 5 times. There are 5 levels of difficulty, and if the player outlasts 2 minutes they receive double their score and extended play.
title: Avoid

description:
California Run is a racing game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player races on a track from a view behind their vehicle trying to complete a course in the allotted time. The player can drive a Porsche, Ferrari, or Corvette, which have different grip, acceleration, and top speed characteristics. The player must safely navigate turns and splits in the road, and must avoid dangers including other cars and water hazards. If the player hits an obstacle they lose speed
title: California Run

description:
Castle Top is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

It is the year 1502, and the player's childhood sweetheart and bride to be, Jessica, has been captured by Frederick, Lord of Alconbury, and is being held captive in one of the high towers of his castle. Unless the player agrees to help him in his attempt to overthrow the King, she will suffer a slow and painful death.

The player controls a character who move laterally and jumps. They must clear levels atop a castle, reaching the right hand side of the screen. Dangers include pits, arrows, and spear throwing guards. Each game starts with 3 lives, and a life is lost if hit by a danger.
title: Castle Top

description:
Leapster is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Harry Leapster's quest is a simple one: to get to school on time. To do this, he must travel across town past houses, a missile base, a graveyard, and finally to school. Harry can move laterally and jump. On each screen, the player must collect a number of items that briefly appear as windows open and close. These can typically only be reached by jumping on top of moving vehicles, and then jumping for the item. Harry has limited time on each screen to collect enough items to move on to the next screen to the right, and he must avoid dangers including: cars, zombies, birds, arrows, balloons, missiles, troops, and more. Harry starts with 5 lives, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Leapster

description:
Winter Wally is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Percy is a first class wally. Whilst out for his morning stroll, like the wally of a penguin he is, he falls through a hole in the ice finding himself trapped in an underground maze of ice caves. In order for him to leave his unwelcome new home, he must face the dangers in the cavern such as deep crevasses, flying ice blocks and moving icebergs to reach the exit. The player controls Percy, who can move laterally and jump. Percy must collect all items on the screen to move to the next level. The player has 4 lives. If the player falls a certain distance or is hit by an object, they lose a life.
title: Winter Wally

description:
Inter Galleon Battle is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Emperor Zor, the blackheartened ruler of Zebulon Galaxy has transformed his flying legions into hypnotized kamikazes. The player must keep the rebellion alive by destroying wave after wave of Zor's zombie commandos before they slam into your ship in their cosmic covenant with death.

The player controls a ship that moves in the cardinal directions, and has to shoot incoming enemy vessels. The enemy vessels approach directly towards the player, and the player must avoid the laser turret that moves at the bottom of the screen. The player must destroy a certain number of enemies each level. The player starts with 5 lives.
title: Inter Galleon Battle

description:
Mix & Match is a 1-player memory game for the 8-bit Atari.

Four colored squares displayed on the screen beep in sequence, and the player must repeat back the sequence. The sequence prolongs by 1 each time, and the goal is to memorize as long of sequence as possible without making a mistake.
title: Mix & Match

description:
Knights & Wizards is a 2-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

King Arthur is dead. Now his terrified subjects watch as the noble wizard Merlin and the rotten fiend Prince Mordred grab for Camelot's treasure! Merlin would give gold to every peasant. Mordred would coat the moat of his dungeon with it. Fiery shots cut the air as wizard battles knight for medieval riches.

The two players move their character in all directions and can fire in the cardinal directions. The field has defenses including walls and castles to block opponents' shots. If a player is hit they return to their castle. Gold bars randomly appear on the screen, and players receive a point for collecting the gold and returning it to their castle without being shot.
title: Knights & Wizards

description:
Crown of Gold is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The Great Crusades are over, and good King Richard has returned to England to reclaim his crown. Wicked Prince John has fled, leaving Nottingham Castle booby trapped with dynamite. The crown glitters by itself in the Crown Hall, protected by deadly arrows.

The player starts in the castle hallway where they can enter 8 separate rooms. Seven of these rooms contain a maze, and the player must defuse 4 sticks of dynamite before the timer runs out. If the player enters the Crown Hall, they must cross the screen to reach the crown while avoiding streams of arrows shooting across the screen.
title: Crown of Gold

description:
Exit Watch is a 1-player arcade game for 8-bit Atari.

The maid quit, so you decided to buy a household robot to do the chores and make life easy. But, the computer at Robatahelp Inc. has gone berserk, and is programming every robot on the assembly line to roll out the factory and straight into your house. Their orders, clean up everything including you.

The player moves in all directions, and can fire in the cardinal directions. Robots rapidly appear from the edges of the screen and move towards the player. A laser beam moves slowly across the screen decreasing the play area. If the player is hit by a laser or robot it's game over. The player must destroy 30 robots and escape out the front door before the game is lost.
title: Exit Watch

description:
Radiation Dump is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Tons of powerful nuclear waste have accumulated in the land. Nowhere can it be stored safely, and mankind is threatened. Navigate a sub through deep waters teeming with sealife. Unload and expertly guide dangerous barrels of nuclear waste to the bottom by avoiding fish or bumping the drifting magnetic bomb. Fish exposed to this deadly substance could cause death if eaten, so the player must be careful how they discard the waste. The player has limited time to try to guide all 25 barrels to the bottom of the sea. The game starts with 5000 units of sealife, and the score is reduced with each collision with sealife.
title: Radiation Dump

description:
Cash In is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Days of devious plotting lead to the exciting moment of the big armored car hold-up. The player focuses on the dangerous driving, and must careen through city streets outrunning treacherous gangster cars. Millions of dollars are at stake!

There are 6 levels of difficulty, and the player starts with 3 lives. The player can pick up money from the 4 corners of the screen, and the value in each corner steadily increases up to $99. Money can then be brought to the center of the screen to add to the player's score. The player loses a life if they contact a mobster car.
title: Cash In

description:
Fog is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

World War II has begun, and President Roosevelt has just announced his lend-lease program to supply Britain with ships and planes to defend against Nazi attack. The player must guide the battleship "America" across the Atlantic amidst dense fog in waters crawling with Nazi ships determined to keep the ship from reaching England.

The player tries to navigate their ship from the left to the right of the screen while avoiding incoming vessels. To complicate matters, enemy ships only appear through the fog for a brief period before flickering out again. The player receives 100 points each time they cross the screen, but if they hit an object they are repositioned back to the left. The goal is to maximize score over 3 minutes of play.
title: Fog

description:
Atlantis Conflict is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

Deep in sparking blue-green waters sleeps the wonderful city of Atlantis. Suddenly, without warning, strange and devilish forces attack. The player must guide their sub to shoot torpedoes at incoming enemies. The player starts at Atlantis, and all movement of their ship costs fuel. The ship can only shoot horizontally, but enemies come from above. The player can refuel by returning to Atlantis. Each level, the player must destroy a certain number of enemies to advance to the next. If 5 enemies reach Atlantis the city is destroy and it's game over. If the player's ship is destroyed or runs out of fuel 3 times, the game also ends.
title: Atlantis Conflict

description:
Copter Chase is a 1-player arcade game for the 8-bit Atari.

The player controls a helicopter which can move in all directions, with the goal of catching a quickly moving purple object. The player must avoid incoming planes and rapidly moving helicopters.
